{"uri": "2024-05-348974864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:09:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:09:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:08:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/5/8/chinese-leader-xi-jinping-and-serbian-president-hail-ironclad-friendship-in-belgrade", "title": "Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Serbian president hail 'ironclad' friendship in Belgrade", "body": "BELGRADE, Serbia -- Chinese President Xi Jinping met Wednesday with the Serbian president, with both sides expressing optimism that the visit will further boost the \"ironclad\" friendly relations between China and the Balkan country, an European Union candidate.\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping, left, shakes hands with his Serbian counterpart Aleksandar Vucic greet the crowd at the Serbia Palace in Belgrade, Serbia, Wednesday, May 8, 2024. (AP Photo/Darko Bandic)\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks are being held.\n\nSerbia's populist President Aleksandar Vucic addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said hs visit to Serbia is \"historic\" because it opens the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many (people,)\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi will proceed to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were clearly visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of those agreements, like the trade without tariffs with China, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\n\"Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xi said in a statement published by China's Foreign Ministry.\n\n\"Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation,\" added Xi. \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations.\"\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, Turkey and Bulgaria, was seen by experts as a demonstration of China's growing global reach.", "source": {"uri": "mb.com.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "Manila Bulletin"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-05-349179642", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "15:01:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T15:01:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T15:00:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.courthousenews.com/chinas-xi-welcomed-with-respect-and-love-in-serbia/", "title": "China's Xi welcomed with 'respect and love' in Serbia", "body": "The visit came on the 25th anniversary of NATO's bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, which killed three people.\n\nBELGRADE, Serbia (AFP) -- Serbia on Wednesday rolled out the red carpet for Chinese President Xi Jinping on the second stage of a European tour aimed at deepening political and economic ties despite tensions over the war in Ukraine.\n\nXi arrived in the Serbian capital Tuesday evening following a state visit to France that saw sometimes robust exchanges with President Emmanuel Macron on trade and China's close ties to Russia despite the Ukraine war.\n\nBut the other two countries chosen for Xi's first trip to Europe since 2019 -- with Hungary as the final stop after Serbia -- are among the most sympathetic to Moscow in Europe.\n\nChina has poured billions into Serbia and neighboring Balkan countries, particularly into mining and manufacturing, and last year Beijing and Belgrade signed a free trade agreement.\n\nSerbia's President Aleksandar Vucic greeted Xi and his wife Peng Liyuan on a red carpet outside the main government offices in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nThe Chinese leader was met by a gun salute before shaking hands with officials, including the prime minister and the National Bank of Serbia governor.\n\nThe two leaders waved from a balcony to several thousand people, some waving Chinese flags, as Vucic called Xi a \"friend of Serbia.\"\n\n\"Such respect and love as he will find here in our Serbia, he will not find anywhere else,\" Vucic added.\n\nHe told the crowd as Xi applauded: \"We have a clear and simple position regarding Chinese territorial integrity. Yes, Taiwan is China.\"\n\nBeijing claims the self-ruled island as its own, and has not ruled out using force to bring it under Chinese control.\n\nXi told Vucic in opening comments that there was a \"strong feeling of friendship between our two countries.\"\n\n\"I hope that this visit will meet your expectations and show the contribution that China can make to Serbia,\" he said.\n\nThey later appeared together to sign a joint declaration, with commercial promises including the purchase of new Chinese trains, new air links and increased Serbian imports.\n\nNATO bombing\n\nIn Belgrade Xi received a warm welcome, with streets decked out with Chinese flags and posters proclaiming a \"warm welcome\" to \"Chinese friends.\"\n\nHis visit coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 U.S. bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, which killed three people.\n\n\"Do not forget that our Chinese friends were with us 25 years ago when this country was being demolished and bombed,\" Vucic told crowds Wednesday.\n\nThe embassy was hit during a months-long, U.S.-led NATO campaign targeting Serbian security forces who were at war with ethnic-Albanian insurgents in Kosovo.\n\nThe U.S. later apologized, saying outdated maps had led the pilot to strike the wrong target.\n\nOn Tuesday, Xi wrote in the Serbian daily Politika that NATO had \"flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy,\" warning that China would \"never allow such tragic history to repeat itself.\"\n\nSerbia has repeatedly supported China's claims over Taiwan and in turn, Beijing has long backed Serbia's territorial claims over the breakaway province of Kosovo.\n\nAlong with Russia, China has prevented Kosovo's recognition at the United Nations.\n\nXi called for the two countries to \"firmly support each other's core interests.\"\n\n\"China supports Serbia in upholding its policy of acting independently ... (and) its efforts to safeguard national sovereignty and territorial integrity on the Kosovo issue,\" he said Wednesday.\n\nUkraine fears\n\n\"For Serbia, this is without a doubt one of the most significant visits,\" Marko Tmusic, a political sciences professor at the University of Belgrade, told AFP.\n\nIn Belgrade, many welcomed Xi's visit.\n\n\"I think it's an excellent thing, this visit from the president of one of the most powerful countries in the world,\" 67-year-old Stojan Vidovic, a retiree, told AFP.\n\nIn France, Xi met with Macron and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen who urged him not to allow the export of technology that could be used by Russia in Ukraine and to do all it could to end the war.\n\nXi warned the West not to \"smear\" China over the conflict and hit back at accusations that Chinese overcapacity was causing global trade imbalances.\n\nSome European allies are concerned that while officially neutral over the Ukraine conflict, China is essentially backing Russia, which is using Chinese machine tools in arms production.\n\nAfter meeting with Vucic, Xi will go later Wednesday to Hungary where China has invested heavily in vast battery and electric vehicle manufacturing plants.\n\n--\n\nBy MINA PEJAKOVIC and HELEN ROXBURGH, Agence France-Presse", "source": {"uri": "courthousenews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Court House News {"uri": "8117151601", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "10:19:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T10:19:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T10:19:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/explainers/serbia-xi-jinping-red-carpet-13768579.html", "title": "Why is Serbia giving Xi Jinping the red carpet treatment?", "body": "China's Xi Jinping and Serbian president Aleksandar Vucic insist that their countries have an 'ironclad partnership.' Reuters\n\nXi Jinping is getting the royal treatment in Serbia.\n\nThe Chinese premier's visit to Europe - a rare one and his first since 2019 - saw him head to France on Monday before arriving in Serbia on Tuesday night.\n\nSerbian President Aleksandar Vucic and government officials welcomed Xi at the Belgrade airport, where he was greeted by a military guard of honour and folk dancers.\n\nThe two leaders will hold a meeting on Wednesday.\n\nThe Belgrade streets were decorated with Chinese flags and placards as thousands of police officers were deployed to secure Xi and his 400-member entourage, the highest-level visit by a foreign leader in years.\n\nWhile some might be surprised that the leader of China has included Serbia on his European sojourn, a look at recent history shows that shouldn't be the case.\n\nSerbia is now seen as China's most important partner in the Balkans\n\nLet's take a look at why Serbia is rolling out the red carpet for Xi.\n\nAccording to RFERL.org, China and Serbia first began improving ties when Vucic's SNS took power in 2012.\n\nRelations were strengthened during Xi's first visit to Belgrade in 2016 when the two countries signed a strategic partnership.\n\nMore importantly, China has given Serbia billions of dollars in infrastructure loans.\n\nIt runs mines and factories across the Balkan country.\n\nSerbian president Aleksandar Vucic describes Xi as a 'friend.'\n\nSerbia is also Europe's firmest supporter of China's Belt and Road Initiative.\n\nBoth Serbia and Hungary are part of China's a Belt and Road Initiative to modernise the railway between the countries' capitals of Budapest and Belgrade and connect them to the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece as an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe bulk of the project, which after numerous delays is expected to be completed in 2026, is financed through loans from Chinese banks -- the kind of capital that Hungary and Serbia have been eager to utilise.\n\nAccording to the AidData research lab at William & Mary, a public university in Virginia, Chinese lenders have issued loans worth more than $22 billion to nine countries in Central and Eastern Europe between 2000 and 2021.\n\nOf that sum, $5.7 billion has gone to Serbia alone.\n\nThe bulk of the project, which after numerous delays is expected to be completed in 2026, is financed through loans from Chinese banks -- the kind of capital that Hungary and Serbia have been eager to utilise.\n\nChina is also popular in Serbia.\n\nRFERL.org quoted a recent poll as showing that two-third of respondents particularly the youth welcoming Chinese investment in their country.\n\nThe survey, published in October 2023 by the Institute for European Affairs, showed three out of four Serbians think China is a 'friendly nation.'\n\nVucic has said he is \"honoured\" that Xi is visiting.\n\nHe said before the visit that Serbia would seek further Chinese investment, particularly when it comes to advanced technologies.\n\nOn a trip to China, Vucic last year said Serbia is \"the only country in Europe that had never joined declarations criticising or attacking China on any issue.\"\n\nBoth leaders insist on an ironclad partnership between their countries.\n\nAs per RFERL.org, the China's People's Daily has called the visit \"a milestone in bilateral relations.\"\n\n\"Serbia has demonstrated once again that China, not Russia, is its most important partner in the East at the moment, especially with Russian-Serbian ties under constant scrutiny because of Ukraine,\" Vuk Vuksanovic, a senior researcher at the Belgrade Center for Security Policy, told RFE/RL.\n\nLast year, Vucic signed 18 agreements with Xi in Beijing, including a free trade deal that should become operational in July.\n\nAccording to BBC, Beijing claims it is Serbia's biggest source of foreign direct investment (FDI) in Serbia.\n\nChina's ambassador Li Ming says that Chinese firms provide 20,000 jobs in Serbia.\n\nIn 2023, China was Serbia's second-largest trading partner after the EU with a total trade exchange of $6.1 billion and among its top five investors, according to the national investment agency.\n\nThis time, China and Serbia are likely to pen around 30 agreements, sources in Belgrade told Bloomberg.\n\nBBC quoted Serbia's infrastructure minister, Goran Vesic as saying much more infrastructure projects are in the offing.\n\n\"There is really a lot of room for co-operation with Chinese companies,\" Vesic said.\n\n'Soaked in blood'\n\nXi's visit also comes on the 25th anniversary of the NATO bombing of China's embassy in which three Chinese journalists were killed.\n\nOn 7 May, 1999, 20 Chinese nationals were wounded in the NATO attack, which prompted outrage in China and an apology from then US president Bill Clinton.\n\nThe embassy was hit during a campaign against the then Yugoslavia to force late Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.\n\n\"The Chinese people appreciate the peace but will never allow that a historic tragedy repeats itself,\" Xi said in an opinion article in the Serbian daily Politika on Tuesday.\n\n\"The friendship between China and Serbia which is soaked in blood that the two peoples spilled together has become a joint memory of the two peoples and will encourage both parties to make together huge steps forward,\" Xi said.\n\nThe Guardian quoted Xi as vowing to \"expand the comprehensive strategic partnership\" with Serbia.\n\nHe also praised Vucic for \"preserving national sovereignty\" and \"opposing the interference of any force in Serbian internal affairs.\"\n\nObservers say Xi's choice of Serbia and Hungary is designed to pull closer two European countries that are pro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment.\n\nVedran Dzihic, a senior lecturer at the University of Vienna and senior researcher at the Austrian Institute for International Affairs, told RFERL.org, \"China sees in Hungary and Serbia the two most important partners in Europe, a kind of door that opens up space to a wider European market and to some strategic investments.\"\n\nSerbia's Western partners view the country as a Chinese hub at the gateway to the EU.\n\nThe countries are also growing closer when it comes to tourism.\n\nAccording to CGTN, Serbia has become an 'increasingly popular' destination since it granted visa-free entry to Chinese tourists in 2017.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, {"uri": "2024-05-349622717", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:44:20", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:44:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:42:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://macaudailytimes.com.mo/xi-and-serbian-president-vucic-hail-ironclad-friendship.html", "title": "Xi and Serbian president Vucic hail 'ironclad' friendship", "body": "Crowd attends a welcome ceremony for President Xi Jinping held by Serbian president Aleksandar Vucic in Belgrade, yesterday\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping met yesterday with the Serbian president, with both sides expressing optimism that the visit will further boost the \"ironclad\" friendly relations between China and the Balkan country.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening [yesterday, Macau time] from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi yesterday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks are being held.\n\nSerbia's populist President Aleksandar Vucic addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said hs visit to Serbia is \"historic\" because it opens the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many (people,)\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi will proceed to Hungary today. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were clearly visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a \"Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\"\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\n\"Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xi said in a statement published by China's Foreign Ministry.\n\n\"Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation,\" added Xi. \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations.\"\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-349268917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:22:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:22:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:21:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.chinanews.net/news/274354382/china-xi-welcomed-with-respect-and-love-in-serbia", "title": "China's Xi welcomed with 'respect and love' in Serbia", "body": "BELGRADE, Serbia (AFP) - Serbia on Wednesday rolled out the red carpet for Chinese President Xi Jinping on the second stage of a European tour aimed at deepening political and economic ties despite tensions over the war in Ukraine.\n\nXi arrived in the Serbian capital Tuesday evening following a state visit to France that saw sometimes robust exchanges with President Emmanuel Macron on trade and China's close ties to Russia despite the Ukraine war.\n\nBut the other two countries chosen for Xi's first trip to Europe since 2019 - with Hungary as the final stop after Serbia - are among the most sympathetic to Moscow in Europe.\n\nChina has poured billions into Serbia and neighboring Balkan countries, particularly into mining and manufacturing, and last year Beijing and Belgrade signed a free trade agreement.\n\nSerbia's President Aleksandar Vucic greeted Xi and his wife Peng Liyuan on a red carpet outside the main government offices in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nThe Chinese leader was met by a gun salute before shaking hands with officials, including the prime minister and the National Bank of Serbia governor.\n\nThe two leaders waved from a balcony to several thousand people, some waving Chinese flags, as Vucic called Xi a \"friend of Serbia.\"\n\n\"Such respect and love as he will find here in our Serbia, he will not find anywhere else,\" Vucic added.\n\nHe told the crowd as Xi applauded: \"We have a clear and simple position regarding Chinese territorial integrity. Yes, Taiwan is China.\"\n\nBeijing claims the self-ruled island as its own, and has not ruled out using force to bring it under Chinese control.\n\nXi told Vucic in opening comments that there was a \"strong feeling of friendship between our two countries.\"\n\n\"I hope that this visit will meet your expectations and show the contribution that China can make to Serbia,\" he said.\n\nThey later appeared together to sign a joint declaration, with commercial promises including the purchase of new Chinese trains, new air links and increased Serbian imports.\n\nIn Belgrade Xi received a warm welcome, with streets decked out with Chinese flags and posters proclaiming a \"warm welcome\" to \"Chinese friends.\"\n\nHis visit coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 U.S. bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, which killed three people.\n\n\"Do not forget that our Chinese friends were with us 25 years ago when this country was being demolished and bombed,\" Vucic told crowds Wednesday.\n\nThe embassy was hit during a months-long, U.S.-led NATO campaign targeting Serbian security forces who were at war with ethnic-Albanian insurgents in Kosovo.\n\nThe U.S. later apologized, saying outdated maps had led the pilot to strike the wrong target.\n\nOn Tuesday, Xi wrote in the Serbian daily Politika that NATO had \"flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy,\" warning that China would \"never allow such tragic history to repeat itself.\"\n\nSerbia has repeatedly supported China's claims over Taiwan and in turn, Beijing has long backed Serbia's territorial claims over the breakaway province of Kosovo.\n\nAlong with Russia, China has prevented Kosovo's recognition at the United Nations.\n\nXi called for the two countries to \"firmly support each other's core interests.\"\n\n\"China supports Serbia in upholding its policy of acting independently ... (and) its efforts to safeguard national sovereignty and territorial integrity on the Kosovo issue,\" he said Wednesday.\n\n\"For Serbia, this is without a doubt one of the most significant visits,\" Marko Tmusic, a political sciences professor at the University of Belgrade, told AFP.\n\n\"I think it's an excellent thing, this visit from the president of one of the most powerful countries in the world,\" 67-year-old Stojan Vidovic, a retiree, told AFP.\n\nIn France, Xi met with Macron and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen who urged him not to allow the export of technology that could be used by Russia in Ukraine and to do all it could to end the war.\n\nXi warned the West not to \"smear\" China over the conflict and hit back at accusations that Chinese overcapacity was causing global trade imbalances.\n\nSome European allies are concerned that while officially neutral over the Ukraine conflict, China is essentially backing Russia, which is using Chinese machine tools in arms production.\n\nAfter meeting with Vucic, Xi will go later Wednesday to Hungary where China has invested heavily in vast battery and electric vehicle manufacturing plants.\n\nBy MINA PEJAKOVIC and HELEN ROXBURGH, Agence France-Presse", "source": {"uri": "chinanews.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "China News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8117346127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:16:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:16:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:15:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.thestandard.com.hk/breaking-news/section/3/216189/China-and-EU-candidate-Serbia-sign-an-agreement-to-build-a-'shared-future'", "title": "China and EU-candidate Serbia sign an agreement to build a 'shared future'", "body": "China and European Union candidate Serbia signed an agreement on Wednesday to build a \"shared future,\" making the Balkan country the first in Europe to agree on such a document with Beijing.\n\nAfter meeting in Belgrade, Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic announced they would \"deepen and elevate the comprehensive strategic partnership between China and Serbia,\" and \"build a new era of a community with a shared future between China and Serbia.\"\n\nIt was not immediately clear what a \"shared future\" meant, but it is unlikely to be met with approval from the EU.\n\nAhead of the meeting, both sides expressed optimism that Xi's visit would further boost the \"ironclad\" friendly relations between China and the Balkan country.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks were held.\n\nSerbia's populist president addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said his visit to Serbia was \"historic\" because it opened the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many,\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi is traveling to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of those agreements, such as the free trade pact, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, Turkey and Bulgaria, was seen by experts as a demonstration of China's growing global reach.", "source": {"uri": "thestandard.com.hk", "dataType": Xi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks are being held.\n\nSerbia's populist President Aleksandar Vucic addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said his visit to Serbia is \"historic\" because it opens the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many (people,)\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"We are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly a two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi will proceed to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were clearly visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina's gateway to Europe\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by US jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbour Hungary.\n\n\"Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xi said in a statement published by China's Foreign Ministry.\n\n\"Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation,\" added Xi. \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations.\"\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernise the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, {"uri": "8119347071", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "14:55:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T14:55:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T14:54:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2692118/", "title": "Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Serbian president hail 'ironclad' friendship in Belgrade - ExBulletin", "body": "BELGRADE, Serbia (AP) Chinese President Xi Jinping met with the Serbian president on Wednesday, with both sides expressing optimism that the visit will further strengthen the all-weather friendly relations between China and the Balkan country, a candidate for EU membership. 'European Union.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia on Tuesday evening and was warmly welcomed by France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by commercial disputes and the Russias war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting China and Serbia and waving flags were bussed from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi in front of the Serbia Palace on Wednesday, in the new Belgrade district where the talks.\n\nSerbian populist President Aleksandar Vucic addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an ironclad friend. He said his visit to Serbia is historic because it paves the way for even closer ties.\n\nWe are making history today even if it doesn't seem like it to many (people), Vucic said. We thank President Xi. He hasn't been to Europe for five years and he has chosen our little Serbia again.\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said that we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people regard the Chinese people as their best and unfailing friend.\n\nThis is a truly bilateral and true friendship... I sincerely welcome this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me, Xi said, according to state television RTS.\n\nXi will visit Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is considered one of China's friendliest partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-Chinese sentiments were clearly visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a road leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags were visible in the city center and along a highway.\n\nChina has invested billions of dollars in Serbia in the form of investments and loans, particularly in the mining and infrastructure sectors. The two countries signed a strategic partnership agreement in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of these agreements, such as tariff-free trade with China, do not comply with the conditions of EU membership. Although Serbia officially wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it is gradually moving away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked country in the heart of the Balkans, is a key country in China's development. Belt and Road Initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date, the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade by American planes during the NATO air war over Kosovo, during which three Chinese citizens were You are.\n\nThis incident helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies operate Serbia's largest copper mine and steel mill, and are also building numerous roads and highways across the country, as well as a railway to Hungary, its northern neighbor.\n\nOur bilateral relationship has stood the test of the changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations, Xi said in a statement issued by the Chinese Foreign Ministry.\n\nAt a new historic starting point, China will work with Serbia to stick to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new perspective in China-Serbia cooperation,\" Xi added. I am confident that this visit will be fruitful and open a new chapter in Sino-Serbian relations.\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia reached an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals, Budapest and Belgrade, as part of a Belt and Road plan to connect the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus, Greece, to the southern port of entry Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system carried on Y-20 transport planes of the Chinese Air Force.\n\nThe delivery of weapons to the territory of at least two NATO member states, Turkey and While it may not denote a specific initiative, experts believe it has an underlying significance as another term for an alliance.\n\n\"Eight years ago, Serbia became China's first comprehensive strategic partner in the Central and Eastern European region, and today Serbia is the first European country to build a community of destiny with China, fully reflecting the strategic, special and high level of China-Serbia relations,\" Mr. Xi said during a press conference after signing the agreement.\n\nMr. Vucic said the two countries \"are moving from strategic relations, through which we had managed to raise our bilateral ties, to the joint future of our two countries.\"\n\n\"That is the highest possible form of cooperation between two countries and I am proud that I was able to sign this today as the President of Serbia,\" he added.\n\nIt was not immediately clear how the EU would respond to Serbia getting even closer to China. Russia's war on Ukraine has pushed the integration of six Western Balkan countries, including Serbia, into the EU at the top of the 27-nation bloc's agenda.\n\nChina has claimed neutrality in the Ukraine conflict, but has refused to call the Russian assault an invasion and has been accused of bolstering Russia's military capacity. Serbia has condemned the Russian invasion but has refused to join international sanctions against Moscow.\n\nMr. Xi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks were held.\n\nSerbia's populist President addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Mr. Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said his visit to Serbia was \"historic\" because it opened the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many,\" Mr. Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Mr. Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly a two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nMr. Xi is traveling to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of those agreements, such as the free trade pact, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernise the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over {"uri": "2024-05-349150663", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:36:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:36:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:21:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.thenationalherald.com/china-and-eu-candidate-serbia-sign-an-agreement-to-build-a-shared-future/", "title": "China and EU-Candidate Serbia Sign an Agreement to Build a 'Shared Future'", "body": "BELGRADE, Serbia (AP) -- China and European Union candidate Serbia signed an agreement on Wednesday to build a \"shared future,\" making the Balkan country the first in Europe to agree on such a document with Beijing.\n\nAfter meeting in Belgrade, Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Serbian President Vucic announced they would \"deepen and elevate the comprehensive strategic partnership between China and Serbia,\" and \"build a new era of a community with a shared future between China and Serbia.\"\n\nXi launched the term \"community for shared future\" over 10 years ago. While it may not denote a specific initiative, experts believe it has an underlying significance as another term for an alliance.\n\n\"Eight years ago, Serbia became China's first comprehensive strategic partner in the Central and Eastern European region, and today Serbia is the first European country to build a community of destiny with China, fully reflecting the strategic, special and high level of China-Serbia relations,\" Xi said during a press conference after signing the agreement.\n\nVucic said the two countries \"are moving from strategic relations, through which we had managed to raise our bilateral ties, to the joint future of our two countries.\"\n\n\"That is the highest possible form of cooperation between two countries and I am proud that I was able to sign this today as the President of Serbia,\" he added.\n\nIt was not immediately clear how the EU would respond to Serbia getting even closer to China. Russia's war on Ukraine has pushed the integration of six Western Balkan countries, including Serbia, into the EU at the top of the 27-nation bloc's agenda.\n\nChina has claimed neutrality in the Ukraine conflict, but has refused to call the Russian assault an invasion and has been accused of bolstering Russia's military capacity. Serbia has condemned the Russian invasion but has refused to join international sanctions against Moscow.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks were held.\n\nSerbia's populist president addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said his visit to Serbia was \"historic\" because it opened the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many,\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly a two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi is traveling to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of those agreements, such as the free trade pact, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, Turkey and Bulgaria, was seen by experts as a demonstration of China's growing global reach.\n\n___\n\nBy DUSAN STOJANOVIC and JOVANA GEC Associated Press\n\nWanquing Chen and Ken Moritsugu contributed from Beijing, China.", "source": {"uri": "thenationalherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The National Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-349060114", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:19:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:19:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:19:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/9/523292/World/International/China-and-EUcandidate-Serbia-sign-an-agreement-to-.aspx", "title": "China and EU-candidate Serbia sign an agreement to build a 'shared future'", "body": "After meeting in Belgrade, Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Serbian President Vucic announced they would \"deepen and elevate the comprehensive strategic partnership between China and Serbia,\" and \"build a new era of a community with a shared future between China and Serbia.\"\n\nXi launched the term \"community for shared future\" over 10 years ago. While it may not denote a specific initiative, experts believe it has an underlying significance as another term for an alliance.\n\n\"Eight years ago, Serbia became China's first comprehensive strategic partner in the Central and Eastern European region, and today Serbia is the first European country to build a community of destiny with China, fully reflecting the strategic, special and high level of China-Serbia relations,\" Xi said during a press conference after signing the agreement.\n\nIt was not immediately clear how the EU would respond to Serbia getting even closer to China. Russia's war on Ukraine has pushed the integration of six Western Balkan countries, including Serbia, into the EU at the top of the 27-nation bloc's agenda.\n\nChina has claimed neutrality in the Ukraine conflict, but has refused to call the Russian assault an invasion and has been accused of bolstering Russia's military capacity. Serbia has condemned the Russian invasion but has refused to join international sanctions against Moscow.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks were held.\n\nSerbia's populist president addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said his visit to Serbia was \"historic\" because it opened the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many,\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly a two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi is traveling to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of those agreements, such as the free trade pact, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's {"uri": "8117568365", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:34:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:34:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:34:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.ekathimerini.com/news/1238222/china-and-eu-candidate-serbia-sign-an-agreement-to-build-a-shared-future/", "title": "China and EU-candidate Serbia sign an agreement to build a 'shared future' | eKathimerini.com", "body": "China and European Union candidate Serbia signed an agreement on Wednesday to build a \"shared future,\" making the Balkan country the first in Europe to agree on such a document with Beijing.\n\nAfter meeting in Belgrade, Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Serbian President Vucic announced they would \"deepen and elevate the comprehensive strategic partnership between China and Serbia,\" and \"build a new era of a community with a shared future between China and Serbia.\"\n\nXi launched the term \"community for shared future\" over 10 years ago. While it may not denote a specific initiative, experts believe it has an underlying significance as another term for an alliance.\n\n\"Eight years ago, Serbia became China's first comprehensive strategic partner in the Central and Eastern European region, and today Serbia is the first European country to build a community of destiny with China, fully reflecting the strategic, special and high level of China-Serbia relations,\" Xi said during a press conference after signing the agreement.\n\nVucic said the two countries \"are moving from strategic relations, through which we had managed to raise our bilateral ties, to the joint future of our two countries.\"\n\n\"That is the highest possible form of cooperation between two countries and I am proud that I was able to sign this today as the President of Serbia,\" he added.\n\nIt was not immediately clear how the EU would respond to Serbia getting even closer to China. Russia's war on Ukraine has pushed the integration of six Western Balkan countries, including Serbia, into the EU at the top of the 27-nation bloc's agenda.\n\nChina has claimed neutrality in the Ukraine conflict, but has refused to call the Russian assault an invasion and has been accused of bolstering Russia's military capacity. Serbia has condemned the Russian invasion but has refused to join international sanctions against Moscow.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks were held.\n\nSerbia's populist president addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said his visit to Serbia was \"historic\" because it opened the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many,\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly a two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi is traveling to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of those agreements, such as the free trade pact, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date - the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by US jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, Turkey and Bulgaria, was seen by experts as a demonstration of China's growing global reach. [AP]\n\nChina Serbia Subscribe to our Newsletters\n\nEnter your information below to receive our weekly newsletters with the latest insights, opinion pieces and current events straight to your inbox.\n\nSIGN UP NOW Kathimerini may send occasional special offers and promotions. He said hs visit to Serbia is \"historic\" because it opens the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many (people,)\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi will proceed to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were clearly visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date - the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\n\"Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xi said in a statement published by China's Foreign Ministry.\n\n\"Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation,\" added Xi. \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations.\"\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, {"uri": "8117801429", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "17:14:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T17:14:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T17:14:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://thediplomat.com/2024/05/china-and-eu-candidate-serbia-sign-agreement-to-build-a-shared-future/", "title": "China and EU-candidate Serbia Sign Agreement to Build a 'Shared Future'", "body": "Serbia became the first European country to commit to building a \"community of common destiny\" with China.\n\nChina and European Union candidate Serbia signed an agreement on Wednesday to build a \"shared future,\" making the Balkan country the first in Europe to agree on such a document with Beijing.\n\nAfter meeting in Belgrade, Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic announced they would \"deepen and elevate the comprehensive strategic partnership between China and Serbia,\" and \"build a new era of a community with a shared future between China and Serbia.\"\n\nXi launched the term \"community for shared future\" over 10 years ago. While it may not denote a specific initiative, experts believe it has an underlying significance as another term for an alliance.\n\n\"Eight years ago, Serbia became China's first comprehensive strategic partner in the Central and Eastern European region, and today Serbia is the first European country to build a community of destiny with China, fully reflecting the strategic, special and high level of China-Serbia relations,\" Xi said during a press conference after signing the agreement.\n\nVucic said the two countries \"are moving from strategic relations, through which we had managed to raise our bilateral ties, to the joint future of our two countries.\"\n\n\"That is the highest possible form of cooperation between two countries and I am proud that I was able to sign this today as the president of Serbia,\" he added.\n\nIt was not immediately clear how the EU would respond to Serbia getting even closer to China. Russia's war on Ukraine has pushed the integration of six Western Balkan countries, including Serbia, into the EU at the top of the 27-nation bloc's agenda.\n\nThe U.S. envoy for the Western Balkans Gabriel Escobar said Xi's visit to Europe, his first in five years, was intended to drive a wedge among the European states.\n\n\"We caution all of our partners and all of our interlocutors to be very aware of China's agenda in Europe and China's agenda with regard to the European community,\" he said in an online press conference.\n\nChina claims neutrality in the Ukraine conflict but has refused to call the Russian assault an invasion and has been accused of bolstering Russia's military capacity. Serbia has condemned the Russian invasion but has refused to join international sanctions against Moscow.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks were held.\n\nSerbia's populist president addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said his visit to Serbia was \"historic\" because it opened the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today, although it doesn't seem so to many,\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said, \"We are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly a two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi is traveling to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of those agreements, such as the free trade pact, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road Initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date - the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, Turkey and Bulgaria, was seen by experts as a demonstration of China's growing global reach.", "source": {"uri": "thediplomat.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-05-348883749", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "10:56:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T10:56:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T08:19:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/05/08/chinese-leader-xi-jinping-and-serbian-president-hail-ironclad-friendship-in-belgrade/", "title": "Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Serbian president hail 'ironclad' friendship in Belgrade", "body": "BELGRADE, Serbia (AP) -- Chinese President Xi Jinping met Wednesday with the Serbian president, with both sides expressing optimism that the visit will further boost the \"ironclad\" friendly relations between China and the Balkan country, an European Union candidate.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks are being held.\n\nSerbia's populist President Aleksandar Vucic addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said hs visit to Serbia is \"historic\" because it opens the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many (people,)\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi will proceed to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were clearly visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of those agreements, like the trade without tariffs with China, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\n\"Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xi said in a statement published by China's Foreign Ministry.\n\n\"Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation,\" added Xi. \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations.\"\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, Turkey and Bulgaria, was seen by experts as a demonstration of China's growing global reach.\n\n-- -\n\nAssociated Press writer Ken Moritsugu contributed from Taipei, Taiwan.", "source": {"uri":
