{"uri": "8117437799", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:12:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:12:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:11:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.wkbn.com/news/national-world/ap-chinese-leader-xi-jinping-set-to-meet-serbian-officials-on-the-second-leg-of-his-europe-tour/", "title": "China and EU-candidate Serbia sign an agreement to build a 'shared future'", "body": "BELGRADE, Serbia (AP) -- China and European Union candidate Serbia signed an agreement on Wednesday to build a \"shared future,\" making the Balkan country the first in Europe to agree on such a document with Beijing.\n\nAfter meeting in Belgrade, Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Serbian President Vucic announced they would \"deepen and elevate the comprehensive strategic partnership between China and Serbia,\" and \"build a new era of a community with a shared future between China and Serbia.\"\n\nXi launched the term \"community for shared future\" over 10 years ago. While it may not denote a specific initiative, experts believe it has an underlying significance as another term for an alliance.\n\n\"Eight years ago, Serbia became China's first comprehensive strategic partner in the Central and Eastern European region, and today Serbia is the first European country to build a community of destiny with China, fully reflecting the strategic, special and high level of China-Serbia relations,\" Xi said during a press conference after signing the agreement.\n\nIt was not immediately clear how the EU would respond to Serbia getting even closer to China. Russia's war on Ukraine has pushed the integration of six Western Balkan countries, including Serbia, into the EU at the top of the 27-nation bloc's agenda.\n\nChina has claimed neutrality in the Ukraine conflict, but has refused to call the Russian assault an invasion and has been accused of bolstering Russia's military capacity. Serbia has condemned the Russian invasion but has refused to join international sanctions against Moscow.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks were held.\n\nSerbia's populist president addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said his visit to Serbia was \"historic\" because it opened the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many,\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly a two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi is traveling to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of those agreements, such as the free trade pact, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, Turkey and Bulgaria, was seen by experts as a demonstration of China's growing global reach.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Ken Moritsugu contributed to this report from Taipei, Taiwan.", "source": {"uri": "wkbn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WKBN"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balkans", While it may not denote a specific initiative, experts believe it has an underlying significance as another term for an alliance.\n\n\"Eight years ago, Serbia became China's first comprehensive strategic partner in the Central and Eastern European region, and today Serbia is the first European country to build a community of destiny with China, fully reflecting the strategic, special and high level of China-Serbia relations,\" Xi said during a press conference after signing the agreement.\n\nVucic said the two countries \"are moving from strategic relations, through which we had managed to raise our bilateral ties, to the joint future of our two countries.\"\n\n\"That is the highest possible form of cooperation between two countries and I am proud that I was able to sign this today as the President of Serbia,\" he added.\n\nIt was not immediately clear how the EU would respond to Serbia getting even closer to China. Russia's war on Ukraine has pushed the integration of six Western Balkan countries, including Serbia, into the EU at the top of the 27-nation bloc's agenda.\n\nThe U.S. envoy for the Western Balkans Gabriel Escobar said Xi's visit to Europe, his first in five years, was intended to drive a wedge among the European states.\n\n\"We caution all of our partners and all of our interlocutors to be very aware of China's agenda in Europe and China's agenda with regard to the European community,\" he said in an online press conference.\n\nChina has claimed neutrality in the Ukraine conflict, but has refused to call the Russian assault an invasion and has been accused of bolstering Russia's military capacity. Serbia has condemned the Russian invasion but has refused to join international sanctions against Moscow.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks were held.\n\nSerbia's populist president addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said his visit to Serbia was \"historic\" because it opened the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many,\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly a two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi is traveling to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of those agreements, such as the free trade pact, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over {"uri": "8117351301", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:19:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:19:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:18:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.lemonde.fr/en/china/article/2024/05/08/china-s-xi-serbian-president-hail-ironclad-friendship-in-belgrade_6670797_162.html", "title": "China's Xi, Serbian president hail 'ironclad' friendship in Belgrade", "body": "Chinese President Xi Jinping met on Wednesday, May 8, with the Serbian president, with both sides expressing optimism that the visit will further boost the \"ironclad\" friendly relations between China and the Balkan country, a European Union candidate.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine. Thousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks are being held.\n\nSerbia's populist President Aleksandar Vucic addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said his visit to Serbia is \"historic\" because it opens the path for even closer ties. \"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many (people,)\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\" \"This is truly two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi will proceed to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe. Signs of pro-China sentiments were clearly visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year. Some of those agreements, like the trade without tariffs with China, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date - the 25anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by US jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed. The incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary. \"Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xi said in a statement published by China's Foreign Ministry.\n\n\"Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation,\" added Xi. \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in {"uri": "8118323104", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:08:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:08:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:07:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://english.aawsat.com/node/5007886", "title": "China, Serbia Chart 'Shared Future' as Xi Jinping Visits Europe", "body": "Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic and his wife Tamara Vucic welcome China's President Xi Jinping and his wife Peng Liyuan for an official two-day state visit, at Nikola Tesla Airport in Belgrade, Serbia, May 7, 2024. REUTERS/Marko Djurica Purchase Licensing Rights\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Serbia on Tuesday evening escorted by MIG-29 jets in a tightly secured visit coinciding with the 25th anniversary of the NATO bombing of China's embassy in which three Chinese journalists were killed.\n\nBelgrade, after France, is the second stop on Xi's first visit to Europe in five years, which also includes Hungary. In Serbia, which is seen as China's most important partner in the Balkans, Xi is expected to discuss China\u00b4s multi-billion investment in the country and possible new deals.\n\nSerbian President Aleksandar Vucic and government officials welcomed Xi at the Belgrade airport, where he was greeted by a military guard of honor and folk dancers. The two leaders will hold a meeting on Wednesday.\n\nOn May 7, 1999, 20 Chinese nationals were wounded in the NATO attack, which prompted outrage in China and an apology from then US President Bill Clinton.\n\nThe embassy was hit during a campaign against the then Yugoslavia to force late Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, Reuters reported.\n\n\"The Chinese people appreciate the peace but will never allow that a historic tragedy repeats itself,\" Xi said in an opinion article in the daily Politika on Tuesday.\n\n\"The friendship between China and Serbia which is soaked in blood that the two peoples spilled together has become a joint memory of the two peoples and will encourage both parties to make together huge steps forward,\" Xi said.\n\nThe Belgrade streets were decorated with Chinese flags and placards as thousands of police officers were deployed to secure Xi and his 400-member entourage, the highest-level visit by a foreign leader in years.\n\nXi is visiting Serbia after France, where President Emmanuel Macron and EU Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen pressed him to ensure more balanced trade with Europe and use his influence on Russia to end the war in Ukraine.\n\nDuring his first visit to Belgrade in 2016, the two countries signed a strategic partnership. Last year, Vucic signed 18 agreements with Xi in Beijing, including a free trade deal that should become operational in July.\n\nBoth leaders insist on an ironclad partnership between their countries. Along with Hungary, which is Xi\u00b4s next stop, Serbia is Europe's firmest supporter of China's Belt and Road Initiative.\n\nChina runs mines and factories across Serbia and has lent billions for roads, bridges and new facilities, becoming Serbia's key partner in much-needed infrastructure development.\n\nObservers say Xi's choice of Serbia and Hungary is designed to pull closer two European countries that are pro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment. Serbia's Western partners view the country as a Chinese hub at the gateway to the EU.\n\nIn 2023, China was Serbia's second-largest trading partner after the EU with a total trade exchange of $6.1 {"uri": "8116988183", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "08:42:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T08:42:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T08:41:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13394947/Chinese-leader-Xi-Jinping-set-meet-Serbian-officials-second-leg-Europe-tour.html", "title": "Chinese leader Xi Jinping set to meet Serbian officials on the...", "body": "BELGRADE, Serbia (AP) - Chinese leader Xi Jinping is set to meet Wednesday with Serbian officials and said he hopes his visit will further boost already friendly relations with the Balkan country, which is seeking entry to the European Union.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia\u00b4s war in Ukraine.\n\nXi will proceed to Hungary later on Wednesday, which, like Serbia, is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSerbian President Aleksandar Vucic and other top officials welcomed Xi at the airport on Tuesday after his plane was escorted by military jets. Vucic said Xi's visit was a \"great honor\" and that China is an \"inspiration\" for Serbia.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were clearly visible - a huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nA man walks in front of a Chinese national flag in Belgrade, Serbia, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. Chinese leader Xi Jinping's visit to European ally Serbia on Tuesday falls on a symbolic date: the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during NATO's air war over Kosovo. (AP Photo/Darko Vojinovic)\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date: the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO\u00b4s air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\n\"Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xi said in an arrival statement published by China's Foreign Ministry. He described the Serbia-China friendship as \"ironclad.\"\n\n\"Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation with stronger momentum, greater scope, and higher quality,\" added Xi. \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations.\"\n\nChinese companies are running Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, Turkey and Bulgaria, was seen by experts as a demonstration of China\u00b4s growing global reach.\n\nPeople walk in front of a Chinese national flag in Belgrade, Serbia, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. Chinese leader Xi Jinping's visit to European ally Serbia on Tuesday falls on a symbolic date: the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during NATO's air war over Kosovo. (AP Photo/Darko Vojinovic)\n\nCleaners walk in front of a Chinese national flag placed on the building in Belgrade, Serbia, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. Chinese leader Xi Jinping's visit to European ally Serbia on Tuesday falls on a symbolic date: the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during NATO's air war over Kosovo. (AP Photo/Darko Vojinovic)\n\nIn this photo provided by the Serbian Presidential Press Service, Chinese President Xi Jinping, left, and his wife Peng Liyuan wave during a welcome ceremony upon arrival at the Nikola Tesla airport in Belgrade, Serbia, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. (Serbian Presidential Press Service via AP)\n\nIn this image provided by the Serbian Presidential Press Service, Chinese President Xi Jinping, center, reviews the honor guard with his Serbian counterpart Aleksandar Vucic during a welcome ceremony upon his arrival at the Nikola Tesla airport in Belgrade, Serbia, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. (Serbian Presidential Press Service via AP)\n\nIn this photo provided by the Serbian Presidential Press Service, Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic, right, welcomes Chinese President Xi Jinping, center, and his wife Peng Liyuan during a welcome ceremony upon his arrival at the Nikola Tesla airport in Belgrade, Serbia, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. (Serbian Presidential Press Service via AP)\n\nIn this photo provided by the Serbian Presidential Press Service, Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic, center right, welcomes Chinese President Xi Jinping, center left, and his wife Peng Liyuan during a welcome ceremony upon his arrival at the Nikola Tesla airport in Belgrade, Serbia, Tuesday, May 7, 2024. Serbian people dressed in national costumes sang and danced to welcome them.\n\n\"China and Serbia enjoy profound traditional friendship. cooperation, explore development, and draw up a new blueprint for the development of bilateral relations.\n\n\"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations,\" he said.\n\nXi's visit to Serbia marks his second visit to the country in eight years, which is a milestone to upgrade and improve bilateral relations.\n\n\"It gives me great pleasure to pay a state visit to the Republic of Serbia at the warm invitation of President Vucic,\" Xi said.\n\n\"On behalf of the Chinese government and people, I would like to extend heartfelt greetings and best wishes to the friendly government and people of Serbia,\" he added.\n\nHe said that since the establishment of the comprehensive strategic partnership in 2016, the bilateral relationship has realized leapfrog development, and achieved historic results.\n\nThe two countries are bound by rock-solid political mutual trust, and have seen fruitful results in high quality Belt and Road cooperation, the Chinese president said, adding that \"our ironclad friendship has taken deeper roots in the heart of the two peoples.\"\n\nChina and Serbia have rendered each other firm support on issues concerning their respective core interests and major concerns, Xi said.\n\n\"We have jointly upheld international fairness and justice, and contributed our share to promoting world peace and development,\" he added.\n\nCooperation between the two countries is rooted in the principle of equality and mutual benefits, said Xi.\n\n\"Standing at a new historical starting point, China {"uri": "8118014247", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "20:18:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T20:18:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T20:18:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/after-serbia-chinas-xi-arrives-in-hungary-to-tighten-bonds/article_17fd6a6d-3079-592b-adc0-22c3793dec40.html", "title": "After Serbia, China's Xi arrives in Hungary to tighten bonds", "body": "Serbia has repeatedly supported China's claims over Taiwan, and Beijing has backed Serbia's claims over Kosovo\n\nFollowing a visit to Serbia, Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Budapest on Wednesday in the last leg of his European tour aimed at strengthening already flourishing ties between Beijing and its closest EU ally.\n\nXi's three-day visit to Hungary marks 75 years of diplomatic relations between the two countries, with the Chinese leader expected to attend a state dinner with Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban later on Wednesday.\n\nHe began his European trip in France, a visit that was cordial but also highlighted tensions between Beijing and the EU over the war in Ukraine and global trade.\n\nEarlier on Wednesday, Xi wrapped up his visit in Serbia, which like Hungary has close ties to both Russia and China.\n\nChina has poured billions into Serbia and neighbouring Balkan countries, particularly into mining and manufacturing, and last year Beijing and Belgrade signed a free-trade agreement.\n\nSerbia's President Aleksandar Vucic greeted Xi and his wife Peng Liyuan on a red carpet outside the main government offices in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nThe Chinese leader was met by a gun salute before shaking hands with officials, including the prime minister and the National Bank of Serbia governor.\n\nThe two leaders waved from a balcony to several thousand people, some waving Chinese flags, as Vucic called Xi a \"friend of Serbia\".\n\n\"Such respect and love as he will find here in our Serbia, he will not find anywhere else,\" Vucic added.\n\nHe also told the crowd as Xi applauded: \"We have a clear and simple position regarding Chinese territorial integrity. Yes, Taiwan is China.\"\n\nBeijing claims the self-ruled island as its own, and has not ruled out using force to bring it under Chinese control.\n\nXi told Vucic in opening comments that there was a \"strong feeling of friendship between our two countries\".\n\nThey later appeared together to sign a joint declaration, with commercial promises including the purchase of new Chinese trains, new air links, and increased Serbian imports.\n\n- NATO bombing -\n\nStreets in the Serbian capital were decked out with Chinese flags and posters proclaiming a \"warm welcome\" to \"Chinese friends\".\n\nXi's visit coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 US bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, which killed three people.\n\n\"Do not forget that our Chinese friends were with us 25 years ago when this country was being demolished and bombed,\" Vucic told the crowds Wednesday.\n\nThe embassy was hit during a months-long, US-led NATO campaign targeting Serbian security forces who were at war with ethnic-Albanian insurgents in Kosovo.\n\nThe United States later apologised, saying outdated maps had led the pilot to strike the wrong target.\n\nOn Tuesday, Xi wrote in the Serbian daily Politika that NATO had \"flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy\", warning that China would \"never allow such tragic history to repeat itself\".\n\nSerbia has repeatedly supported China's claims over Taiwan and in turn, Beijing has long backed Serbia's territorial claims over the breakaway province of Kosovo.\n\nAlong with Russia, China has prevented Kosovo's recognition at the United Nations.\n\nXi called for the two countries to \"firmly support each other's core interests\".\n\n\"China supports Serbia in upholding its policy of acting independently... (and) its efforts to safeguard national sovereignty and territorial integrity on the Kosovo issue,\" he said Wednesday.\n\n- Ukraine fears -\n\n\"For Serbia, this is without a doubt one of the most significant visits,\" Marko Tmusic, a political sciences professor at the University of Belgrade, told AFP.\n\nIn Belgrade, many welcomed Xi's visit.\n\n\"I think it's an excellent thing, this visit from the president of one of the most powerful countries in the world,\" 67-year-old Stojan Vidovic, a retiree, told AFP.\n\nIn France, Xi met President Emmanuel Macron and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen who urged him not to allow the export of technology that could be used by Russia in Ukraine and to do all it could to end the war.\n\nXi warned the West not to \"smear\" China over the conflict and hit back at accusations that Chinese overcapacity was causing global trade imbalances.\n\nSome European allies are concerned that while officially neutral over the Ukraine conflict, China is essentially backing Russia, which is using Chinese machine tools in arms production.\n\nIn Hungary, China has invested heavily in vast battery and electric vehicle manufacturing plants.\n\nXi will hold talks with Orban, who has bucked the European Union's official position to \"de-risk\" relations with China.\n\nbur-rox-ehl/kym/imm", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8117509378", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:02:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:02:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:58:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/chinas-xi-welcomed-with-respect-and-love-i-1822852.html", "title": "Chinas Xi Welcomed With respect And Love In Serbia - UrduPoint", "body": "Serbia on Wednesday rolled out the red carpet for Chinese President Xi Jinping on the second stage of a European tour aimed at deepening political and economic ties\n\nBelgrade, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 8th May, 2024) Serbia on Wednesday rolled out the red carpet for Chinese President Xi Jinping on the second stage of a European tour aimed at deepening political and economic ties.\n\nXi arrived in the Serbian capital Tuesday evening following a state visit to France that saw sometimes robust exchanges with President Emmanuel Macron on trade and China's close ties to Russia despite the Ukraine war.\n\nBut the other two countries chosen for Xi's first trip to Europe since 2019 -- with Hungary as the final stop after Serbia -- are among the most sympathetic to Moscow in Europe.\n\nChina has poured billions into Serbia and neighbouring Balkan countries, particularly into mining and manufacturing, and last year Beijing and Belgrade signed a free trade agreement.\n\nSerbia's President Aleksandar Vucic greeted Xi and his wife Peng Liyuan on a red carpet outside the main government offices in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nThe Chinese leader was met by a gun salute before shaking hands with officials, including the prime minister and the National Bank of Serbia governor.\n\nThe two leaders waved from a balcony to several thousand people, some waving Chinese flags, as Vucic called Xi a \"friend of Serbia\".\n\n\"Such respect and love as he will find here in our Serbia, he will not find anywhere else,\" Vucic added.\n\nHe told the crowd as Xi applauded: \"We have a clear and simple position regarding Chinese territorial integrity. Yes, Taiwan is China\".\n\nBeijing claims the self-ruled island as its own, and has not ruled out using force to bring it under Chinese control.\n\nXi told Vucic in opening comments that there was a \"strong feeling of friendship between our two countries\".\n\n\"I hope that this visit will meet your expectations and show the contribution that China can make to Serbia,\" he said.\n\nThey later appeared together to sign a joint declaration, with commercial promises including the purchase of new Chinese trains, new air links, and increased Serbian imports.\n\nIn Belgrade Xi received a warm welcome, with streets decked out with Chinese flags and posters proclaiming a \"warm welcome\" to \"Chinese friends\".\n\n\"For Serbia, this is without a doubt one of the most significant visits,\" Marko Tmusic, a political sciences professor at the University of Belgrade, told AFP.\n\nIn Belgrade, many welcomed Xi's visit.\n\n\"I think it's an excellent thing, this visit from the president of one of the most powerful countries in the world,\" 67-year-old Stojan Vidovic, a retiree, told AFP.", "source": {"uri": "urdupoint.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UrduPoint"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8118032057", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "20:36:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T20:36:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T20:35:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.fox41yakima.com/after-serbia-chinas-xi-arrives-in-hungary-to-tighten-bonds/", "title": "After Serbia, China's Xi arrives in Hungary to tighten bonds | Fox 11 Tri Cities Fox 41 Yakima", "body": "Following a visit to Serbia, Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Budapest on Wednesday in the last leg of his European tour aimed at strengthening already flourishing ties between Beijing and its closest EU ally.\n\nXi's three-day visit to Hungary marks 75 years of diplomatic relations between the two countries, with the Chinese leader expected to attend a state dinner with Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban later on Wednesday.\n\nHe began his European trip in France, a visit that was cordial but also highlighted tensions between Beijing and the EU over the war in Ukraine and global trade.\n\nEarlier on Wednesday, Xi wrapped up his visit in Serbia, which like Hungary has close ties to both Russia and China.\n\nChina has poured billions into Serbia and neighbouring Balkan countries, particularly into mining and manufacturing, and last year Beijing and Belgrade signed a free-trade agreement.\n\nSerbia's President Aleksandar Vucic greeted Xi and his wife Peng Liyuan on a red carpet outside the main government offices in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nThe Chinese leader was met by a gun salute before shaking hands with officials, including the prime minister and the National Bank of Serbia governor.\n\nThe two leaders waved from a balcony to several thousand people, some waving Chinese flags, as Vucic called Xi a \"friend of Serbia\".\n\n\"Such respect and love as he will find here in our Serbia, he will not find anywhere else,\" Vucic added.\n\nHe also told the crowd as Xi applauded: \"We have a clear and simple position regarding Chinese territorial integrity. Yes, Taiwan is China.\"\n\nBeijing claims the self-ruled island as its own, and has not ruled out using force to bring it under Chinese control.\n\nXi told Vucic in opening comments that there was a \"strong feeling of friendship between our two countries\".\n\nThey later appeared together to sign a joint declaration, with commercial promises including the purchase of new Chinese trains, new air links, and increased Serbian imports.\n\n- NATO bombing -\n\nStreets in the Serbian capital were decked out with Chinese flags and posters proclaiming a \"warm welcome\" to \"Chinese friends\".\n\nXi's visit coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 US bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, which killed three people.\n\n\"Do not forget that our Chinese friends were with us 25 years ago when this country was being demolished and bombed,\" Vucic told the crowds Wednesday.\n\nThe embassy was hit during a months-long, US-led NATO campaign targeting Serbian security forces who were at war with ethnic-Albanian insurgents in Kosovo.\n\nThe United States later apologised, saying outdated maps had led the pilot to strike the wrong target.\n\nOn Tuesday, Xi wrote in the Serbian daily Politika that NATO had \"flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy\", warning that China would \"never allow such tragic history to repeat itself\".\n\nSerbia has repeatedly supported China's claims over Taiwan and in turn, Beijing has long backed Serbia's territorial claims over the breakaway province of Kosovo.\n\nAlong with Russia, China has prevented Kosovo's recognition at the United Nations.\n\nXi called for the two countries to \"firmly support each other's core interests\".\n\n\"China supports Serbia in upholding its policy of acting independently... (and) its efforts to safeguard national sovereignty and territorial integrity on the Kosovo issue,\" he said Wednesday.\n\n- Ukraine fears -\n\n\"For Serbia, this is without a doubt one of the most significant visits,\" Marko Tmusic, a political sciences professor at the University of Belgrade, told AFP.\n\nIn Belgrade, many welcomed Xi's visit.\n\n\"I think it's an excellent thing, this visit from the president of one of the most powerful countries in the world,\" 67-year-old Stojan Vidovic, a retiree, told AFP.\n\nIn France, Xi met President Emmanuel Macron and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen who urged him not to allow the export of technology that could be used by Russia in Ukraine and to do all it could to end the war.\n\nXi warned the West not to \"smear\" China over the conflict and hit back at accusations that Chinese overcapacity was causing global trade imbalances.\n\nSome European allies are concerned that while officially neutral over the Ukraine conflict, China is essentially backing Russia, which is using Chinese machine tools in arms production.\n\nIn Hungary, China has invested heavily in vast battery and electric vehicle manufacturing plants.\n\nXi will hold talks with Orban, who has bucked the European Union's official position to \"de-risk\" relations with China.\n\nbur-rox-ehl/kym/imm\n\nFOX41 Yakima\u00a9FOX11 TriCities\u00a9", {"uri": "2024-05-349170406", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:52:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:52:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:50:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/xi-jinping-and-serbian-president-friendship-belgrade-9316188/", "title": "Chinese leader Xi Jinping and Serbian president hail 'ironclad' friendship in Belgrade", "body": "Xi arrived in Serbia to a warm welcome on Tuesday evening from France, where he had a high-stakes state visit dominated by trade disputes and Russia's war in Ukraine.\n\nThousands of people chanting \"China-Serbia\" and waving flags were bused in from across Serbia to attend a welcoming ceremony for Xi on Wednesday in front of the Serbia Palace, in the new part of Belgrade where the talks are being held.\n\nSerbia's populist President Aleksandar Vucic addressed the crowd from a balcony, calling Xi an \"ironclad\" friend. He said his visit to Serbia is \"historic\" because it opens the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today although it doesn't seem so to many (people,)\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\" At the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends\".\n\n\"This is truly two-sided and truthful friendship... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi will proceed to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were clearly visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSome of those agreements, like the trade without tariffs with China, are not in line with EU conditions for membership. Although Serbia formally wants to join the 27-nation bloc, it has been steadily drifting away from that path.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by US jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbour Hungary.\n\n\"Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xi said in a statement published by China's Foreign Ministry.\n\n\"Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation,\" added Xi. \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations.\"\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernise the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than USD 2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, Turkiye and Bulgaria, was seen by experts as a demonstration of China's growing global reach.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Indian Express"}, "authors": {"uri": "8118388441", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "03:21:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T03:21:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T03:21:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.dawn.com/news/1832334", "title": "China, Serbia agree to chart 'shared future'", "body": "BELGRADE: China and Serbia on Wednesday agreed to follow a \"shared future\" as President Xi Jinping visited the Balkan country as part of his bid to forge stronger relations with allies at the edge of the European Union.\n\nXi is on his first European tour in five years, and the trip was seen as an effort to strengthen ties with eastern European countries that are pro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment. He will fly to Hungary later in the day.\n\n\"We are writing history today,\" Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic told a large crowd that had gathered in front of the Serbian presidential palace to welcome Xi, applauding and chanting \"China, China\".\n\nThe two countries signed 29 agreements promoting legal, regulatory and economic cooperation. Serbia will also become the first European country in years to enter into a free trade agreement with China when a deal signed last year comes into effect on July 1.\n\nIn a bid to boost ties with eastern Europe, Xi to reach Hungary after touring Serbia\n\nVucic said that since 2020 China had been the single-largest investor in Serbia, and that its investment was up 30-fold over the past decade. The free trade deal will guarantee tariff-free exports for 95 per cent of Serbian products to China over the next five to 10 years, he said.\n\nXi said that China was ready to import more high-quality agricultural products from Serbia and would welcome more direct flights between Belgrade and Chinese cities.\n\nBoth leaders boast of an ironclad partnership. Along with Hungary, Serbia is Europe's firmest supporter of China's huge Belt and Road infrastructure project across parts of Asia and Europe.\n\n\"Serbia became China's first strategic partner in central and eastern Europe eight years ago, and it becomes the first European country with which we shall build a community with shared future,\" Xi said.\n\nThe two leaders said they would support each other's sovereignty and territorial integrity, meaning that Serbia considers Taiwan, viewed by Beijing as a breakaway province, to be part of China, just as China considers Kosovo, which declared independence in 2008, as part of Serbia.\n\n\"We shall jointly confront hegemony and the politics of power,\" Xi said.\n\nXi's visit comes on the anniversary of the 1999 Nato bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during a campaign against the former Yugoslavia to force late Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.\n\nNato said the bombing, which killed three Chinese journalists and wounded 20 Chinese nationals, was accidental. It prompted outrage in China and an apology from then US President Bill Clinton.\n\n\"The Chinese people appreciate the peace but will never allow that a historic tragedy repeats itself,\" Xi said in an opinion article in the daily Politika on Tuesday.\n\nVucic said the two countries had agreed to establish an inter-governmental technology committee that would enable Serbia to get access to the latest technologies and use of artificial intelligence.\n\nChina owns mines and factories across Serbia and has lent billions for roads, bridges and new facilities, becoming Serbia's key partner in much-needed infrastructure development.\n\nXi left France on Tuesday after a two-day trip during which he offered no major concessions on trade or foreign policy, even as President Emmanuel Macron {"uri": "8117177744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "10:36:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T10:36:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T10:35:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.newsgd.com/node_4a45bf5687/ea2b73eab1.shtml", "title": "Xi arrives in Belgrade for state visit to Serbia", "body": "Chinese President Xi Jinping arrives in Belgrade for a state visit to Serbia at the invitation of Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic, May 7, 2024. (Xinhua/Liu Bin)\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Belgrade on Tuesday to pay a state visit to Serbia.\n\nSerbian Air Force sent two fighter jets to escort Xi's plane after it entered the country's airspace.\n\nThe Chinese president was warmly welcomed by Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic and his wife, Tamara Vucic, at Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport.\n\nSerbian children presented flowers to Xi and his wife, Peng Liyuan, and waved the national flags of China and Serbia. Serbian people dressed in national costumes sang and danced to welcome them.\n\n\"China and Serbia enjoy profound traditional friendship. Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xi said in a written statement upon arrival.\n\nXi said he looks forward to taking this visit as an opportunity to have in-depth exchange of views with Vucic on bilateral relationship and other issues of mutual interest, renew friendship, plan for cooperation, explore development, and draw up a new blueprint for the development of bilateral relations.\n\n\"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations,\" he said.\n\nXi's visit to Serbia marks his second visit to the country in eight years, which is a milestone to upgrade and improve bilateral relations.\n\n\"It gives me great pleasure to pay a state visit to the Republic of Serbia at the warm invitation of President Vucic,\" Xi said.\n\n\"On behalf of the Chinese government and people, I would like to extend heartfelt greetings and best wishes to the friendly government and people of Serbia,\" he added.\n\nHe said that since the establishment of the comprehensive strategic partnership in 2016, the bilateral relationship has realized leapfrog development, and achieved historic results.\n\nThe two countries are bound by rock-solid political mutual trust, and have seen fruitful results in high quality Belt and Road cooperation, the Chinese president said, adding that \"our ironclad friendship has taken deeper roots in the heart of the two peoples.\"\n\nChina and Serbia have rendered each other firm support on issues concerning their respective core interests and major concerns, Xi said.\n\n\"We have jointly upheld international fairness and justice, and contributed our share to promoting world peace and development,\" he added.\n\nCooperation between the two countries is rooted in the principle of equality and mutual benefits, said Xi.\n\n\"Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation with stronger momentum, greater scope, and higher quality,\" he said.\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping arrives in Belgrade for a state visit to Serbia at the invitation of Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic, May 7, 2024. Xi was warmly welcomed by President Vucic and his wife, Tamara Vucic, at Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport upon arrival. {"uri": "8118339539", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "02:30:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T02:30:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T02:28:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "http://en.people.cn/n3/2024/0509/c90000-20167008.html", "title": "Xi, Vucic hold talks, hail evergrowing ironclad friendship", "body": "Tens of thousands of Serbian people chant \"China! Serbia!\" while waving Chinese and Serbian national flags as they welcome the visiting Chinese President Xi Jinping in Belgrade on May 8, 2024. Photo: Xinhua\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping and Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic on Wednesday signed a joint statement on building a community with shared future in the new era in Belgrade, making Serbia the first European country to build such a community with China.\n\nIn the joint statement, the two countries decided to deepen and elevate the China-Serbia comprehensive strategic partnership. Serbia was the first Central and Eastern European country to become China's comprehensive strategic partner eight years ago.\n\n\"It is a strategic choice made by both sides to build a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era. Its goal is to realize the aspiration of the two peoples for a better life. Its foundation and driving force come from the firm support and extensive participation of the two peoples,\" Xi told reporters during a joint press conference with Vucic.\n\nXi also announced six measures to support the building of a China-Serbia community with a shared future.\n\nChina is ready to import more quality and distinctive agricultural products from Serbia. China welcomes Serbia to increase direct flights between Belgrade and Shanghai, and encourages airlines from both sides to launch direct flights between Belgrade and Guangzhou.\n\nThe Chinese side will aid 50 young Serbian scientists in exchange programs with China for the next three years and a total of 300 Serbian youths will be invited to study in China in the next three years, said Xi.\n\nChina supports Serbia in hosting Expo 2027, and will send a delegation to participate in the grand show. China encourages its enterprises to take part in the construction of relevant projects, Xi said.\n\nWith joint efforts from China and Serbia, the free trade agreement between the two countries will take effect on July 1, Xi said.\n\nDuring his talks with Vucic on Wednesday in Belgrade, Xi said bilateral relations between China and Serbia are richer in content and have become a model of friendly relations between China and European countries.\n\nXi called on China and Serbia to carry forward the innovative nature of bilateral relations, open up new prospects for cooperation, and make innovative cooperation a new growth point of bilateral ties.\n\nXi was greeted by tens of thousands of Serbians on Wednesday and a welcoming ceremony was held outside the Palace of Serbia before the meeting between the two leaders.\n\nChinese national flags and Chinese-language welcoming banners were hanging on landmark buildings in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nChinese and Serbian experts said the meeting between the two heads of state will continue to provide high-level guidance to the sound development of bilateral relationship for the years to come and further inject vitality into the time-weathered, ironclad friendship.\n\nIronclad friendship\n\nOn Tuesday, a signed article by President Xi titled \"May the Light of Our Ironclad Friendship Shine on the Path of China-Serbia Cooperation\" was published in Serbian media Politika.\n\nXi noted in the article that \"there has always been an affinity between Chinese and Serbian peoples despite the long distance between us. During the bitter Anti-Fascist War and our respective nation-building in the last century, the Chinese and Serbian peoples forged a strong friendship that extends through time and space.\"\n\n\"Amid the ongoing transformations unseen in a century in the world, our mutual support remains as strong as ever, our cooperation is closer, and our exchanges and mutual learning more substantive. Whatever changes in the international landscape, China and Serbia remain true friends and good partners. Our ironclad friendship is ever-growing, setting a model for state-to-state and people-to-people interactions,\" Xi wrote.\n\nXi said China and Serbia should always be good friends and treat each other with sincerity, good partners for win-win cooperation, play an exemplary role in promoting fairness and justice and strengthen the heart-to-heart connection between their two peoples.\n\nWith China's support, hundreds of kilometers of highways have been built, the fastest railway in Eastern Europe entered operation, and energy facilities keep renewing, Boyan Lalic, Director of the Belt and Road Institute Belgrade, told the Global Times Wednesday.\n\nThe China-built high-speed railway connecting Belgrade to Novi Sad, inexpensive and comfortable, has cut the previously 1.5-hour trip to just 36 minutes, making a two-city life possible for many young people seeking opportunities, the Global Times learned.\n\nThe railway is part of a more ambitious project linking Belgrade and Budapest, the capital of Hungary, which could finish construction as early as 2025. The project has created jobs, offered unique career experience and trainings, and has allowed people like Serbian engineer Aleksandra Milosavljevic to \"make really good friends with my Chinese colleagues.\"\n\nJoin hands on international stage\n\nIn the signed article, Xi wrote \"Twenty-five years ago today, NATO flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy in Yugoslavia ... This we should never forget. The Chinese people cherish peace, but we will never allow such tragic history to repeat itself.\"\n\nThe China-Serbia friendship, forged with the blood of our compatriots, will stay in the shared memory of the Chinese and Serbian peoples, and will inspire us to march forward with big strides, Xi wrote.\n\nDong Yifan, a research fellow at the Institute of European Studies, China Institutes of Contemporary International Relations, said that both China and Serbia adhere to independence and non-alignment in their strategic approaches, choosing to follow their own development paths and opposing hegemony. \"We share a strong consensus in international affairs.\"\n\nThe last stop of Xi's three-nation European trip is Hungary, during which a series of cooperation agreements are expected to be signed, according to media reports.\n\nBoth Serbia and Hungary are pillar countries in China-proposed BRI, and have long been at the forefront of European countries' relations with China with close cooperation, Dong said, adding that high-level diplomacy has played a key role in the two countries' relations with China.\n\nHe Zhigao, a research fellow with the Institute of European Studies of CASS, said that Serbia and Hungary \"stand out\" among European countries in regard to developing China ties partly because they can overcome some external restraints and make more {"uri": "8117598827", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:54:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:54:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:53:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/international/global/china-serbia-chart-shared-future-xi-jinping-visits-europe", "title": "China, Serbia chart 'shared future' as Xi Jinping visits Europe", "body": "CHINA and Serbia on Wednesday (May 8) agreed to follow a \"shared future\" as President Xi Jinping visited the Balkan country as part of his bid to forge stronger relations with allies at the edge of the European Union.\n\nXi is on his first European tour in five years, and the trip was seen as an effort to strengthen ties with eastern European countries that are pro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment. He will fly to Hungary later in the day.\n\n\"We are writing history today,\" Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic told a large crowd that had gathered in front of the Serbian presidential palace to welcome Xi, applauding and chanting \"China, China\".\n\nThe two countries signed 29 agreements promoting legal, regulatory and economic cooperation. Serbia will also become the first European country in years to enter into a free trade agreement with China when a deal signed last year comes into effect on Jul 1.\n\nVucic said that since 2020 China had been the single-largest investor in Serbia, and that its investment was up 30-fold over the past decade. The free trade deal will guarantee tariff-free exports for 95 per cent of Serbian products to China over the next five to 10 years, he said.\n\nXi said that China was ready to import more high-quality agricultural products from Serbia and would welcome more direct flights between Belgrade and Chinese cities.\n\nBoth leaders boast of an ironclad partnership. Along with Hungary, Serbia is Europe's firmest supporter of China's huge Belt and Road infrastructure project across parts of Asia and Europe.\n\n\"Serbia became China's first strategic partner in central and eastern Europe eight years ago, and it becomes the first European country with which we shall build a community with shared future,\" Xi said.\n\nThe two leaders said they would support each other's sovereignty and territorial integrity, meaning that Serbia considers Taiwan, viewed by Beijing as a breakaway province, to be part of China, just as China considers Kosovo, which declared independence in 2008, as part of Serbia.\n\n\"We shall jointly confront hegemony and the politics of power,\" Xi said.\n\nXi\u00b4s visit comes on the anniversary of the 1999 Nato bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during a campaign against the former Yugoslavia to force late Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.\n\nNato said the bombing, which killed three Chinese journalists and wounded 20 Chinese nationals, was accidental. It prompted outrage in China and an apology from then US President bill Clinton.\n\n\"The Chinese people appreciate the peace but will never allow that a historic tragedy repeats itself,\" Xi said in an opinion article in the daily Politika on Tuesday.\n\nVucic said the two countries had agreed to establish an inter-governmental technology committee that would enable Serbia to get access to the latest technologies and use of artificial intelligence.\n\nChina owns mines and factories across Serbia and has lent billions for roads, bridges and new facilities, becoming Serbia's key partner in much-needed infrastructure development.\n\nXi left France on Tuesday after a two-day trip during which he offered no major concessions on trade or foreign policy, even as President Emmanuel Macron pressed him on market access and Ukraine. {"uri": "8117251097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:19:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:19:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:18:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com/chinas-xi-welcomed-respect-love-serbia-3731513", "title": "China's Xi Welcomed With 'Respect And Love' In Serbia", "body": "Serbia's President Aleksandar Vucic reaffirmed his strong support for China's sovereignty over Taiwan Wednesday as he gave a lavish welcome to President Xi Jinping, who is seeking to deepen political and economic ties with friendlier countries in Europe.\n\nChina has poured billions into Serbia and neighbouring Balkan countries, particularly into mining and manufacturing, and last year Beijing and Belgrade signed a free trade agreement.\n\nXi and his wife Peng Liyuan were greeted by Vucic on a red carpet outside the main government offices in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nThe Chinese leader was met by a gun salute and the Chinese national anthem before shaking hands with officials including the prime minister and the National Bank of Serbia governor.\n\nThe two leaders waved from a balcony to several thousand people waiting outside, with some waving Chinese flags.\n\nVucic called welcomed Xi a \"friend of Serbia\".\n\n\"Such respect and love as he will find here in our Serbia, he will not find anywhere else,\" Vucic added.\n\nHe told the crowd as Xi applauded: \"We have a clear and simple position regarding Chinese territorial integrity. Yes, Taiwan is China\".\n\nBeijing claims the self-ruled island as its own, and said it will not rule out using force to bring the island under Chinese control.\n\nAs the two leaders sat down for meetings, Xi told Vucic in opening comments that there was a \"strong feeling of friendship between our two countries\".\n\nXi arrived in Belgrade on Tuesday evening following a state visit to France that saw sometimes robust exchanges with President Emmanuel Macron on trade and China's close ties to Russia despite the Ukraine war.\n\nThe other two countries chosen for Xi's first trip to Europe since 2019 -- with Hungary as the final stop after Serbia -- are among the most sympathetic to Moscow in Europe.\n\nStreets in the Serbian capital were decked out with Chinese flags, along with posters and billboards that proclaimed a \"warm welcome\" to \"Chinese friends\".\n\nXi's visit also coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 US bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, which killed three people.\n\n\"Do not forget that our Chinese friends were with us 25 years ago when this country was being demolished and bombed,\" Vucic told the crowds.\n\n\"They paid a high price, they lost people only a few hundred meters from here on this very day.\"\n\nThe embassy was hit during a months-long, US-led NATO campaign targeting Serbian security forces who were at war with ethnic-Albanian insurgents in Kosovo.\n\nThe US later apologised, saying outdated maps had led the pilot to strike the wrong target.\n\nOn Tuesday, Xi wrote in the Serbian daily Politika that NATO had \"flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy\", warning that China would \"never allow such tragic history to repeat itself\".\n\nChina has long backed Serbia's territoral claims over the breakaway province of Kosovo and along with Russia has prevented its recognition at the United Nations.\n\nSerbian finance minister Sinisa Mali told state broadcaster RTS that discussions Wednesday would centre on \"a great project\" and a \"major investment from China in a very promising area.\"\n\n\"For Serbia, this is without a doubt one of the most significant visits,\" Marko Tmusic, a political sciences professor at the University of Belgrade, told AFP.\n\n\"Standing 'shoulder to shoulder' with France -- with whom China marks 60 years of diplomatic relations -- and Hungary... is certainly a great honour\" for Serbia, he added.\n\nPeople in Belgrade welcomed Xi's visit.\n\n\"I think it's an excellent thing, this visit from the president of one of the most powerful countries in the world,\" 67-year-old Stojan Vidovic, a retiree, told AFP.\n\nIn France, Xi met with Macron and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. They urged him not to allow the export of technology that could be used by Russia in Ukraine and to do all it could to end the war.\n\nEurope is concerned that while officially neutral over the Ukraine conflict, China is essentially backing Russia, which is using Chinese machine tools in arms production.\n\nAfter meeting with Vucic, Xi will go later Wednesday to Hungary where China has invested heavily in vast battery and electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing plants.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business Times"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8117720665", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:15:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:15:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:14:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/world/europe/2024-05-08-china-and-serbia-plan-shared-future-as-xi-visits/", "title": "China and Serbia plan 'shared future' as Xi visits", "body": "Belgrade -- China and Serbia on Wednesday agreed to follow a \"shared future\" as President Xi Jinping visited the Balkan country as part of his bid to forge stronger relations with allies at the edge of the EU.\n\nXi is on his first European tour in five years, and the trip was seen as an effort to strengthen ties with eastern European countries that are pro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment. He will fly to Hungary later in the day.\n\n\"We are writing history today,\" Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic told a large crowd that had gathered in front of the Serbian presidential palace to welcome Xi, applauding and chanting \"China, China\".\n\nThe two countries signed 29 agreements promoting legal, regulatory and economic co-operation. Serbia will also become the first European country in years to enter into a free-trade agreement with China when a deal signed in 2023 comes into effect on July 1.\n\nTop investor\n\nVucic said that since 2020 China had been the single-largest investor in Serbia, and that its investment was up 30-fold over the past decade. The free-trade deal will guarantee tariff-free exports for 95% of Serbian products to China over the next five to 10 years, he said.\n\nXi said that China was ready to import more high-quality agricultural products from Serbia and would welcome more direct flights between Belgrade and Chinese cities.\n\nBoth leaders boast of an ironclad partnership. Along with Hungary, Serbia is Europe's firmest supporter of China's huge Belt and Road infrastructure project across parts of Asia and Europe.\n\n\"Serbia became China's first strategic partner in central and Eastern Europe eight years ago, and it becomes the first European country with which we shall build a community with shared future,\" Xi said.\n\nThe two leaders said they would support each other's sovereignty and territorial integrity, meaning that Serbia considers Taiwan, viewed by Beijing as a breakaway province, to be part of China, just as China considers Kosovo, which declared independence in 2008, as part of Serbia.\n\n\"We shall jointly confront hegemony and the politics of power,\" Xi said.\n\nSymbolism\n\nXi's visit comes on the anniversary of the 1999 Nato bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade during a campaign against the former Yugoslavia to force late Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.\n\nNato said the bombing, which killed three Chinese journalists and wounded 20 Chinese nationals, was accidental. It prompted outrage in China and an apology from then US president Bill Clinton.\n\n\"The Chinese people appreciate the peace but will never allow that a historic tragedy repeats itself,\" Xi said in an opinion article in the daily Politika on Tuesday.\n\nVucic said the two countries had agreed to establish an intergovernmental technology committee that would enable Serbia to get access to the latest technologies and use of artificial intelligence.\n\nChina owns mines and factories across Serbia and has lent billions for roads, bridges and new facilities, becoming Serbia's key partner in much-needed infrastructure development.\n\nXi left France on Tuesday after a two-day trip during which he offered no major concessions on trade or foreign policy, even as President Emmanuel Macron He said hs visit to Serbia is \"historic\" because it opens the path for even closer ties.\n\n\"We are writing history today, although it doesn't seem so to many (people),\" Vucic said. \"We thank President Xi. He hasn't come to Europe in five years and he has again chosen our little Serbia.\"\n\nAt the start of the official meeting on Wednesday, Xi said \"we are first-hand witnesses that the Serbian people view Chinese people as ironclad best friends.\"\n\n\"This is truly two-sided and truthful friendship ... I truly hail this and it really made an extremely deep impression on me,\" Xi said, according to the state RTS television.\n\nXi will proceed to Hungary later on Wednesday. Like Serbia, Hungary is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were clearly visible throughout the Serbian capital. A huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nChina has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date -- the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by U.S. jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed.\n\nThe incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nChinese companies run Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbor Hungary.\n\n\"Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xi said in a statement published by China's Foreign Ministry.\n\n\"Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista dcChina-Serbia cooperation,\" added Xi. \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations.\"\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernize the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes.\n\nThe arms delivery over the territory of at {"uri": "2024-05-349475939", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "20:27:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T20:27:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T19:52:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/after-serbia-chinas-xi-arrives-in-hungary-to-tighten-bonds/article_a15fa208-38e8-5df7-a46a-f8fdfd812ca1.html", "title": "After Serbia, China's Xi arrives in Hungary to tighten bonds", "body": "Serbia has repeatedly supported China's claims over Taiwan, and Beijing has backed Serbia's claims over Kosovo\n\nFollowing a visit to Serbia, Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Budapest on Wednesday in the last leg of his European tour aimed at strengthening already flourishing ties between Beijing and its closest EU ally.\n\nXi's three-day visit to Hungary marks 75 years of diplomatic relations between the two countries, with the Chinese leader expected to attend a state dinner with Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban later on Wednesday.\n\nHe began his European trip in France, a visit that was cordial but also highlighted tensions between Beijing and the EU over the war in Ukraine and global trade.\n\nEarlier on Wednesday, Xi wrapped up his visit in Serbia, which like Hungary has close ties to both Russia and China.\n\nChina has poured billions into Serbia and neighbouring Balkan countries, particularly into mining and manufacturing, and last year Beijing and Belgrade signed a free-trade agreement.\n\nSerbia's President Aleksandar Vucic greeted Xi and his wife Peng Liyuan on a red carpet outside the main government offices in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nThe Chinese leader was met by a gun salute before shaking hands with officials, including the prime minister and the National Bank of Serbia governor.\n\nThe two leaders waved from a balcony to several thousand people, some waving Chinese flags, as Vucic called Xi a \"friend of Serbia\".\n\n\"Such respect and love as he will find here in our Serbia, he will not find anywhere else,\" Vucic added.\n\nHe also told the crowd as Xi applauded: \"We have a clear and simple position regarding Chinese territorial integrity. Yes, Taiwan is China.\"\n\nBeijing claims the self-ruled island as its own, and has not ruled out using force to bring it under Chinese control.\n\nXi told Vucic in opening comments that there was a \"strong feeling of friendship between our two countries\".\n\nThey later appeared together to sign a joint declaration, with commercial promises including the purchase of new Chinese trains, new air links, and increased Serbian imports.\n\n- NATO bombing -\n\nStreets in the Serbian capital were decked out with Chinese flags and posters proclaiming a \"warm welcome\" to \"Chinese friends\".\n\nXi's visit coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 US bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, which killed three people.\n\n\"Do not forget that our Chinese friends were with us 25 years ago when this country was being demolished and bombed,\" Vucic told the crowds Wednesday.\n\nThe embassy was hit during a months-long, US-led NATO campaign targeting Serbian security forces who were at war with ethnic-Albanian insurgents in Kosovo.\n\nThe United States later apologised, saying outdated maps had led the pilot to strike the wrong target.\n\nOn Tuesday, Xi wrote in the Serbian daily Politika that NATO had \"flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy\", warning that China would \"never allow such tragic history to repeat itself\".\n\nSerbia has repeatedly supported China's claims over Taiwan and in turn, Beijing has long backed Serbia's territorial claims over the breakaway province of Kosovo.\n\nAlong with Russia, China has prevented Kosovo's recognition at the United Nations.\n\nXi called for the two countries to \"firmly support each other's core interests\".\n\n\"China supports Serbia in upholding its policy of acting independently... (and) its efforts to safeguard national sovereignty and territorial integrity on the Kosovo issue,\" he said Wednesday.\n\n- Ukraine fears -\n\n\"For Serbia, this is without a doubt one of the most significant visits,\" Marko Tmusic, a political sciences professor at the University of Belgrade, told AFP.\n\nIn Belgrade, many welcomed Xi's visit.\n\n\"I think it's an excellent thing, this visit from the president of one of the most powerful countries in the world,\" 67-year-old Stojan Vidovic, a retiree, told AFP.\n\nIn France, Xi met President Emmanuel Macron and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen who urged him not to allow the export of technology that could be used by Russia in Ukraine and to do all it could to end the war.\n\nXi warned the West not to \"smear\" China over the conflict and hit back at accusations that Chinese overcapacity was causing global trade imbalances.\n\nSome European allies are concerned that while officially neutral over the Ukraine conflict, China is essentially backing Russia, which is using Chinese machine tools in arms production.\n\nIn Hungary, China has invested heavily in vast battery and electric vehicle manufacturing plants.\n\nXi will hold talks with Orban, who has bucked the European Union's official position to \"de-risk\" relations with China.\n\nbur-rox-ehl/kym/imm\n\nMore from this section\n\nGemoo Launches CapUp to Make Viral Videos for Tiktok, Instagram, and YouTube easily and Instantly MMI Webinar with MBA Focuses on Using Data, Technology to Reach 'Mortgage-Ready' Millennials TikTok sues US to block
