in Serbia", "body": "China has invested billions of dollars in Serbia and the Balkans, especially in the mining and manufacturing sectors\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping was received \"with respect and love\" by his Serbian counterpart Aleksandar Vucic in the Serbian capital on Wednesday, a new leg of his European tour that has already taken him to France and will end in Hungary.\n\nChina has invested billions of dollars in Serbia and the Balkans, especially in the mining and manufacturing sectors, and Beijing and Belgrade signed a free trade agreement last year.\n\nAccompanied by his wife Peng Liyuan, Xi Jinping was greeted on Wednesday by Aleksandar Vucic on a red carpet in front of the main government buildings to the sound of the military band.\n\nThe two leaders greeted a crowd of several thousand people, some waving Chinese flags, from a balcony, according to footage from Serbian state television RTS.\n\nVucic welcomed Xi Jinping and called him \"a friend of Serbia\". \"The respect and love you will find here, in our Serbia, you will not find anywhere else,\" he added.\n\nThe Chinese president was greeted by his country's national anthem, before shaking hands with several Serbian officials.\n\n\"Yes, Taiwan is China,\" Vucic told the crowd, a statement in line with China's claim to the island, which it considers part of its territory.\n\nAt the start of their bilateral meeting, Xi told Vucic that there was \"a strong feeling of friendship\" between the two countries.\n\nThey then met to sign a joint statement on strengthening their diplomatic relations and attended the presentation of several draft trade agreements, including the purchase of Chinese trains, new air links and increased imports of Serbian goods.\n\nThe Chinese president arrived in Belgrade on Tuesday evening after a state visit to France where he was received with pomp by French President Emmanuel Macron and they discussed trade disputes and Beijing-Moscow relations, which the West frowns upon in the context of the war in Ukraine.\n\nIn addition to France and Serbia, on his first trip to Europe since 2019, Xi Jinping will visit Hungary.\n\nSerbia and Hungary are considered the most friendly countries with Russia and China on the European continent.\n\nSerbian Finance Minister Sinisa Mali told RTS that Wednesday's talks would focus on \"a big project\", without giving further details.\n\nXi Jinping's visit to Belgrade coincides with the 25th anniversary of the US bombing of the Chinese embassy, which killed three people on May 7, 1999, as part of a NATO campaign against Serb targets during the Kosovo war.\n\nThe US later apologised and claimed that the maps were out of date.\n\nSpeaking about the event in an article published on Tuesday in the Serbian daily Politika, Xi Jinping said NATO had \"brazenly bombed\" the embassy.\n\n\"The Chinese people cherish peace, but will never allow the tragedy of history to happen again,\" he stressed, also extolling the \"unfailing friendship\" between China and Serbia.\n\nSerbs interviewed by AFP in Belgrade said they welcomed Xi Jinping's arrival.\n\n\"I think it's a great thing, this visit by the president of one of the most powerful countries in the world,\" said Stojan Vidovic, a 67-year-old pensioner.\n\n\"It's fantastic for us,\" said Dijana Radic, 69, who hopes the visit will lead to \"something good {"uri": "8115230593", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "09:19:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T09:19:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T09:18:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.b92.net/english/politics/19953/belgrade-is-ready-to-host-xi-chinese-flags-flaunting-xi-ahead-of-visit-land-of-beauty-and-legends-photo/vest", "title": "Belgrade is ready to host Xi, Chinese flags flaunting; Xi ahead of visit: Land of beauty and legends PHOTO", "body": "President of China, Xi Jinping, will pay an official visit to Serbia today and tomorrow, and he will be hosted by the President of Serbia, Aleksandar Vu\u010di\u0107.\n\nThe last time Xi was in Serbia was back in 2016, which was the first visit of the President of China to Serbia after 32 years, and on that occasion the Declaration on Strategic Partnership was signed.\n\nXi is coming to Belgrade on the anniversary of the NATO bombing of the Chinese embassy building in New Belgrade, in which three Chinese journalists were killed. Xinhua correspondent Shao Junhaun and Guangming daily correspondents Su Xinghua and Zhu Ying were killed.\n\nIn the rocket attack on the Chinese Embassy, which happened 15 minutes before midnight, 20 people were injured. The embassy, which was visibly marked as a building of diplomatic importance, was hit by three missiles, and in addition to the main building, auxiliary buildings in the embassy yard were also destroyed.\n\nIn the attack on the embassy, buildings in the immediate vicinity suffered significant damage, especially the \"Energoprojekt\" building and the JBC Residential and Business Center.\n\nA memorial plaque was discovered at the site of the bombing in 2009.\n\nIn an author's text for daily Politika, Chinese President Xi Jinping states that he still remembers the friendly scene during his previous visit to Serbia and that he is looking forward to meeting Serbian President Aleksandar Vu\u010di\u0107.\n\n\"When summer approaches, all plants bloom. In this time full of hope, at the invitation of President Aleksandar Vu\u010di\u0107, I will pay a state visit to the Republic of Serbia. This will be my second visit to your country, the land of beauty and legends, as the President of the People's Republic of China. Friendly scenes during my last visit to Serbia 8 years ago are still vivid in my mind, and in the past 8 years the close cooperation between the two sides has already achieved fruitful results of cooperation and injects new vitality into the steel friendship between China and Serbia,\" the Chinese president writes in an author's text for Politika.\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping, who is arriving in Belgrade today, was in France yesterday, where he spoke with French President Emmanuel Macron. On that occasion, the two leaders confirmed their commitment to promoting a political solution to the Iranian nuclear issue.\n\nIn a joint statement, Xi and Macron called for \"concrete implementation\" of the two-state solution when it comes to the conflict in the Gaza Strip and condemned Israel's policy of building settlements in the West Bank, Reuters reports citing Chinese state media. Xi and Macron urged all sides to refrain from taking unilateral steps on the ground that could increase tensions in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.\n\nVu\u010di\u0107 met Xi in October last year in Beijing, during the third \"Belt and Road\" Forum, when 18 agreements were signed, including the Free Trade Agreement between Serbia and China, which should soon enter into force.\n\nThis is President Xi's first visit to Europe in the last five years, since the outbreak of the Covid-19 pandemic, and during this European tour, he will visit only three European capitals - Paris, Belgrade and Budapest.\n\nHe started his five-day tour with a visit to France on May 5, he will come to Belgrade on May 7, and after that he will visit Budapest. Major security measures were taken for Xi's arrival in Belgrade, so his delegation will be secured by 3,400 policemen, Tanjug learns.\n\nXi will be met by Serbian MiG-29 fighters who will follow his plane from the border, and a guard of the Serbian Army will be lined up in his honor at the Belgrade airport.\n\nChinese and Serbian flags will be placed along the highway in Belgrade, and a ceremonial welcome of the Chinese delegation, numbering 400 people, will be organized in front of the Palace of Serbia, and more than 30 agreements are planned to be signed.\n\nA festive lunch will be organized, and the Chinese President will have the opportunity to taste Serbian dishes and wines, and a music program in Serbian and Chinese will be held, which will end with the song \"This is Serbia\".\n\nThe Chinese president will be hosted by Serbian President Aleksandar Vu\u010di\u0107. The last time Xi was in Serbia was in 2016, which was the first visit of the President of China to Serbia after 32 years, and on that occasion the Declaration on Strategic Partnership was signed.\n\nDuring the last meeting of the Chinese and Serbian presidents in October last year in Beijing, in addition to the Free Trade Agreement, several bilateral documents were signed, such as those on police cooperation in managing emergency situations, the construction of roads, the Serbian-Chinese industrial park, the export of apples, digitization.\n\nOn the eve of Chinese President Xi's visit, President Vu\u010di\u0107 told Chinese CCTV that China is Serbia's best partner in achieving national goals and assessed that Xi's visit to Belgrade comes at the right time, that he is very happy about the talks he will have with the Chinese president and that there is many topics to discuss.\n\nHe stressed that Serbia is fully committed to Xi's visit and believes that it will bring benefits and be in the interest of both the Chinese and Serbian people. Announcing the visit of the Chinese president in his address to the citizens, Vu\u010di\u0107 said that Xi is one of the most important world leaders and a sincere friend of Serbia and asked all citizens of Serbia to welcome the Chinese president in a \"wonderful and hospitable\" way.\n\nPresident Vu\u010di\u0107 pointed out that thanks to the cooperation with Beijing, Serbia has gained a lot, and one of those things is a direct airline to Tianjin, and emphasized that we will soon get another to Shanghai, and that a third is planned, which will connect Belgrade and Guangzhou.\n\nChinese Ambassador to Belgrade Li Ming assessed that the visit of Chinese President Xi Jinping to Serbia at the highest, state level, represents a turning point for raising the level of cooperation and upgrading relations between Serbia and China.\n\n\"We believe that Serbia will be a great host and that the visit will be successful and fruitful,\" Ambassador Li Ming told reporters at a conference organized on the occasion of the arrival of President Xi Jinping in Belgrade. The ambassador believes that the visit will make a new contribution to the peace, stability and prosperity of the region and adds that a number of development documents and contracts will be signed during the visit. Trade between the two countries is growing year by year, in 2023 it amounted to 5.6 billion euros, so China became Serbia's second trading partner. The largest Serbian exporters last year were three Chinese-owned companies, Zijin Mining exported goods worth 1.15 billion euros, Zijin Copper was second with 746.3 million, and the owner of the Smederevo ironworks, HBIS Group, exported 549.1 million euros.\n\nThe share of the mine in Bor, with the production of 240,000 tons of copper per year, is 24 percent of the total production of the Zijin Mining Group. Chinese companies also participate in numerous infrastructure and traffic projects, such as the construction of the \"Milo\u0161 Veliki\" highway section from Pakovra\u0107a to Po\u017eega, the construction of the Fru\u0161ka gora corridor, the Danube corridor, the construction of the \"Osmeh Vojvodina\" expressway, the Belgrade - Zrenjanin - Novi Sad highway.\n\nWhen it comes to railway projects, Chinese companies are building a high-speed railway from Novi Sad to Subotica, they are participating in the Belgrade metro project, Serbia is also buying five high-speed trains from China, and Chinese companies have built a section of the high-speed railway from Belgrade to Stara Pazova.\n\nChinese companies participated in numerous completed projects, such as the sections of the \"Milo\u0161 Veliki\" highway from Belgrade to Ub (including the bridge over the Sava) and from Lajkovac to Ljig, they participated in the construction of the Belgrade ring road, and the Pupin bridge over the Danube was the first in Europe in the construction of which Chinese companies participated.\n\nSerbia and China also participate in energy projects, such as the construction of block B3 of the Kostolac thermal power plant with a capacity of 350 megawatts, joint communal projects, the construction of sewage...\n\nOn Monday, Xi visited Paris, where he met with French President Emmanuel Macron and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.\n\nThe President of China is accompanied by his wife Peng Liyuan, member of the Main Committee of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC), director of the General Office of the CPC Central Committee Cai Qi, as well as member of the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee and Foreign Mr. Vucic said that Mr. Xi's visit was a great honor and that China is a source of inspiration for Serbia.\n\nSigns of pro-Chinese sentiments were clearly visible: a huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a road leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags were visible in the city center and along a highway.\n\nChina has invested billions of dollars in Serbia in the form of investments and loans, particularly in the mining and infrastructure sectors. The two countries signed a strategic partnership agreement in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked country in the heart of the Balkans, is a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative, intended to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date: the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade by American planes during the NATO air war over Kosovo, during which three Chinese citizens were killed. This incident helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\nOur bilateral relationship has stood the test of the changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations, Xi said in an arrival statement released by the Chinese Ministry of Affairs. foreign. He described the friendship between Serbia and China as ironclad.\n\nStanding at a new historic starting point, China will work with Serbia to stick to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open a new perspective in China-Serbia cooperation with stronger momentum, more greater scope and better quality, he said: I added: I am convinced that this visit will be fruitful and open a new chapter in Sino-Serbian relations.\n\nChinese companies operate Serbia's largest copper mine and steel mill, and are also building numerous roads and highways across the country, as well as a railway to Hungary, its northern neighbor.\n\nIn 2014, Hungary and Serbia struck a deal with Beijing to upgrade the railway between their capitals Budapest and Belgrade, as part of a Belt and Road plan to connect the port of Piraeus, in Greece, under Chinese control, in the south, a point of entry. for Chinese products to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than $2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays.\n\nIn 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia received a semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown on US Army Y-20 transport planes. {"uri": "2024-05-349859499", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "06:59:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T06:59:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T03:30:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.bradfordera.com/online_features/business_and_careers/global-times-xi-vucic-hold-talks-hail-evergrowing-ironclad-friendship/article_dd0f792a-cf24-5817-ac93-b06ecdbe7e46.html", "title": "Global Times: Xi, Vucic hold talks, hail evergrowing ironclad friendship", "body": "BEIJING, May 8, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- Chinese President Xi Jinping and Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic on Wednesday signed a joint statement on building a community with shared future in the new era in Belgrade, making Serbia the first European country to build such a community with China.\n\nIn the joint statement, the two countries decided to deepen and elevate the China-Serbia comprehensive strategic partnership. Serbia was the first Central and Eastern European country to become China's comprehensive strategic partner eight years ago.\n\n\"It is a strategic choice made by both sides to build a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era. Its goal is to realize the aspiration of the two peoples for a better life. Its foundation and driving force come from the firm support and extensive participation of the two peoples,\" Xi told reporters during a joint press conference with Vucic.\n\nXi also announced six measures to support the building of a China-Serbia community with a shared future.\n\nChina is ready to import more quality and distinctive agricultural products from Serbia. China welcomes Serbia to increase direct flights between Belgrade and Shanghai, and encourages airlines from both sides to launch direct flights between Belgrade and Guangzhou.\n\nThe Chinese side will aid 50 young Serbian scientists in exchange programs with China for the next three years and a total of 300 Serbian youths will be invited to study in China in the next three years, said Xi.\n\nChina supports Serbia in hosting Expo 2027, and will send a delegation to participate in the grand show. China encourages its enterprises to take part in the construction of relevant projects, Xi said.\n\nWith joint efforts from China and Serbia, the free trade agreement between the two countries will take effect on July 1, Xi said.\n\nDuring his talks with Vucic on Wednesday in Belgrade, Xi said bilateral relations between China and Serbia are richer in content and have become a model of friendly relations between China and European countries.\n\nXi called on China and Serbia to carry forward the innovative nature of bilateral relations, open up new prospects for cooperation, and make innovative cooperation a new growth point of bilateral ties.\n\nXi was greeted by tens of thousands of Serbians on Wednesday and a welcoming ceremony was held outside the Palace of Serbia before the meeting between the two leaders.\n\nChinese national flags and Chinese-language welcoming banners were hanging on landmark buildings in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nChinese and Serbian experts said the meeting between the two heads of state will continue to provide high-level guidance to the sound development of bilateral relationship for the years to come and further inject vitality into the time-weathered, ironclad friendship.\n\nIronclad friendship\n\nOn Tuesday, a signed article by President Xi titled \"May the Light of Our Ironclad Friendship Shine on the Path of China-Serbia Cooperation\" was published in Serbian media Politika.\n\nXi noted in the article that \"there has always been an affinity between Chinese and Serbian peoples despite the long distance between us. During the bitter Anti-Fascist War and our respective nation-building in the last century, the Chinese and Serbian peoples forged a strong friendship that extends through time and space.\"\n\n\"Amid the ongoing transformations unseen in a century in the world, our mutual support remains as strong as ever, our cooperation is closer, and our exchanges and mutual learning more substantive. Whatever changes in the international landscape, China and Serbia remain true friends and good partners. Our ironclad friendship is ever-growing, setting a model for state-to-state and people-to-people interactions,\" Xi wrote.\n\nXi said China and Serbia should always be good friends and treat each other with sincerity, good partners for win-win cooperation, play an exemplary role in promoting fairness and justice and strengthen the heart-to-heart connection between their two peoples.\n\nWith China's support, hundreds of kilometers of highways have been built, the fastest railway in Eastern Europe entered operation, and energy facilities keep renewing, Boyan Lalic, Director of the Belt and Road Institute Belgrade, told the Global Times Wednesday.\n\nThe China-built high-speed railway connecting Belgrade to Novi Sad, inexpensive and comfortable, has cut the previously 1.5-hour trip to just 36 minutes, making a two-city life possible for many young people seeking opportunities, the Global Times learned.\n\nThe railway is part of a more ambitious project linking Belgrade and Budapest, the capital of Hungary, which could finish construction as early as 2025. The project has created jobs, offered unique career experience and trainings, and has allowed people like Serbian engineer Aleksandra Milosavljevic to \"make really good friends with my Chinese colleagues.\"\n\nJoin hands on international stage\n\nThe China-Serbia friendship, forged with the blood of our compatriots, will stay in the shared memory of the Chinese and Serbian peoples, and will inspire us to march forward with big strides, Xi wrote.\n\nDong Yifan, a research fellow at the Institute of European Studies, China Institutes of Contemporary International Relations, said that both China and Serbia adhere to independence and non-alignment in their strategic approaches, choosing to follow their own development paths and opposing hegemony. \"We share a strong consensus in international affairs.\"\n\nThe last stop of Xi's three-nation European trip is Hungary, during which a series of cooperation agreements are expected to be signed, according to media reports.\n\nBoth Serbia and Hungary are pillar countries in China-proposed BRI, and have long been at the forefront of European countries' relations with China with close cooperation, Dong said, adding that high-level diplomacy has played a key role in the two countries' relations with China.\n\nHe Zhigao, a research fellow with the Institute of European Studies of CASS, said that Serbia and Hungary \"stand out\" among European countries in regard to developing China ties partly because they can overcome some external restraints and make more independent decisions based on their own interests.\n\nView original {"uri": "8116241771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "20:56:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T20:56:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T20:52:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13393245/Chinas-Xi-Jinping-visits-Serbia-anniversary-1999-NATO-bombing.html", "title": "China's Xi Jinping visits Serbia on anniversary of 1999 NATO bombing", "body": "By Aleksandar Vasovic and Daria Sito-Sucic\n\nBELGRADE, May 7 (Reuters) - Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Serbia on Tuesday evening escorted by MIG-29 jets in a tightly secured visit coinciding with the 25th anniversary of the NATO bombing of China's embassy in which three Chinese journalists were killed.\n\nBelgrade, after France, is the second stop on Xi's first visit to Europe in five years, which also includes Hungary. In Serbia, which is seen as China's most important partner in the Balkans, Xi is expected to discuss China\u00b4s multi-billion investment in the country and possible new deals.\n\nSerbian President Aleksandar Vucic and government officials welcomed Xi at the Belgrade airport, where he was greeted by a military guard of honor and folk dancers. The two leaders will hold a meeting on Wednesday.\n\nOn May 7, 1999, 20 Chinese nationals were wounded in the NATO attack, which prompted outrage in China and an apology from then U.S. President Bill Clinton.\n\nThe embassy was hit during a campaign against the then Yugoslavia to force late Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.\n\n\"The Chinese people appreciate the peace but will never allow that a historic tragedy repeats itself,\" Xi said in an opinion article in the daily Politika on Tuesday.\n\n\"The friendship between China and Serbia which is soaked in blood that the two peoples spilled together has become a joint memory of the two peoples and will encourage both parties to make together huge steps forward,\" Xi said.\n\nThe Belgrade streets were decorated with Chinese flags and placards as thousands of police officers were deployed to secure Xi and his 400-member entourage, the highest-level visit by a foreign leader in years.\n\nIRONCLAD FRIENDSHIP\n\nXi is visiting Serbia after France, where President Emmanuel Macron and EU Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen pressed him to ensure more balanced trade with Europe and use his influence on Russia to end the war in Ukraine.\n\nDuring his first visit to Belgrade in 2016, the two countries signed a strategic partnership. Last year, Vucic signed 18 agreements with Xi in Beijing, including a free trade deal that should become operational in July.\n\nBoth leaders insist on an ironclad partnership between their countries. Along with Hungary, which is Xi\u00b4s next stop, Serbia is Europe's firmest supporter of China\u00b4s Belt and Road Initiative.\n\nChina runs mines and factories across Serbia and has lent billions for roads, bridges and new facilities, becoming Serbia's key partner in much-needed infrastructure development.\n\nObservers say Xi's choice of Serbia and Hungary is designed to pull closer two European countries that are pro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment. Serbia\u00b4s Western partners view the country as a Chinese hub at the gateway to the EU.\n\nIn 2023, China was Serbia\u00b4s second-largest trading partner after the EU with a total trade exchange of $6.1 billion and among its top five investors, according to the national investment agency. Xi will proceed to Hungary later on Wednesday, which, like Serbia, is seen as one of China's more friendly partners in Europe.\n\nSerbian President Aleksandar Vucic and other top officials welcomed Xi at the airport on Tuesday after his plane was escorted by military jets. Vucic said Xi's visit was a \"great honour\" and that China is an \"inspiration\" for Serbia.\n\nCongress Criticises Modi Government China Policy\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were clearly visible - a huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway. China has poured billions of dollars into Serbia in investment and loans, particularly in mining and infrastructure. The two countries signed an agreement on a strategic partnership in 2016 and a free trade agreement last year.\n\nSerbia, a landlocked nation in the heart of the Balkans, has been a key country in China's Belt and Road initiative designed to increase Beijing's influence in Europe through economic investment. Critics say it could serve as a Chinese Trojan horse and gateway to Europe.\n\nXi also arrived in Serbia on a symbolic date: the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade by US jets during NATO's air war over Kosovo, when three Chinese citizens were killed. The incident has helped forge close political ties between China and Serbia.\n\n\"Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xi said in an arrival statement published by China's Foreign Ministry. He described the Serbia-China friendship as \"ironclad\". \"Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation with stronger momentum, greater scope, and higher quality,\" added Xi. \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations.\"\n\nUS Warns Of China-Russia Collaboration For Possible Taiwan Invasion - Report\n\nChinese companies are running Serbia's biggest copper mine and a steel mill, and are also building scores of roads and highways across the country, along with a railway toward northern neighbour Hungary. In 2014, Hungary and Serbia concluded an agreement with Beijing to modernise the railway between their capitals of Budapest and Belgrade, part of a Belt and Road plan to link up with the Chinese-controlled port of Piraeus in Greece to the south, an entry point for Chinese goods to Central and Eastern Europe.\n\nThe more than USD 2 billion project is expected to be completed in 2026, after numerous delays. In 2022, shortly after the Russian invasion of Ukraine, Serbia took semi-secret delivery of a sophisticated Chinese anti-aircraft system flown in on Chinese Air Force Y-20 transport planes. The arms delivery over the territory of at least two NATO member states, Turkiye and Bulgaria, was seen by experts as a demonstration of China's growing global reach.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-349014595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:41:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:41:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T10:20:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/chinas-xi-welcomed-with-respect-and-love-in-serbia/article_a15fa208-38e8-5df7-a46a-f8fdfd812ca1.html", "title": "China's Xi welcomed with 'respect and love' in Serbia", "body": "The two leaders waved from a balcony to a crowd of several thousand waiting outside\n\nSerbia's President Aleksandar Vucic reaffirmed his strong support for China's sovereignty over Taiwan Wednesday as he gave a lavish welcome to President Xi Jinping, who is seeking to deepen political and economic ties with friendlier countries in Europe.\n\nChina has poured billions into Serbia and neighbouring Balkan countries, particularly into mining and manufacturing, and last year Beijing and Belgrade signed a free trade agreement.\n\nXi and his wife Peng Liyuan were greeted by Vucic on a red carpet outside the main government offices in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nThe Chinese leader was met by a gun salute and the Chinese national anthem before shaking hands with officials including the prime minister and the National Bank of Serbia governor.\n\nThe two leaders waved from a balcony to several thousand people waiting outside, with some waving Chinese flags.\n\nVucic called welcomed Xi a \"friend of Serbia\".\n\n\"Such respect and love as he will find here in our Serbia, he will not find anywhere else,\" Vucic added.\n\nHe told the crowd as Xi applauded: \"We have a clear and simple position regarding Chinese territorial integrity. Yes, Taiwan is China\".\n\nBeijing claims the self-ruled island as its own, and said it will not rule out using force to bring the island under Chinese control.\n\nAs the two leaders sat down for meetings, Xi told Vucic in opening comments that there was a \"strong feeling of friendship between our two countries\".\n\nXi arrived in Belgrade on Tuesday evening following a state visit to France that saw sometimes robust exchanges with President Emmanuel Macron on trade and China's close ties to Russia despite the Ukraine war.\n\nThe other two countries chosen for Xi's first trip to Europe since 2019 -- with Hungary as the final stop after Serbia -- are among the most sympathetic to Moscow in Europe.\n\nStreets in the Serbian capital were decked out with Chinese flags, along with posters and billboards that proclaimed a \"warm welcome\" to \"Chinese friends\".\n\n- NATO bombing -\n\nXi's visit also coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 US bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, which killed three people.\n\n\"Do not forget that our Chinese friends were with us 25 years ago when this country was being demolished and bombed,\" Vucic told the crowds.\n\n\"They paid a high price, they lost people only a few hundred meters from here on this very day.\"\n\nThe embassy was hit during a months-long, US-led NATO campaign targeting Serbian security forces who were at war with ethnic-Albanian insurgents in Kosovo.\n\nThe US later apologised, saying outdated maps had led the pilot to strike the wrong target.\n\nOn Tuesday, Xi wrote in the Serbian daily Politika that NATO had \"flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy\", warning that China would \"never allow such tragic history to repeat itself\".\n\nChina has long backed Serbia's territoral claims over the breakaway province of Kosovo and along with Russia has prevented its recognition at the United Nations.\n\nSerbian finance minister Sinisa Mali told state broadcaster RTS that discussions Wednesday would centre on \"a great project\" and a \"major investment from China in a very promising area.\"\n\n- Ukraine fears -\n\n\"For Serbia, this is without a doubt one of the most significant visits,\" Marko Tmusic, a political sciences professor at the University of Belgrade, told AFP.\n\n\"Standing 'shoulder to shoulder' with France -- with whom China marks 60 years of diplomatic relations -- and Hungary... is certainly a great honour\" for Serbia, he added.\n\nPeople in Belgrade welcomed Xi's visit.\n\n\"I think it's an excellent thing, this visit from the president of one of the most powerful countries in the world,\" 67-year-old Stojan Vidovic, a retiree, told AFP.\n\nIn France, Xi met with Macron and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. They urged him not to allow the export of technology that could be used by Russia in Ukraine and to do all it could to end the war.\n\nXi warned the West not to \"smear\" China over the conflict and also hit back at accusations that Chinese overcapacity was causing global trade imbalances.\n\nEurope is concerned that while officially neutral over the Ukraine conflict, China is essentially backing Russia, which is using Chinese machine tools in arms production.\n\nAfter meeting with Vucic, Xi will go later Wednesday to Hungary where China has invested heavily in vast battery and electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing plants.\n\nbur-rox/ds\n\nMore from this section\n\nMMI Webinar with MBA Focuses on Using Data, Technology to Reach 'Mortgage-Ready' Millennials Innovating Customer {"uri": "8118144335", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:28:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:28:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:27:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.eurasiareview.com/09052024-chinas-xi-arrives-in-hungary-for-orban-meeting-next-leg-of-european-charm-trip/", "title": "China's Xi Arrives In Hungary For Orban Meeting, Next Leg Of European Charm Trip", "body": "(RFE/RL) -- Chinese President Xi Jinping, fresh off an apparently successful trip to Serbia, on May 8 arrived in Hungary, where he is scheduled to meet later in the night with another authoritarian leader -- Prime Minister Viktor Orban -- and where he'll likely receive another warm welcome.\n\nChinese state television said Xi arrived in Budapest \"by special plane and began his state visit to Hungary, at the invitation of Hungarian President Tamas Sulyok and Prime Minister Viktor Orban.\"\n\nXi left Belgrade on May 8 after meeting there with Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic at a city palace where thousands of people were gathered to greet them as both men lauded their countries' friendship as \"ironclad\" and issued a joint statement to boost cooperation toward \"a common future in the new era.\"\n\nXi is on a rare, six-day European tour that already took him to France to meet with President Emmanuel Macron and EU leaders, who urged him to ease Chinese trade restrictions and to use his influence to press Russian President Vladimir Putin to end his invasion of Ukraine.\n\nXi's first trip to Europe in five years is seen as part of his drive to increase Beijing's influence on the continent's economic and political affairs.\n\nThe Sino-Serbian agreement signed by Xi and Vucic raises the level of their cooperation from strategic partnership to \"building the community of Serbia and China with a common future in the new era.\"\n\nAfter a series of bilateral meetings, Vucic called it \"the highest form of cooperation between the two countries.\"\n\nXi said their countries will \"jointly oppose hegemony and power politics\" in the interest of \"fundamental and long-term interests.\"\n\nHe called their bilateral political trust \"strong as a rock.\"\n\nVucic has promoted Chinese investment and trade and diplomatic ties for his Balkan nation of around 7 million as he has sought to balance outreach to Russia and China and the bucking of Western sanctions on Russia over the Ukraine war with his country's bid for eventual EU membership.\n\nSpeaking from a balcony of the palace, Vucic thanked Xi for visiting \"little Serbia\" and said they were \"making history today even though it doesn't seem so to many.\"\n\nXi called it a \"truly two-sided and honest friendship,\" according to Serbian state television.\n\nLike Moscow, Beijing has supported Belgrade diplomatically in its refusal to recognize former province Kosovo's independence, while Belgrade has supported China's claims to Taiwan. \"Taiwan is China,\" Vucic said on May 8, citing the UN Charter.\n\nXi's visit was seemingly timed to coincide with the 25th anniversary of NATO's bombing of the former Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in 1999, a deadly incident that has united Beijing and Belgrade in their criticism of Western intervention in the Balkans and around the world.\n\nChina has invested some $6 billion in Serbia in the past decade, putting the money into copper mines and a steel mill as well as major highway and infrastructure projects that have been criticized by some as nontransparent and overly risky deals between governments.\n\nChinese and Serbian officials were expected to sign more than 30 agreements in areas that Vucic suggested were in many cases aimed at boosting technology and innovation in Serbia.\n\nAhead of the Chinese president's arrival, Belgrade was decorated with flags of Serbia and China, and welcome messages were set up along the route from the airport to the city center in Serbian and Chinese.\n\nXi also made Serbia a stop in 2016, when he signed a free-trade agreement with Belgrade that alarmed skeptics of Chinese economic and political intentions in Europe.", That joint statement is a strategically important direction for the development of our bilateral relations, as well as our worldview,\" Vucic said at a joint press conference with Xi.\n\nThe Republic of Serbia and the People's Republic of China are progressing from strategic relations to bilateral relations, he said, adding, \"We are moving on to the community that talks about the common future of our two countries.\"\n\nAddressing Xi as a \"dear friend,\" Vucic said \"the statement on deepening and raising the comprehensive strategic partnership and building the community of Serbia and China with a common future in the new era\" is the highest level of cooperation between the two countries.\n\nVucic said that Serbia supports the principle of one China, and any question that someone would ask the People's Republic of China about it is their internal question.\n\nHe said Serbia supports the principle of one China.\n\n\"Taiwan and Hong Kong are issues for the People's Republic of China. As long as China wants to, these issues will be resolved. And it will always have the Republic of Serbia's support because that is the foundation of the United Nations charter and international public law,\" Vucic said.\n\nThe Serbian president thanked his Chinese counterpart for his unequivocal position on Kosovo and Metohija, as well as the Republic of Serbia's territorial integrity.\n\nOn Tuesday evening, Vucic and his wife Tamara Vucic welcomed Xi and his wife Peng Liyuan to Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport with a Serbian Army guard of honor.\n\nSerbian Prime Minister Milos Vucevic, Foreign Minister Marko Djuric, and Parliament Speaker Ana Brnabic were also present at the airport.\n\nXi, for his part, said Serbia will be the first European country with which Beijing will form a community with a shared future.\n\n\"We jointly announced that we will create a community between China and Serbia with a shared future in the new era, ushering in a new chapter in Chinese-Serbian relations.\n\n\"Eight years ago, Serbia became China's first Comprehensive Strategic Partner in Central and Eastern Europe. Today, Serbia is becoming the first European country where we will create a community with a shared future,\" he said.\n\nHe added that his meeting with Vucic, whom he described as an exceptional statesman, had left him deeply impressed.\n\n\"Under your leadership, Serbia maintained stability, achieved rapid economic development, and people's living conditions improved. You are an exceptional statesman with a strategic vision,\" he said.\n\nA large crowd gathered on the plateau in front of the Palace of Serbia to welcome Xi, waving Chinese and Serbian flags.\n\nVucic and Xi took a moment between the meeting to greet the citizens.\n\nMiG-29 fighters escorted Chinese leader Xi's plane in Serbian airspace.\n\nXi's first official visit in eight years coincides with the 25th anniversary of the bombing of China's Embassy in Belgrade.\n\nSerbia is one of three stops on the Chinese president's European tour, which started in France and will end in Hungary.\n\nDue to {"uri": "8118966466", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "10:41:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T10:41:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T10:40:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "http://www.bbrtv.com/2024/0509/935137.html", "title": "Xi concludes Serbia visit with elevated ties, emotional moments", "body": "Chinese President Xi Jinping arrives in Belgrade for a state visit to Serbia at the invitation of Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic, May 7, 2024. (Xinhua/Huang Jingwen)\n\nPrecious moments of goodwill and friendship are a signature of Xi's short but significant stay in Serbia, which lasts no more than 24 hours.\n\nBELGRADE, May 9 (Xinhua) -- Chinese President Xi Jinping wrapped up his state visit to Serbia on Wednesday, bundling up a multitude of deals and a strengthened bond of friendship with the country.\n\nAt the end of a fully-packed day, Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic bid farewell to Xi at the Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport, where he had welcomed the Chinese president the day before.\n\nEarlier in the day, Xi and Vucic signed a joint statement on the building of a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era, an upgrade of relations from the comprehensive strategic partnership established in 2016.\n\nThe deal makes Serbia the first European country to build such a community with China. Countries like Laos, Pakistan and Thailand have also endorsed a high-level engagement of the kind with China.\n\n\"With this agreement, Serbia is leading the way in its relations with China,\" said Ivona Ladjevac, deputy director at the Institute for International Politics and Economics in Belgrade.\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping and Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic hold talks in Belgrade, Serbia, May 8, 2024. (Xinhua/Li Xueren)\n\nAleksandar Mitic, a research fellow also with the institute said this improvement of strategic cooperation should be viewed very positively. \"It is not directed against anyone.\"\n\nSerbia has long been known as \"the gateway to the Balkans\" on the European continent. \"Everything that has been done so far and will be done in the future can serve as an example to other countries in the region and throughout Europe to get involved as much as possible,\" said Mitic. \"The principle of mutual benefit can really work.\"\n\nIn support of the building of the China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era, Xi has announced six measures when he met the press together with Vucic. Notable among the measures are a free trade agreement between China and Serbia which will take effect on July 1 and an exchange program under which Serbian youths and young Serbian scientists are invited to visit China in the next three years.\n\n\"The sky is the limit,\" said Vucic, referring to the scope of cooperation with China.\n\n\"For Serbia, it obviously brings a great deal,\" said Aleksandar Pavic, a Serbian political expert. \"The opening of the Chinese market with the Free Trade Agreement, academic exchanges ... those are very, very important.\"\n\n\"China offers a hand of cooperation on an equal footing, and offers great opportunities without conditions,\" Pavic said. \"We've grown weary of the zero-sum game for far too long.\"\n\nThe substantial deals added new testimony to the special bond of ironclad friendship enjoyed by China and Serbia.\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping attends a welcome ceremony held by Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic in Belgrade, Serbia, May 8, 2024. (Xinhua/Ding Haitao)\n\nPrecious moments of goodwill and friendship are a signature of Xi's short but significant stay in Serbia, which lasts no more than 24 hours.\n\nA telling moment was the grand welcoming ceremony held by Vucic on Wednesday morning with the impressive attendance of more than 10,000 Serbian people.\n\nCrowds were waving the national flags of both countries and chanting \"China! Serbia!\" with applause and cheers pervading the atmosphere.\n\n\"We are here to show our friendship with China, and we want our Chinese friends know that we cherish it very much,\" said Milos Tosic, a college professor present at the event. Tosic told Xinhua that it is not only his opinion, but one shared \"by all the people here today.\"\n\nAt a welcoming banquet around noon, Xi shared his nostalgic memory with Vucic, reminiscing about the Yugoslav film \"The Bridge\" and the song \"Bella Ciao,\" which have become the fondest memories in his youthful days.\n\n\"China will work together with the friendly people of Serbia and make tireless efforts to build a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era,\" Xi pledged in his concluding remarks at the banquet toast, opening up a vista for the two countries.", {"uri": "8116259758", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "21:09:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T21:09:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T21:09:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.intellinews.com/china-s-xi-jinping-arrives-in-serbia-on-anniversary-of-belgrade-embassy-bombing-324285/", "title": "China's Xi Jinping arrives in Serbia on anniversary of Belgrade embassy bombing", "body": "Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Serbia on the evening of May 7, a symbolic date that is the 25th anniversary of the accidental Nato bombing of China's embassy in Belgrade.\n\nXi is visiting Serbia as one of three stops on a tour of Europe, between his visits to France and Hungary. The two East European countries on his tour have both emerged as important allies of China in the region, and have benefited from inflows of Chinese investment.\n\nSerbian President Aleksandar Vucic personally welcomed Xi at Belgrade airport, alongside members of the government.\n\n\"With this visit, you have done a great honour to our country and people, who sincerely love China and value the friendship of your great country,\" the Serbian president said told his Chinese counterpart, according to a post on his Instagram page.\n\n\"Long live the steel friendship of Serbia and China, which was tempered in difficult times and which we will continue to preserve through mutual respect, understanding and firm support,\" added Vucic.\n\nXi commented on the \"deep traditional friendship\" between the two countries.\n\n\"Our bilateral relations have withstood the test of the changing international environment and become a fine example of interstate relations. Since the establishment of a comprehensive strategic partnership in 2016, bilateral relations have achieved historic results,\" he said, according to a statement from the Chinese embassy in Belgrade.\n\nEmbassy bombing\n\nEarlier in the day, Xi referred to the 1999 embassy bombing in an opinion piece published in the daily Politika, writing of the importance of peace as well as China's resolve to prevent such tragedies from recurring.\n\nThe bombing, during a campaign against Yugoslavia, resulted in the deaths of three Chinese journalists and injuries to twenty Chinese nationals. Then-US president Bill Clinton issued an apology in the aftermath of the incident, which sparked outrage in China.\n\nIn the comment piece, Xi also highlighted the enduring friendship between China and Serbia, forged through shared experiences and joint efforts.\n\n\"The friendship between China and Serbia which is soaked in blood that the two peoples spilled together has become a joint memory of the two peoples and will encourage both parties to make together huge steps forward,\" he wrote.\n\nWarm welcome\n\nBelgrade has been prepared to receive Xi with streets adorned with Chinese flags and placards, while thousands of police officers have been deployed to ensure security for the visiting delegation.\n\nAhead of Xi's arrival, several members of the Chinese delegation, including ministers and institutional representatives, have already arrived in Belgrade. Minister of Finance Sinisa Mali and Minister of Trade Tomislav Momirovic, greeted the Chinese delegation at Nikola Tesla airport.\n\nDuring his stay in Serbia, Xi is expected to engage in talks on China's investments in the country and potential new agreements with his Serbian counterpart Vucic.\n\nThe relationship between China and Serbia has seen several advances in recent years. In 2016, the two countries signed a strategic partnership, and last year witnessed the signing of 18 agreements during Vucic's visit to Beijing. These agreements included a free trade deal set to become operational in July, reflecting the deepening economic ties between the two nations.\n\nXi said he expected discussions with Serbian leaders to further strengthen bilateral cooperation.\n\nTrade and infrastructure\n\nSerbia's alignment with China's Belt and Road Initiative has cemented its position as a key partner for China in Europe. Chinese investments in Serbia have contributed significantly to infrastructure development, with projects spanning mines, factories, roads and bridges.\n\nChina is currently Serbia's second most important economic partner following the EU. China was also the top foreign investor in Serbia in 2023, accounting for \u20ac1.37bn of the total \u20ac4.5bn.\n\nChinese companies have played an important role in Serbia's industrial sector, and are among the country's top exporters. Specifically, Serbia's top exporters were dominated by three Chinese-owned companies in 2023: Zijin Mining, Zijin Copper and the HBIS Group.\n\nOther recent collaborations include the establishment of yuan clearing arrangements and the inauguration of a new freight route linking China's Hebei province with Belgrade.\n\nXi's visit coincides with the installation of Serbia's new government, led by former defence minister Milos Vucevic.", "source": {"uri": "intellinews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Intellinews                        "}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118479795", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:56:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:56:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:56:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.euractiv.com/section/enlargement/news/eu-candidate-serbia-and-china-chart-shared-future/", "title": "EU candidate Serbia and China chart 'shared future'", "body": "China and Serbia on Wednesday (8 May) agreed to follow a \"shared future\" as President Xi Jinping visited the Balkan country as part of his bid to forge stronger relations with allies at the edge of the European Union.\n\nXi is on his first European tour in five years, and the trip was seen as an effort to strengthen ties with eastern European countries that are pro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment. He will fly to Hungary later in the day.\n\n\"We are writing history today,\" Serbian President Aleksandar Vu\u010di\u0107 told a large crowd that had gathered in front of the Serbian presidential palace to welcome Xi, applauding and chanting \"China, China\".\n\nThe two countries signed 29 agreements promoting legal, regulatory and economic cooperation. Serbia will also become the first European country in years to enter into a free trade agreement with China when a deal signed last year comes into effect on 1 July.\n\nVu\u010di\u0107 said that since 2020 China had been the single-largest investor in Serbia, and that its investment was up 30-fold over the past decade. The free trade deal will guarantee tariff-free exports for 95% of Serbian products to China over the next five to 10 years, he said.\n\nXi said that China was ready to import more high-quality agricultural products from Serbia and would welcome more direct flights between Belgrade and Chinese cities.\n\nBoth leaders boast of an ironclad partnership. Along with Hungary, Serbia is Europe's firmest supporter of China's huge Belt and Road infrastructure project across parts of Asia and Europe.\n\n\"Serbia became China's first strategic partner in central and eastern Europe eight years ago, and it becomes the first European country with which we shall build a community with shared future,\" Xi said.\n\nThe two leaders said they would support each other's sovereignty and territorial integrity, meaning that Serbia considers Taiwan, viewed by Beijing as a breakaway province, to be part of China, just as China considers Kosovo, which declared independence in 2008, as part of Serbia.\n\n\"We shall jointly confront hegemony and the politics of power,\" Xi said.\n\nXi\u00b4s visit comes on the anniversary of the 1999 NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during a campaign against the former Yugoslavia to force late Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.\n\nNATO said the bombing, which killed three Chinese journalists and wounded 20 Chinese nationals, was accidental. It prompted outrage in China and an apology from then US President Bill Clinton.\n\n\"The Chinese people appreciate the peace but will never allow that a historic tragedy repeats itself,\" Xi said in an opinion article in the daily Politika on Tuesday.\n\nVu\u010di\u0107 said the two countries had agreed to establish an inter-governmental technology committee that would enable Serbia to get access to the latest technologies and use of artificial intelligence.\n\nChina owns mines and factories across Serbia and has lent billions for roads, bridges and new facilities, becoming Serbia's key partner in much-needed infrastructure development.\n\nXi left France on Tuesday after a two-day trip during which he offered no major concessions on trade or foreign policy, even as President Emmanuel That joint statement is a strategically important direction for the development of our bilateral relations, as well as our worldview,\" Vucic said at a joint press conference with Xi.\n\nThe Republic of Serbia and the People's Republic of China are progressing from strategic relations to bilateral relations, he said, adding, \"We are moving on to the community that talks about the common future of our two countries.\"\n\nAddressing Xi as a \"dear friend,\" Vucic said \"the statement on deepening and raising the comprehensive strategic partnership and building the community of Serbia and China with a common future in the new era\" is the highest level of cooperation between the two countries.\n\nVucic said that Serbia supports the principle of one China, and any question that someone would ask the People's Republic of China about it is their internal question.\n\nHe said Serbia supports the principle of one China.\n\n\"Taiwan and Hong Kong are issues for the People's Republic of China. As long as China wants to, these issues will be resolved. And it will always have the Republic of Serbia's support because that is the foundation of the United Nations charter and international public law,\" Vucic said.\n\nThe Serbian president thanked his Chinese counterpart for his unequivocal position on Kosovo and Metohija, as well as the Republic of Serbia's territorial integrity.\n\nOn Tuesday evening, Vucic and his wife Tamara Vucic welcomed Xi and his wife Peng Liyuan to Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport with a Serbian Army guard of honor.\n\nSerbian Prime Minister Milos Vucevic, Foreign Minister Marko Djuric, and Parliament Speaker Ana Brnabic were also present at the airport.\n\nXi, for his part, said Serbia will be the first European country with which Beijing will form a community with a shared future.\n\n\"We jointly announced that we will create a community between China and Serbia with a shared future in the new era, ushering in a new chapter in Chinese-Serbian relations.\n\n\"Eight years ago, Serbia became China's first Comprehensive Strategic Partner in Central and Eastern Europe. Today, Serbia is becoming the first European country where we will create a community with a shared future,\" he said.\n\nHe added that his meeting with Vucic, whom he described as an exceptional statesman, had left him deeply impressed.\n\n\"Under your leadership, Serbia maintained stability, achieved rapid economic development, and people's living conditions improved. You are an exceptional statesman with a strategic vision,\" he said.\n\nA large crowd gathered on the plateau in front of the Palace of Serbia to welcome Xi, waving Chinese and Serbian flags.\n\nVucic and Xi took a moment between the meeting to greet the citizens.\n\nMiG-29 fighters escorted Chinese leader Xi's plane in Serbian airspace.\n\nXi's first official visit in eight years coincides with the 25th anniversary of the bombing of China's Embassy in Belgrade.\n\nSerbia is one of three stops on the Chinese president's European tour, which started in France and will end in Hungary.\n\nDue to {"uri": "8119123578", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "12:24:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T12:24:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T12:22:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2692027/", "title": "Xi Jinping welcomes new chapter in China-Serbia relations as Belgrade supports his global vision - ExBulletin", "body": "The two leaders were greeted by a crowd of around 20,000 flag-waving people and shouts from Serbia! China! in front of the Serbian Palace, a major government complex in the center of the capital.\n\nXi told Vucic that Beijing is willing to continue the all-weather friendship between the two countries, jointly safeguard the fundamental and long-term interests of the two countries, and pursue national development and national rejuvenation side by side, according to Chinese state television channel CCTV. .\n\nLater, Xi said at a joint press conference: We agreed to guide and direct the construction of a China-Serbia community with a shared future for the new era by strengthening strategic communication.\n\nMore than a decade ago, Xi first announced his concept of a community with a shared future, often seen as a challenge to the current US-led world order.\n\nAt its core is the vision of a new type of international relations and global governance characterized by mutual respect, common security and peaceful development.\n\nEight years ago, Serbia became China's first comprehensive strategic partner in the Central and Eastern European region, and today Serbia is the first European country to build a community with a shared future with China, fully reflecting the strategic, special and high level of Sino-Serbian relations. , Xi added.\n\nChina, like Russia, Serbia and dozens of other countries, does not recognize Kosovo's 2008 declaration of independence.\n\nIn return, Serbia does not recognize Taiwan's independence and Vucic said at the press conference that his country supports the one-China principle and views the Taiwan issue as an internal issue of China.\n\nThey also pledged to support each other on territorial issues when they met earlier today.\n\nXi said the two countries were also committed to deepening economic relations in traditional strong areas such as transportation and energy infrastructure, while also extending them to innovation cooperation.\n\nHe also said Beijing welcomed the decision to open a direct air route between Belgrade and Shanghai and supported plans for another route linking the Serbian capital to Guangzhou.\n\nThe free trade agreement signed last year by the two countries, which will give Serbian companies access to the vast Chinese market, is expected to come into force in early July.\n\nVucic said the deal would secure the country's future, adding that China's previous experiences could provide a roadmap for Serbia's future trajectory.\n\nIn 2022, China became Serbia's largest source of foreign direct investment and the second largest trading partner after the EU, according to China's official Xinhua News Agency.\n\nTrade between the two countries fell from US$596 million in 2016 to US$4.35 billion last year.\n\nIn recent years, Beijing has invested considerable sums in Serbia, investing in numerous factories and mines, providing billions in loans to build roads and financing the development of a railway line between Belgrade and Budapest.\n\nXi's arrival in Belgrade on Tuesday, after his two-day visit to France, coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade during the NATO campaign in Kosovo.\n\nThe United States has apologized for the incident, insisting it was an error caused by the use of outdated maps, but it remains a sore point in China.\n\nXi did not visit the site of the former Chinese embassy in Belgrade, although it was to be on his itinerary.\n\nThere were no road closures or significant increased security at the site of the former Chinese embassy on Wednesday, except for a few police stationed along nearby roads, as downtown Belgrade was booked for Xi's visit.\n\nA group of Chinese tourists visited the site around mid-afternoon.\n\nAnother group of overseas Chinese, wearing red caps, began a vigil of sorts at the site on Tuesday, but their numbers dwindled as Xi's departure drew closer on Wednesday.\n\nA young Chinese couple working in Belgrade waited there at noon, expecting to see Xi or his wife Peng Liyuan, but left around 1 p.m. after waiting more than an hour.\n\nThe Chinese Cultural Center, built on the site, also showed no sign of a groundbreaking ceremony, with only an electronic screen in the reception area of its office building showing a poster warmly announcing President Xi's visit in Serbia and some local Chinese. language newspapers reporting on Xi's European tour on a desk.\n\nFlowers placed at the monument to honor the victims were presented by Chinese state-owned companies operating in Serbia, including Shandong Hi-Speed, which invested in the Chinese Cultural Center, and China Energy Engineering Corporation.\n\nIn an opinion piece published Tuesday in Serbia's oldest daily Politika, Xi wrote: \"The Chinese people cherish peace, but we will never allow such a tragic history to repeat itself.\"\n\nThe China-Serbia friendship, forged with the blood of our compatriots, will remain in the collective memory of the Chinese and Serbian people and inspire us to make significant progress together.\n\nXi was due to travel to Hungary, the final stop of his European tour, later on Wednesday, before returning to China on Friday.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8117428779", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "13:07:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T13:07:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:06:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/china,-serbia-chart-'shared-future'-as-xi-jinping-visits-europe/77087811", "title": "China, Serbia chart 'shared future' as Xi Jinping visits Europe", "body": "BELGRADE (Reuters) -China and Serbia on Wednesday agreed to follow a \"shared future\" as President Xi Jinping visited the Balkan country, part of his bid to forge stronger relations with allies at the edge of the European Union.\n\nXi\u00b4s visit is part of his first European tour in five years, and is seen as an effort to strengthen ties with eastern European countries that are pro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment. He will fly to Hungary later in the day.\n\n\"We are writing history today,\" Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic told a large crowd that had gathered in front of the Serbian presidential palace to welcome Xi, applauding and chanting \"China, China\".\n\nThe two countries signed 29 agreements promoting legal, regulatory and economic cooperation, with Serbia becoming the first European country to sign a free trade agreement with China in years.\n\nVucic said that since 2020 China had been the single-largest investor in Serbia, and that its investment was up 30-fold over the past decade. The free trade deal that should become operational in July will guarantee tariff-free exports for 95% of Serbian products to China over the next five to 10 years, he said.\n\nBoth leaders boast of an ironclad partnership. Along with Hungary, Serbia is Europe's firmest supporter of China's huge Belt and Road infrastructure project across parts of Asia and Europe.\n\n\"Serbia became China\u00b4s first strategic partner in central and eastern Europe eight years ago, and it becomes the first European country with which we shall build a community with shared future,\" Xi said.\n\nBoth leaders said they would support each other's sovereignty and territorial integrity, meaning that Serbia considers Taiwan, viewed by Beijing as a breakaway province, to be part of China, just as China considers Kosovo, which declared independence in 2008, as part of Serbia.\n\n\"We shall jointly confront hegemony and the politics of power,\" Xi said.\n\nSYMBOLISM OF THE VISIT\n\nXi\u00b4s visit comes on the anniversary of the 1999 NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during a campaign against the former Yugoslavia to force late Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.\n\nThe bombing, which killed three Chinese journalists and wounded 20 Chinese nationals, prompted outrage in China and an apology from then U.S. President Bill Clinton.\n\n\"The Chinese people appreciate the peace but will never allow that a historic tragedy repeats itself,\" Xi said in an opinion article in the daily Politika on Tuesday.\n\nVucic said the two countries had agreed to establish an inter-governmental technology committee that would enable Serbia to get access to the latest technologies and use of artificial intelligence.\n\nChina owns mines and factories across Serbia and has lent billions for roads, bridges and new facilities, becoming Serbia's key partner in much-needed infrastructure development.\n\nXi left France on Tuesday after a two-day trip during which he offered no major concessions on trade or foreign policy, even as President Emmanuel Macron pressed him on market access and Ukraine.\n\n(Writing by by Daria Sito-Sucic in Sarajevo; Editing by Chinese President Xi Jinping is due to land in Serbia on Tuesday on the 25th anniversary of the accidental NATO bombing of China's Embassy in which three Chinese journalists were killed, the second stop of his first European tour in five years.\n\nTwenty Chinese nationals were wounded in the 1999 NATO attack, which prompted outrage in China and an apology from then U.S. President Bill Clinton.\n\nThe embassy was hit during a campaign against the then Yugoslavia to force late Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.\n\n\"The Chinese people appreciate the peace but will never allow that a historic tragedy repeats itself,\" Xi said in an opinion article in the daily Politika on Tuesday.\n\n\"The friendship between China and Serbia which is soaked in blood that the two peoples spilled together has become a joint memory of the two peoples and will encourage both parties to make together huge steps forward,\" Xi said.\n\nThe streets of Belgrade were decorated with Chinese flags and placards as thousands of police officers were deployed to secure Xi and his 400-member entourage.\n\nIRONCLAD FRIENDSHIP\n\nXi is visiting Serbia after France, where President Emmanuel Macron and EU Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen pressed him to ensure more balanced trade with Europe and use his influence on Russia to end the war in Ukraine.\n\nXi is expected to discuss China\u00b4s multi-billion investment in Serbia and possible new deals.\n\nDuring his first visit to Belgrade in 2016, the two countries signed a strategic partnership. Last year, Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic signed 18 agreements with Xi in Beijing, including a free trade deal that should become operational in July.\n\nThe two leaders talk about an ironclad partnership between their countries. Along with Hungary, which is Xi\u00b4s next stop, Serbia is Europe's firmest supporter of the China's Belt and Road Initiative.\n\nChina runs mines and factories across Serbia and has lent billions for roads, bridges and new facilities, becoming its key partner in much-needed infrastructure development.\n\nObservers say Xi's choice of Serbia and Hungary is designed to pull closer two European countries that arepro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment. Serbia's Western partners view the country as a Chinese hub at the gateway to the EU.\n\nIn 2023, China was Serbia's second-largest trading partner after the EU with a total trade exchange of $6.1 {"uri": "8118995974", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "11:01:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T11:01:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T11:00:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://english.news.cn/20240509/c6b0007fcd044acf96db287035105cb7/c.html", "title": "Xinhua Headlines: Xi concludes Serbia visit with elevated ties, deepened friendship and promising cooperation", "body": "BELGRADE, May 9 (Xinhua) -- Chinese President Xi Jinping wrapped up his state visit to Serbia on Wednesday, bundling up a multitude of deals and a strengthened bond of friendship with the country.\n\nAt the end of a fully-packed day, Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic bid farewell to Xi at the Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport, where he had welcomed the Chinese president the day before.\n\nEarlier in the day, Xi and Vucic signed a joint statement on the building of a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era, an upgrade of relations from the comprehensive strategic partnership established in 2016.\n\nThe deal, which was declared by Xi and Vucic during their meeting in the Serbian capital, makes Serbia the first European country to build such a community with China.\n\nOver the past few years, Xi said, the bilateral relationship has leapfrogged with historic progress, and since the establishment of a comprehensive strategic partnership in 2016, in particular, the bilateral relationship has been enriched in substance and expanded in scope, which has become an example for China's friendly relations with other European countries.\n\nSerbia is China's first comprehensive strategic partner in Central and Eastern Europe, Xi said, adding that under the new circumstances, Serbia has become the first European country to build with China a community with a shared future, which speaks volumes about the strategic, special and high-level China-Serbia relations.\n\n\"With this agreement, Serbia is leading the way in its relations with China,\" said Ivona Ladjevac, deputy director at the Institute for International Politics and Economics in Belgrade.\n\nThe announcement on deepening and elevating the comprehensive strategic partnership and building a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era marks a new milestone in the history of this bilateral relationship, said Vucic.\n\nThe strategic, practical, and innovative nature of promoting bilateral relations will set a benchmark and model for cooperation between the East and the West, Chen Fengying, a researcher at the China Institutes of Contemporary International Relations, told Xinhua in a recent interview.\n\nThe ironclad friendship between China and Serbia has stood the test of the changing international landscape, Xi said, noting that such friendship is characterized by profound historical roots, solid political foundation, extensive common interests and strong popular support.\n\nIn a signed article published Tuesday in Politika, a Belgrade-based Serbian daily, Xi wrote that the ironclad friendship between the two countries is ever-growing. \"Whatever changes in the international landscape, China and Serbia remain true friends and good partners,\" he wrote.\n\nThe Chinese president's arrival coincides with the 25th anniversary of the NATO bombing of the Chinese embassy in the former Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.\n\nIn 1999, the U.S.-led NATO forces carried out savage airstrikes for 78 days against Yugoslavia, leaving more than 8,000 civilians dead or injured and nearly 1 million more displaced. On the night of May 7, exactly 25 years ago, NATO bombed the Chinese embassy, killing three Chinese journalists, including one from Xinhua.\n\n\"The Chinese people cherish peace, but we will never allow such tragic history to repeat itself,\" Xi wrote in the article. \"The China-Serbia friendship, forged with the blood of our compatriots, will stay in the shared memory of the Chinese and Serbian peoples, and will inspire us to march forward with big strides.\"\n\nGordana, a local resident who didn't reveal her full name, referred to the bombing as a \"painful memory\" to her. \"The cooperation between China and Serbia holds the promise of providing my children with a better life than I experienced,\" she told Xinhua.\n\nPrecious moments of goodwill and friendship are a signature of Xi's short but significant stay in Serbia, which lasts no more than 24 hours.\n\nA telling moment was the grand welcoming ceremony held by Vucic on Wednesday morning with the impressive attendance of more than 10,000 Serbian people.\n\nCrowds were waving the national flags of both countries and chanting \"China! Serbia!\" with applause and cheers pervading the atmosphere.\n\n\"We are here to show our friendship with China, and we want our Chinese friends know that we cherish it very much,\" said Milos Tosic, a college professor present at the event. Tosic told Xinhua that it is not only his opinion, but one shared \"by all the people here today.\"\n\nAt a welcoming banquet around noon, Xi shared his nostalgic memory with Vucic, reminiscing about the Yugoslav film \"The Bridge\" and the song \"Bella Ciao,\" which have become the fondest memories in his youthful days.\n\n\"China will work together with the friendly people of Serbia and make tireless efforts to build a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era,\" Xi pledged in his concluding remarks at the banquet toast.\n\nDuring the meeting with Vucic, Xi said the China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era is an upgrade of the ironclad friendship between China and Serbia, and it also represents their common values and objectives, namely, joint pursuit of development, win-win cooperation and mutual success.\n\nIn support of the building of the China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era, Xi has announced six measures when he met the press together with Vucic. Notable among the measures are a free trade agreement between China and Serbia which will take effect on July 1 and an exchange program under which Serbian youths and young Serbian scientists are invited to visit China in the next three years.\n\n\"The sky is the limit,\" said Vucic, referring to the scope of cooperation with China.\n\n\"For Serbia, it obviously brings a great deal,\" said Aleksandar Pavic, a Serbian political expert. \"The opening of the Chinese market with the Free Trade Agreement, academic exchanges ... those are very, very important.\"\n\n\"China offers a hand of cooperation on an equal footing, and offers great opportunities without conditions,\" Pavic said. \"We've grown weary of the zero-sum game for far too long.\"\n\nThe substantial deals added new testimony to the special bond of ironclad friendship enjoyed by China and Serbia.\n\nPast years have seen leapfrog growth of China-Serbia cooperation. Two-way trade in 2023 surged to 4.35 billion U.S. dollars, Chinese customs statistics showed. In 2022, China became the largest source of direct investment for Serbia. After the bilateral free trade deal takes effect, more than 60 percent of taxable items will become tariff-free immediately, and the final import volume proportion of both sides with zero-tariff items will reach about 95 percent.\n\nUnder the framework of the China-proposed Belt and Road Initiative are flagship projects such as the Smederevo Steelworks and the high-speed railway between Belgrade and Budapest. An integral segment of the Belgrade-Budapest railway is the high-speed train linking Belgrade and Serbia's second-largest city Novi Sad, which has transported some 6.83 million passengers over the past two years.\n\nSerbia has long been known as \"the gateway to the Balkans\" on the European continent. \"Everything that has been done so far and will be done in the future can serve as an example to other countries in the region and throughout Europe to get involved as much as possible,\" said Aleksandar Mitic, a research fellow also with the institute.\n\n\"The principle of mutual benefit can really work,\" said Mitic.\n\nSerbia, undoubtedly, stands as a reliable partner for China in Europe, said Aleksandar Vojvodic, head engineer of the Clean Serbia Project of China Road and Bridge Corporation.\n\nThere will be a promising prospect for further enhancement and expansion of existing cooperation, said Vojvodic. \u25a0", "source": {"uri": "english.news.cn", "dataType": "news",
