{"uri": "2024-05-348831799", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "10:14:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T10:14:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T09:42:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/chinas-xi-serbia-talks-boost-economic-ties-1847958", "title": "China's Xi In Serbia For Talks To Boost Economic Ties", "body": "Serbia's President Aleksandar Vucic reaffirmed his strong support for China's sovereignty over Taiwan as he gave a lavish welcome to President Xi Jinping who is seeking to deepen political and economic ties with friendlier countries in Europe.\n\nChina has poured billions into Serbia and neighbouring Balkan countries, particularly into mining and manufacturing, and last year Beijing and Belgrade signed a free trade agreement.\n\nXi and his wife Peng Liyuan were greeted by Vucic on a red carpet outside the main government offices in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nThe Chinese leader was met by a gun salute and the Chinese national anthem, as helicopters whirred overhead, before shaking hands with officials including the prime minister and the National Bank of Serbia governor.\n\nThe two leaders waved from a balcony to a crowd of several thousand waiting outside, pictures from state broadcaster RTS showed, some waving Chinese flags.\n\nVucic welcomed Xi and called him a \"friend of Serbia\".\n\n\"Such respect and love as he will find here in our Serbia, he will not find anywhere else,\" Vucic added.\n\nHe told the crowd as Xi applauded: \"We have a clear and simple position regarding Chinese territorial integrity. Yes, Taiwan is China\". China has stepped up diplomatic pressure on the island that it has claimed for decades.\n\nThe Chinese president arrived in Belgrade on Tuesday from a state visit to France that saw sometimes robust exchanges with President Emmanuel Macron on trade and China's close ties to Russia despite the Ukraine war.\n\nThe other two countries chosen for Xi's first trip to Europe since 2019 -- with Hungary as the final stop after Serbia -- are among the most sympathetic to Moscow in Europe.\n\nSerbian finance minister Sinisa Mali told state broadcaster RTS that discussions Wednesday would centre on \"a great project\".\n\n\"We are aiming to attract a major investment from China in a very promising area,\" he said, adding \"I won't reveal our cards at this moment.\"\n\nStreets in the Serbian capital were decked out with Chinese flags, along with posters and billboards that proclaimed a \"warm welcome\" to \"Chinese friends\".\n\nXi's visit also coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 US bombing of the Chinese embassy there, which killed three people.\n\n\"Do not forget that our Chinese friends were with us 25 years ago when this country was being demolished and bombed,\" Vucic told the crowds.\n\n\"They paid a high price, they lost people only a few hundred meters from here on this very day.\"\n\nThe embassy was hit during a months-long, US-led NATO campaign targeting Serbian security forces who were at war with ethnic-Albanian insurgents in Kosovo.\n\nThe US later apologised, saying outdated maps had led the pilot to strike the wrong target.\n\nOn Tuesday, Xi wrote in Serbian daily Politika that NATO had \"flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy in Yugoslavia\", warning that China would \"never allow such tragic history to repeat itself\".\n\nChina has long backed Serbia's territoral claims over the breakaway province of Kosovo and along with Russia has prevented its recognition at the United Nations.\n\nHe also hailed the \"ironclad friendship\" between China and Serbia, which he said was \"forged with the blood of our compatriots\".\n\nStefan Vladisavljev, programme director at the Foundation BFPE for a Responsible Society, said that the date of the visit gave it \"significant symbolic importance\".\n\nPeople in Belgrade welcomed Xi's visit.\n\n\"I think it's an excellent thing, this visit from the president of one of the most powerful countries in the world,\" 67-year-old Stojan Vidovic, a retiree, told AFP.\n\n\"It's fantastic for us,\" agreed 69-year-old Dijana Radic, a former translator. She said she hoped there would be \"results from this visit, something good for both parties\".\n\nIn France, Xi met with Macron and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. They urged him not to allow the export of technology that could be used by Russia in Ukraine and to do all it could to end the war.\n\nEurope is concerned that while officially neutral over the Ukraine conflict, China is essentially backing Russia, which is using Chinese machine tools in arms production.\n\nAfter meeting with Vucic, Xi will go later Wednesday to Hungary where China has invested heavily in vast battery and electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing plants.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business Times AU"}, "authors": "eng-9543499", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.3803921568627451, "wgt": 197, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8118228066", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "00:11:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T00:11:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T00:08:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://english.news.cn/europe/20240509/b206f487fabc4bec89e7f9d559feb323/c.html", "title": "China, Serbia decide to build community with shared future", "body": "Chinese President Xi Jinping and Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic hold talks in Belgrade, Serbia, May 8, 2024. (Xinhua/Li Xueren)\n\nBELGRADE, May 8 (Xinhua) -- China and Serbia have decided on Wednesday to build a community with a shared future, an upgrade of their relations from the comprehensive strategic partnership established eight years ago.\n\nThe decision was declared by visiting Chinese President Xi Jinping and his Serbian counterpart, Aleksandar Vucic, during their meeting in the Serbian capital.\n\nXi stressed that the ironclad friendship between China and Serbia has stood the test of the changing international landscape, saying that such friendship is characterized by profound historical roots, solid political foundation, extensive common interests and strong popular support.\n\nOver the past few years, Xi said, under the leadership of him and Vucic, the bilateral relationship has leapfrogged with historic progress, and since the establishment of a comprehensive strategic partnership in 2016, in particular, the bilateral relationship has been enriched in substance and expanded in scope, which has become an example for China's friendly relations with other European countries.\n\nActions speak louder than words, Xi noted. He said China will stand shoulder to shoulder with Serbia, share weal and woe like passengers in the same boat, carry forward the spirit of the ironclad friendship, maintain and grow their friendship, and jointly safeguard fundamental and long-term interests of the two countries.\n\nAs the two sides pursue their respective national development and revitalization, China will join hands with Serbia to advance the building of a community with a shared future in the new era, he added.\n\nXi stressed that Serbia is China's first comprehensive strategic partner in Central and Eastern Europe, saying that their bilateral cooperation has injected strong impetus into their respective development and rejuvenation, and brought tangible benefits to the two peoples.\n\nUnder the new circumstances, Serbia has become the first European country to build with China a community with a shared future, which speaks volumes about the strategic, special and high-level China-Serbia relations, he said.\n\nThe China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era, Xi said, is an upgrade of the ironclad friendship between China and Serbia, adding that it also represents their common values and objectives, namely, joint pursuit of development, win-win cooperation and mutual success.\n\nThese are the common aspirations of China, Serbia, and all countries that are committed to independence, peace and development, he added.\n\nBy building a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era, the two sides should keep deepening and expanding high-quality Belt and Road cooperation and collaboration between China and Central and Eastern European countries, thus contributing to their respective modernization, Xi said.\n\nThe Chinese leader called on the two sides to highlight the strategic nature of the bilateral relationship and keep to its general direction, saying that China supports Serbia in upholding independence and pursuing a development path suited to its national conditions, and supports its efforts in safeguarding national sovereignty and territorial integrity.\n\nThe two sides, Xi said, should continue to offer each other firm support, deepen strategic cooperation, and safeguard their respective political security and fundamental interests.\n\nHe urged China and Serbia to stay committed to practical cooperation and deliver welfare for the two peoples, saying that high-quality Belt and Road cooperation between China and Serbia has achieved remarkable results.\n\nThe two sides should steadily advance cooperation in traditional areas such as transportation and energy infrastructure, make sure the entire Serbian section of the Belgrade-Budapest railway go into operation as scheduled, jointly operate well their major cooperation projects, create more small and beautiful livelihood projects, and continue to generate positive economic and social impacts, he said.\n\nWith the China-Serbia Free Trade Agreement set to take effect on July 1 this year, the high-standard mutual opening up between China and Serbia will surely enter a new stage, Xi said, adding that China will continue to import more high-quality agricultural specialties from Serbia.\n\nThe Chinese side will invite 300 young Serbians to China on study and exchange programs in the next three years, said Xi, adding that China welcomes the opening of direct flights from Belgrade to Shanghai by the Serbian side so as to comprehensively deepen people-to-people exchanges.\n\nXi also called for opening up new prospects of cooperation with a focus on the innovation dimension in bilateral relations and making innovation cooperation a new growth driver in the relationship.\n\nChina will support 50 young Serbian scientists in taking part in scientific research exchanges in China in the next three years, Xi said, adding that China is ready to work with Serbia to strengthen cooperation on artificial intelligence (AI) and endeavor to ensure humanity properly develop and utilize AI.\n\nIt is important for China and Serbia to jointly reject hegemonism and power politics, and oppose bloc politics or bloc confrontation, Xi said, adding that the two sides should join hands to uphold the purposes and principles of the UN Charter, practice true multilateralism, and promote international fairness and justice.\n\nFor his part, Vucic extended the warmest welcome to Xi and noted that China is Serbia's most sincere friend.\n\nAlthough Serbia is a small country, China always fully respects its sovereignty and territorial integrity, and provides valuable support for its economic and social development, he said.\n\nVucic hailed Xi as a great world leader. He said that under Xi's strong leadership, China has made remarkable achievements, and it has become a beacon of development and progress of the world and is playing an increasingly important leading role in international affairs.\n\nThe Communist Party of China seeks to enhance the well-being of not only the Chinese people, but also people across the world, he said, adding that the Serbian people are full of gratitude and respect for China, especially for President Xi, and feel truly proud to be an ironclad friend to such a great nation.\n\nSerbia firmly supports China's legitimate position on issues concerning its core interests including on Taiwan, he said, adding that there is but one China in the world, and that Serbia will, without hesitation, continue to unswervingly provide China with firm support.\n\nVucic noted that China's investment in and cooperation with Serbia have greatly facilitated the latter's economic and social development and improved Serbian people's living standards, saying that since 2016, in particular, thanks to the personal commitment and support by Xi, the HBIS Smederevo steel plant has had immensely positive socioeconomic impacts.\n\nThe transformative changes in the steel plant's development prospects have also boosted the confidence and raised the hope of the people, he added.\n\nSerbia's future is closely linked with China, he said, adding that Serbia looks forward to intensifying exchanges with China in all areas and at all levels, and to strengthening cooperation with China in various fields including infrastructure, new energy, innovation, artificial intelligence and people-to-people and cultural exchanges.\n\nSerbia will actively advance high-quality Belt and Road cooperation with China, and work to ensure that the Serbian sector of the Belgrade-Budapest railway will be completed as planned, he said.\n\nVucic said Serbia welcomes investment cooperation from more Chinese businesses and looks forward to opening more direct flights, adding that building on the entry-into-force of the bilateral Free Trade Agreement, Serbia is ready to expand economic and trade cooperation with China.\n\nThe announcement on deepening and elevating the comprehensive strategic partnership and building a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era marks a new milestone in the history of this bilateral relationship, he noted.\n\nSerbia firmly supports and will actively participate in the Global Development Initiative, the Global Security Initiative and the Global Civilization Initiative put forth by Xi, he said, adding that his country will stay in close strategic coordination with China in multilateral fora, jointly oppose hegemonism and power politics, uphold the purposes of the UN Charter, and defend international fairness and justice.\n\nAfter the talks, the two presidents signed the Joint Statement on Deepening and Elevating the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership and Building a China-Serbia Community with a Shared Future in the New Era. They also witnessed the exchange of multiple cooperation documents including on Belt and Road cooperation, green development, digital economy, e-commerce, infrastructure, economic and technical cooperation, information and communication, agri-food, and the media. Xi and Vucic also had a joint meeting with the press.\n\nPrior to their meeting, Vucic accompanied Xi to the platform of the Palace of Serbia. On the square in front of the Palace, some 15,000 Serbian people were waving national flags of China and Serbia to express the warmest welcome to Xi. The Chinese leader waved to the crowd, which burst into jubilant, prolonged applause and cheers.\n\nLater in his meeting with Vucic, Xi said that he was deeply touched when he was greeted at the airport by President Vucic together with many senior government officials who held a grand welcoming ceremony for his visit.\n\nHe also said he was deeply moved by the genuine friendliness toward China from the Serbian people who are good friends of the Chinese people. \u25a0\n\nIn this combo photo, Chinese President Xi Jinping, accompanied by Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic prior to their talks, is greeted by thousands of Serbians in Belgrade, Serbia, on May 8, 2024. Xi and Vucic on Wednesday held talks here. (Xinhua/Huang Jingwen, Ding Haitao)\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping attends a welcome ceremony held by Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic prior to their talks in Belgrade, Serbia, May 8, 2024. In the joint statement, the two countries decided to deepen and elevate the China-Serbia comprehensive strategic partnership. (Xinhua/Li Xueren)\n\nBELGRADE, May 8 (Xinhua) -- China and Serbia have decided on Wednesday to build a community with a shared future, an upgrade of their relations from the comprehensive strategic partnership established eight years ago.\n\nThe decision was declared by visiting Chinese President Xi Jinping and his Serbian counterpart, Aleksandar Vucic, during their meeting in the Serbian capital.\n\nXi said the ironclad China-Serbia friendship has stood the test of changing international situation, and enjoys a firm political foundation that boasts profound history, as well as solid public support with extensive common interests.\n\nIn recent years, Xi said he and Vucic have jointly led the leapfrog development of bilateral relations and made historic achievements.\n\nIn particular, since the comprehensive strategic partnership between China and Serbia was established in 2016, bilateral relations have grown richer in connotation, and continuously expanded in scope, becoming a model of friendly relations between China and European countries, he said.\n\nActions speak louder than words, Xi noted. He said the Chinese side is willing to work with Serbia to continue to stand together through thick and thin, share a common future, and uphold the spirit of the two countries' ironclad friendship.\n\nChina is also ready to join Serbia to maintain and develop the amity of the two countries, jointly safeguard the fundamental and long-term interests of both sides, pursue development and rejuvenation of their own country, and jointly advance the building of a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era, he said.\n\nXi stressed that Serbia is China's first comprehensive strategic partner in Central and Eastern Europe. Cooperation between the two sides has injected strong impetus into the two countries' respective development and revitalization, delivering tangible benefits to the two peoples, he said.\n\nUnder the new circumstances, Serbia has become the first European country to build a community with a shared future with China, which fully demonstrates the strategic, special and high-level nature of the bilateral relationship, he said.\n\nThe building of the China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era is an elevation of the two countries' ironclad friendship, and it also represents the shared values and goals of both sides, namely, seeking common development, achieving win-win cooperation and pursuing common progress, which is the shared vision of both countries and nations worldwide that uphold independence and strive for peace and development, Xi said.\n\nXi said that the two sides should deepen and expand high-quality Belt and Road cooperation and the cooperation between China and Central and Eastern European Countries by building a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era, thereby advancing the modernization of their respective nation.\n\nHe called on both sides to underscore the strategic significance of the bilateral ties, and grasp the overarching direction of the relationship. China supports Serbia in upholding independence and pursuing a development path suited to its national conditions, and also supports Serbia's efforts to safeguard its national sovereignty and territorial integrity, Xi said.\n\nThe two sides should continue to firmly support each other, deepen strategic cooperation, and safeguard their respective political security and fundamental interests, he added.\n\nXi also urged the two countries to adhere to the practical nature of bilateral cooperation and bring benefits to the two peoples. High-quality Belt and Road cooperation between the two countries has yielded fruitful results, Xi noted.\n\nBoth sides, Xi said, should steadily promote cooperation in traditional areas like transportation and energy infrastructure, such as ensuring the timely completion of the entire Belgrade-Budapest railway project, jointly managing major cooperation projects, and creating more \"small yet smart\" projects for public well-being, so as to continue to deliver positive economic and social benefits.\n\nThe China-Serbia Free Trade Agreement will come into effect on July 1 this year, Xi noted, saying that the high-level mutual opening-up between China and Serbia will surely enter a new stage.\n\nChina will continue to import more high-quality agricultural products with Serbian features, and is ready to invite 300 young Serbian people to China for study and exchange in the next three years, he said.\n\nSerbia is welcome to deepen cultural and people-to-people exchanges in an all-round way, he added.\n\nThe Chinese leader called on Beijing and Belgrade to carry forward the innovative nature of bilateral relations, open up new prospects for cooperation, and make innovative cooperation a new growth point of bilateral ties.\n\nIn the next three years, Xi said, China will support 50 young Serbian scientists to carry out research exchange visits to China, and is willing to strengthen cooperation with Serbia in artificial intelligence (AI) to promote the rational development and application of AI for humanity.\n\nXi called on the two countries to jointly oppose hegemonism and power politics, as well as bloc politics and camp confrontation, uphold the purposes and principles of the UN Charter, practice genuine multilateralism, and promote international fairness and justice. \u25a0\n\nChinese President Xi Jinping attends a welcome ceremony held by Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic prior to their talks in Belgrade, Serbia, May 8, 2024. {"uri": "8117509437", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:00:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:00:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T13:58:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/chinas-xi-in-serbia-for-talks-to-boost-econo-1822728.html", "title": "Chinas Xi In Serbia For Talks To Boost Economic Ties - UrduPoint", "body": "Serbia's President Aleksandar Vucic reaffirmed his strong support for China's sovereignty over Taiwan as he gave a lavish welcome to President Xi Jinping who is seeking to deepen political and economic ties with friendlier countries in Europe\n\nBelgrade, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 8th May, 2024) Serbia's President Aleksandar Vucic reaffirmed his strong support for China's sovereignty over Taiwan as he gave a lavish welcome to President Xi Jinping who is seeking to deepen political and economic ties with friendlier countries in Europe.\n\nChina has poured billions into Serbia and neighbouring Balkan countries, particularly into mining and manufacturing, and last year Beijing and Belgrade signed a free trade agreement.\n\nXi and his wife Peng Liyuan were greeted by Vucic on a red carpet outside the main government offices in Belgrade on Wednesday.\n\nThe Chinese leader was met by a gun salute and the Chinese national anthem, as helicopters whirred overhead, before shaking hands with officials including the prime minister and the National Bank of Serbia governor.\n\nThe two leaders waved from a balcony to a crowd of several thousand waiting outside, pictures from state broadcaster RTS showed, some waving Chinese flags.\n\nVucic welcomed Xi and called him a \"friend of Serbia\". \"Such respect and love as he will find here in our Serbia, he will not find anywhere else,\" Vucic added.\n\nHe told the crowd as Xi applauded: \"We have a clear and simple position regarding Chinese territorial integrity. Yes, Taiwan is China\". China has stepped up diplomatic pressure on the island that it has claimed for decades.\n\nThe Chinese president arrived in Belgrade on Tuesday from a state visit to France that saw sometimes robust exchanges with President Emmanuel Macron on trade and China's close ties to Russia despite the Ukraine war.\n\nThe other two countries chosen for Xi's first trip to Europe since 2019 -- with Hungary as the final stop after Serbia -- are among the most sympathetic to Moscow in Europe.\n\nSerbian finance minister Sinisa Mali told state broadcaster RTS that discussions Wednesday would centre on \"a great project\".\n\n\"We are aiming to attract a major investment from China in a very promising area,\" he said, adding \"I won't reveal our cards at this moment.\"\n\nStreets in the Serbian capital were decked out with Chinese flags, along with posters and billboards that proclaimed a \"warm welcome\" to \"Chinese friends\".\n\n- NATO bombing -\n\nXi's visit also coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 US bombing of the Chinese embassy there, which killed three people.\n\n\"Do not forget that our Chinese friends were with us 25 years ago when this country was being demolished and bombed,\" Vucic told the crowds.\n\n\"They paid a high price, they lost people only a few hundred meters from here on this very day.\"\n\nThe embassy was hit during a months-long, US-led NATO campaign targeting Serbian security forces who were at war with ethnic-Albanian insurgents in Kosovo.\n\nThe US later apologised, saying outdated maps had led the pilot to strike the wrong target. On Tuesday, Xi wrote in Serbian daily Politika that NATO had \"flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy in Yugoslavia\", warning that China would \"never allow such tragic history to repeat itself\".\n\nChina has long backed Serbia's territoral claims over the breakaway province of Kosovo and along with Russia has prevented its recognition at the United Nations.\n\nHe also hailed the \"ironclad friendship\" between China and Serbia, which he said was \"forged with the blood of our compatriots\".\n\nStefan Vladisavljev, programme director at the Foundation BFPE for a Responsible Society, said that the date of the visit gave it \"significant symbolic importance\".\n\n\"I think it's an excellent thing, this visit from the president of one of the most powerful countries in the world,\" 67-year-old Stojan Vidovic, a retiree, told AFP.\n\n\"It's fantastic for us,\" agreed 69-year-old Dijana Radic, a former translator. She said she hoped there would be \"results from this visit, something good for both parties\".\n\nIn France, Xi met with Macron and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. They urged him not to allow the export of technology that could be used by Russia in Ukraine and to do all it could to end the war.\n\nXi warned the West not to \"smear\" China over the conflict and also hit back at accusations that Chinese overcapacity was causing global trade imbalances.\n\nEurope is concerned that while officially neutral over the Ukraine conflict, China is essentially backing Russia, which is using Chinese machine tools in arms production.\n\nAfter meeting with Vucic, Xi will go later Wednesday to Hungary where China has invested heavily in vast battery and electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing plants.", "source": {"uri": "urdupoint.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UrduPoint"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-349032749", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:57:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:57:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:54:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2932071-china-serbia-chart-shared-future-as-xi-jinping-visits-europe", "title": "China, Serbia chart 'shared future' as Xi Jinping visits Europe", "body": "China and Serbia on Wednesday agreed to follow a \"shared future\" as President Xi Jinping visited the Balkan country, part of his bid to forge stronger relations with allies at the edge of the European Union. Xi\u00b4s visit is part of his first European tour in five years, and is seen as an effort to strengthen ties with eastern European countries that are pro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment.\n\nChina and Serbia on Wednesday agreed to follow a \"shared future\" as President Xi Jinping visited the Balkan country, part of his bid to forge stronger relations with allies at the edge of the European Union.\n\nXi\u00b4s visit is part of his first European tour in five years, and is seen as an effort to strengthen ties with eastern European countries that are pro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment. He will fly to Hungary later in the day. \"We are writing history today,\" Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic told a large crowd that had gathered in front of the Serbian presidential palace to welcome Xi, applauding and chanting \"China, China\".\n\nThe two countries signed 29 agreements promoting legal, regulatory and economic cooperation, with Serbia becoming the first European country to sign a free trade agreement with China in years. Vucic said that since 2020 China had been the single-largest investor in Serbia, and that its investment was up 30-fold over the past decade. The free trade deal that should become operational in July will guarantee tariff-free exports for 95% of Serbian products to China over the next five to 10 years, he said.\n\nBoth leaders boast of an ironclad partnership. Along with Hungary, Serbia is Europe's firmest supporter of China's huge Belt and Road infrastructure project across parts of Asia and Europe. \"Serbia became China\u00b4s first strategic partner in central and eastern Europe eight years ago, and it becomes the first European country with which we shall build a community with shared future,\" Xi said.\n\nBoth leaders said they would support each other's sovereignty and territorial integrity, meaning that Serbia considers Taiwan, viewed by Beijing as a breakaway province, to be part of China, just as China considers Kosovo, which declared independence in 2008, as part of Serbia. \"We shall jointly confront hegemony and the politics of power,\" Xi said.\n\nSYMBOLISM OF THE VISIT Xi\u00b4s visit comes on the anniversary of the 1999 NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during a campaign against the former Yugoslavia to force late Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.\n\nThe bombing, which killed three Chinese journalists and wounded 20 Chinese nationals, prompted outrage in China and an apology from then U.S. President Bill Clinton. \"The Chinese people appreciate the peace but will never allow that a historic tragedy repeats itself,\" Xi said in an opinion article in the daily Politika on Tuesday.\n\nVucic said the two countries had agreed to establish an inter-governmental technology committee that would enable Serbia to get access to the latest technologies and use of artificial intelligence. China owns mines and factories across Serbia and has lent billions for roads, bridges and new facilities, becoming Serbia's key partner in much-needed infrastructure development.\n\nXi left France on Tuesday after a two-day trip during which he offered no major concessions on trade or foreign policy, even as President Emmanuel Macron pressed him on market access and Ukraine. Wednesday would centre on \"a great project\".\n\n\"We are aiming to attract a major investment from China in a very promising\n\narea,\" he said, adding \"I won't reveal our cards at this moment.\"\n\nStreets in the Serbian capital were decked out with Chinese flags, along with\n\nposters and billboards that proclaimed a \"warm welcome\" to \"Chinese friends\".\n\n- NATO bombing -\n\nXi's visit also coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 US bombing of\n\nthe Chinese embassy there, which killed three people.\n\n\"Do not forget that our Chinese friends were with us 25 years ago when this\n\ncountry was being demolished and bombed,\" Vucic told the crowds.\n\n\"They paid a high price, they lost people only a few hundred meters from here\n\non this very day.\"\n\nThe embassy was hit during a months-long, US-led NATO campaign targeting\n\nSerbian security forces who were at war with ethnic-Albanian insurgents in\n\nKosovo.\n\nThe US later apologised, saying outdated maps had led the pilot to strike the\n\nwrong target.\n\nOn Tuesday, Xi wrote in Serbian daily Politika that NATO had \"flagrantly\n\nbombed the Chinese embassy in Yugoslavia\", warning that China would \"never\n\nallow such tragic history to repeat itself\".\n\nChina has long backed Serbia's territoral claims over the breakaway province\n\nof Kosovo and along with Russia has prevented its recognition at the United\n\nNations.\n\nHe also hailed the \"ironclad friendship\" between China and Serbia, which he\n\nsaid was \"forged with the blood of our compatriots\".\n\nStefan Vladisavljev, programme director at the Foundation BFPE for a\n\nResponsible Society, said that the date of the visit gave it \"significant\n\nsymbolic importance\".\n\n\"I think it's an excellent thing, this visit from the president of one of the\n\nmost powerful countries in the world,\" 67-year-old Stojan Vidovic, a retiree,\n\ntold AFP.\n\n\"It's fantastic for us,\" agreed 69-year-old Dijana Radic, a former\n\ntranslator. She said she hoped there would be \"results from this visit,\n\nsomething good for both parties\".\n\nIn France, Xi met with Macron and EU Commission President Ursula von der\n\nLeyen. They urged him not to allow the export of technology that could be\n\nused by Russia in Ukraine and to do all it could to end the war.\n\nXi warned the West not to \"smear\" China over the conflict and also hit back\n\nat accusations that Chinese overcapacity was causing global trade imbalances.\n\nEurope is concerned that while officially neutral over the Ukraine conflict,\n\nChina is essentially backing Russia, which is using Chinese machine tools in\n\narms production.\n\nAfter meeting with Vucic, Xi will go later Wednesday to Hungary where China\n\nhas invested heavily in vast {"uri": "8116905671", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "07:49:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T07:49:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T07:49:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://english.news.cn/20240508/b1ba2f4dd68b49eda795e0694c0dffdb/c.html", "title": "Xi envisages stronger China-Serbia ironclad bond in visit upon anniversary", "body": "China will work with Serbia to forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation \"with stronger momentum, greater scope, and higher quality,\" Xi said.\n\nBELGRADE, May 8 (Xinhua) -- Chinese President Xi Jinping kicked off his second state visit to Serbia on Tuesday night with the aim of fortifying the ironclad friendship between China and Serbia amidst evolving global dynamics.\n\nUpon his arrival, Xi said China will work with Serbia to forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation \"with stronger momentum, greater scope, and higher quality.\"\n\nSerbia has rolled out its red carpet for Xi. Among those welcoming Xi at the Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport was his Serbian counterpart, Aleksandar Vucic. The two heads of state will hold meetings on Wednesday.\n\nTwo fighter jets were dispatched to escort Xi's plane upon its entry into Serbia's airspace. Over the past days, the streets of Belgrade have been richly ornamented with Chinese features, not least the flying Chinese national flags and waving banners.\n\nIn a signed article published Tuesday in Politika, a Belgrade-based Serbian daily, Xi wrote that the ironclad friendship between the two countries is ever-growing. \"Whatever changes in the international landscape, China and Serbia remain true friends and good partners.\"\n\n\"Together we will build a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era,\" Xi wrote.\n\nThe Chinese president's arrival coincides with the 25th anniversary of the NATO bombing of the Chinese embassy in the former Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.\n\nIn 1999, the U.S.-led NATO forces carried out savage airstrikes for 78 days against Yugoslavia, leaving more than 8,000 civilians dead or injured and nearly 1 million more displaced. On the night of May 7, exactly 25 years ago, NATO bombed the Chinese embassy, killing three Chinese journalists, including one from Xinhua.\n\n\"The Chinese people cherish peace, but we will never allow such tragic history to repeat itself,\" Xi wrote in the article. \"The China-Serbia friendship, forged with the blood of our compatriots, will stay in the shared memory of the Chinese and Serbian peoples, and will inspire us to march forward with big strides.\"\n\nAleksandar Mitic, research fellow in International Relations at the Institute of International Politics and Economics in Belgrade, told Xinhua that the friendship, tempered by blood and fire, \"will represent a cornerstone for cooperation in the future.\"\n\nDuring Xi's last state visit to Serbia in 2016, Xi made the site of the old embassy as his first stop to pay homage to the Chinese martyrs killed in the NATO bombing in 1999.\n\nThe ruins of the embassy have now been revamped into a Chinese cultural center for local residents in Serbia to learn both Chinese language and traditional culture. The square outside the center was also renamed \"Serbia-China Friendship Square.\"\n\nGordana, a local resident working nearby who didn't reveal her full name, referred to the bombing as a \"painful memory\" to her. \"The cooperation between China and Serbia holds the promise of providing my children with a better life than I experienced,\" she told Xinhua.\n\nPast years have seen leapfrog growth of China-Serbia cooperation. Two-way trade in 2023 surged to 4.35 billion U.S. dollars, Chinese customs statistics showed. In 2022, China became the largest source of direct investment for Serbia. In October 2023, witnessed by Xi and Vucic, China and Serbia signed a free trade agreement. After the deal takes effect, more than 60 percent of taxable items will become tariff-free immediately, and the final import volume proportion of both sides with zero-tariff items will reach about 95 percent.\n\nUnder the framework of the China-proposed Belt and Road Initiative are flagship projects such as the Smederevo Steelworks and the high-speed railway between Belgrade and Budapest. An integral segment of the Belgrade-Budapest railway is the high-speed train linking Belgrade and Serbia's second-largest city Novi Sad, which has transported some 6.83 million passengers over the past two years.\n\n\"We mainly cooperated in the field of transportation and energy field,\" said Katarina Zakic, head of the Regional Centre Belt and Road at the Institute of International Politics and Economics. In the future, cooperation will be important in the fields of green energy and e-commerce, she told Xinhua.\n\nAlready, Chinese companies and their Serbian counterparts are working on a number of green energy programs, such as the Saraorci Photovoltaic Project. Upon completion, the project will provide more than 16 million kilowatt-hours of green electricity every year and reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 16,000 tons.\n\nSerbia, undoubtedly, stands as a reliable partner for China in Europe, said Aleksandar Vojvodic, head engineer of the Clean Serbia Project of China Road and Bridge Corporation.", "source": {"uri": "english.news.cn", "dataType": {"uri": "8117572258", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:37:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:37:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:36:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3261922/xi-jinping-hails-new-chapter-chinas-relations-serbia-belgrade-backs-his-global-vision", "title": "Xi Jinping hails 'new chapter' for China's relations with Serbia", "body": "Chinese leader hails Belgrade\u2019s support for his vision of a \u2018community with a shared future\u2019 as the countries pledge to deepen relations\n\nXi also backed Serbia\u2019s stance on Kosovo during meeting with President Aleksandar Vucic on Wednesday morning\n\nSerbia has endorsed a key element of Xi Jinping\u2019s global vision as the two countries promised to deepen relations during the Chinese leader\u2019s trip to Belgrade.\n\nXi described the visit, the second leg of his European tour, as \u201copening a new chapter\u201d in bilateral relations when meeting his Serbian counterpart Aleksandar Vucic on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe two countries signed a pledge to deepen and elevate their comprehensive strategic partnership and announced that they would \u201cbuild a community with a shared future\u201d.\n\nThe two leaders were greeted by a flag-waving crowd of around 20,000 people and shouts of \u201cSerbia! China!\u201d outside the Palace of Serbia, a major government complex in the centre of the capital.\n\nXi told Vucic that Beijing was ready to continue the \u201cironclad friendship\u201d between the two countries, to jointly safeguard the fundamental and long-term interests of both countries, and pursue their national development and national rejuvenation side by side, according to Chinese state broadcaster CCTV.\n\nLater, Xi told a joint press conference: \u201cWe agreed to guide and steer the building of a China-Serbia community with a shared future for the new era through strengthening strategic communication.\n\nXi first announced his concept of a \u201ccommunity with a shared future\u201d \u2013 which is often seen as a challenge to the existing US-led global order \u2013 over 10 years ago.\n\nAt its core is a vision of a new type of international relations and global governance characterised by mutual respect, common security and peaceful development.\n\n\u201cEight years ago, Serbia became China\u2019s first comprehensive strategic partner in the Central and Eastern European region, and today Serbia is the first European country to build a community of destiny with China, fully reflecting the strategic, special and high level of China-Serbia relations,\u201d Xi added.\n\nXi also told the press conference that Beijing supported Belgrade\u2019s efforts to maintain national sovereignty and territorial integrity in Kosovo.\n\nChina, along with Russia and Serbia and dozens of other countries, does not recognise Kosovo\u2019s 2008 declaration of independence.\n\nIn return, Serbia does not recognise Taiwan as independent and Vucic told the press conference that his country supports the one-China principle and regards the Taiwan question as an internal matter for China.\n\nThey also pledged mutual support on territorial issues when they met earlier in the day.\n\nXi said the two had also pledged to deepen their economic relations both in traditional areas of strength such as transport and energy infrastructure, while also extending it to cooperation on innovation.\n\nHe also said Beijing welcomed the move to open a direct flight route from Belgrade to Shanghai and back plans for another route linking the Serbian capital and Guangzhou.\n\nA free-trade agreement the two countries signed last year, which will grant Serbian companies access to the extensive Chinese market, is due to take effect at the start of July.\n\nVucic said the pact will \u201cguarantee\u201d the country\u2019s future, adding that China\u2019s previous experiences could provide a road map for Serbia\u2019s future trajectory.\n\nAlthough Serbia is a candidate for EU membership, it is one of Europe\u2019s strongest supporters of China\u2019s expansive belt and road infrastructure project.\n\nIn 2022, China emerged as Serbia\u2019s top source of foreign direct investment and the second-largest trading partner after the European Union, according to Chinese state news agency Xinhua.\n\nTrade between the two countries has risen from US$596 million in 2016 to US$4.35 billion last year.\n\nIn recent years, Beijing has poured substantial investment into Serbia, owning numerous factories and mines, providing billions in loans for constructing roads and funding the development of a railway line between Belgrade and Budapest.\n\nXi\u2019s arrival in Belgrade on Tuesday, following his two-day visit to France, coincided with the 25th anniversary of the 1999 bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade during Nato\u2019s Kosovo campaign.\n\nThe US apologised for the incident, insisting it was a mistake that was caused by using outdated maps, but it continues to be a sore point in China.\n\nIn an opinion piece published in Serbia\u2019s oldest daily newspaper Politika on Tuesday, Xi wrote: \u201cThe Chinese people cherish peace, but we will never allow such tragic history to repeat itself.\n\n\u201cThe China-Serbia friendship, forged with the blood of our Political mutual trust between the two countries is rock-solid. Pragmatic cooperation, institutional upgrading, and multilateral coordination are close and smooth, and hardcore friendship is everlasting.\"\n\nMore than two dozen agreements were signed during this visit, promoting legal, regulatory and economic cooperation.\n\nAnd both leaders said they would support each other's sovereignty and territorial integrity.\n\nMeaning that Serbia considers Taiwan, viewed by Beijing as a breakaway province, to be part of China, just as China considers Kosovo, which declared independence in 2008, as part of Serbia.\n\nVucic said Serbia and China are moving from strategic relations to (quote) \"a community that talks about the shared future of our two countries.\"\n\nChina owns mines and factories across Serbia and has lent it billions for roads, bridges and new facilities, becoming the country's key partner in much-needed infrastructure development.\n\n:: May 8, 1999\n\nXi's visit coincides with the anniversary of the accidental 1999 NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.\n\nIt killed three Chinese journalists and wounded 20 Chinese nationals. It sparked outrage in China and an apology from then-U.S. President Bill Clinton.\n\n:: File\n\nAlong with Hungary, Serbia is Europe's firmest supporter of China's huge Belt and Road infrastructure project, which stretches across parts of Asia and Europe.\n\nThe Chinese president had left France on Tuesday after a two-day trip where he offered no major concessions on trade or foreign policy.", {"uri": "8116767681", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "06:15:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T06:15:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T06:14:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/world/europe/xis-visit-to-serbia-hungary-shows-beijings-limitations-in-eu-china-relations-say-analysts20240508114210/", "title": "Xi's visit to Serbia, Hungary shows Beijing's limitations in EU-China relations, say analysts", "body": "Belgrade [Serbia], May 8 (ANI): Analysts have said that Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Serbia and Hungary demonstrates China's limitations amid the ups and downs in ties between Beijing and the European Union, VOA News reported.\n\nXi Jinping, accompanied by his wife, Peng Liyuan, arrived in Belgrade on Tuesday to pay a state visit to Serbia. Xi and his wife arrived in Serbia after concluding his visit to France.\n\nSerbian President Aleksandar Vucic and his wife, Tamara Vucic, welcomed Xi Jinping at Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport. Children welcomed Xi and his wife, Peng Liyuan by presenting them with flowers and waving the national flags of China and Serbia.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to mark the 25th anniversary of the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in 1999. The US has apologised for what it called a \"mistaken\" bombing that killed three Chinese nationals and injured 20 others. Xi is expected to pay tribute to those killed at the site, which is now a Chinese cultural centre.\n\nDuring his visit to France, French President Emmanuel Macron pressed Xi Jinping on Russia's military action in Ukraine, trade disputes and human rights. Notably, Xi is on a six-day visit to Europe and after his Serbia visit, he will head to Hungary.\n\nSpeaking to VOA News, Francesco Sisci, an Italian sinologist, said that it appears that China is facing difficulties in its relations with European nations.\n\nSisci said, \"It's interesting that ... China didn't manage to secure more significant countries for Xi's visit to Europe. It seems that China is having greater difficulties in its ties with European countries, and it has good ties with two governments that have also good ties with Moscow. That is -- Europe is moving faster away from China as it sees it too close to Moscow.\"\n\nSerbia and Hungary have developed close ties with Russia and China under Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic and Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban. China has been investing billions in various projects, including electric vehicles, railways, and factories, in Serbia and Hungary.\n\nJa Ian Chong, associate professor of political science at the National University of Singapore, said that Xi will try to stress China's role in supporting stability.\n\n\"Xi will probably try to stress the PRC's [People's Republic of China] role in supporting stability and maybe suggest but not openly accuse the United States of being destabilizing and unnecessarily aggressive,\" VOA News quoted Ja Ian Chong as saying.\n\nThe two nations like China have spoken against sanctions by the US and EU on Russia over its military action in Ukraine, which began in 2022, although Hungary has voted in favour of them.\n\nOrban, despite leading a nation that is both a North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and EU member, has friendly ties with Russian President Vladimir Putin and held talks with him on the sidelines of the Belt and Road International Cooperation Summit Forum held in Beijing in October.\n\nUnlike other EU members, Hungary continues to purchase the majority of its fuel from Russia. Serbia is a candidate to join the European Union. Viktor Orban is the only leader who attended the Summit and met Xi Jinping.\n\nDragana Mitrovic, a political science professor at the University of Belgrade, said those ties have triggered tensions with Hungary's partners in the West.\n\nMitrovic said, \"In this moment of tense geopolitical competition and measuring economic and overall cooperation by strategic gains and losses, Hungary will continue to be under pressure from Brussels and Washington when pursuing cooperation with China,\" VOA News reported.\n\nUpon arriving in Serbia, Xi in a written statement stated, \"China and Serbia enjoy profound traditional friendship. Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xinhua reported.\n\nXi said he looks forward to taking this visit as an opportunity to hold talks with Aleksandar Vuvic on bilateral ties and other issues of mutual interest, renewing friendship, planning for cooperation, exploring development, and creating a new blueprint for the development of bilateral relations.\n\nHe said, \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations.\" Xi Jinping arrived in Serbia at the invitation of Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic. {"uri": "2024-05-349283700", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:37:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:37:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:26:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.kosovo-online.com/en/news/kontext/xis-arrival-belgrade-good-occasion-west-reassess-its-actions-towards-serbia-8-5-2024", "title": "Xi's arrival in Belgrade is a good occasion for the West to reassess its actions towards Serbia", "body": "\"At a time when new threats and blackmail are coming from the West regarding Kosovo and Republic of Srpska, while Germany and the USA are preparing to admit Pristina to the Council of Europe and stigmatize Serbs with false accusations of genocide, Chinese President Xi Jinping, as the most influential leader currently in the world, in Belgrade shows the greatest friendship with Aleksandar Vucic and the Serbian people.\"\n\nCompiled by: Milos Garic\n\nRarely has a visit by a foreign statesman to Serbia caused such attention and resonance as the current arrival in Belgrade of President Xi Jinping of China. And with good reason.\n\nThe visit of President Xi is of historical significance for Serbia and represents the pinnacle of successful policies led by Serbia under President Aleksandar Vucic, agree many analysts, not only in Serbia.\n\nSerbia is one of only three European countries that the head of the world superpower, the People's Republic of China, decided to visit after five years. This fact alone speaks volumes, especially considering that the other two countries are France and Hungary.\n\nThe economic significance of Serbia's strategic partnership with China is enormous; that will be discussed later. However, the arrival of the Chinese president primarily represents a valuable encouragement for Serbia and provides it with maneuvering space to persist in its sovereign policies. It is also a message to many in the West that China's role is becoming increasingly significant in the Balkans.\n\nPresident Xi's stay in Belgrade, his second since assuming leadership of China, comes at a sensitive time when Serbia is facing multiple attacks from Western countries on its national interests, both regarding Kosovo and the UN resolution on Srebrenica.\n\nThe sincere and emotional friendly statements of President Xi and Vucic, the announcement of further strengthening of the strategic partnership between China and Serbia, as well as the spectacular reception of the numerous Chinese delegation in Belgrade, in front of thousands of gathered citizens of the Serbian capital, it is clear, will not be very pleasing to some political centers in the West and the region.\n\nSerbia has an alternative\n\nChina is a sincere fighter against the world order based on the rule of force advocated by the West, which violates international law wherever it suits it, with the Serbian people being its biggest victim.\n\nWhat messages does the arrival of the Chinese president in Belgrade send in this regard, here in the Balkans, but also towards the EU and the USA?\n\nPolitical analyst Ognjen Gogic believes that Xi's visit to Belgrade is a good occasion for the West to reconsider its policy and treatment towards Serbia.\n\n\"China is still not on the radar for many regarding Serbia because it is considered that Russia is Serbia's main ally, especially in blocking the recognition of Kosovo's independence and statehood. However, China is also very consistent in this regard. The support of official Beijing to Serbia is very significant in the United Nations, where there is now an attempt with a resolution on genocide, but it also has an impact in the Council of Europe, in the attempts of some countries to admit Pristina. President Xi's visit to Belgrade is not directly related to current events in the Council of Europe, but it can be significant in that regard. It is a message of support to Belgrade, a message to Western countries, for which China is a very important partner,\" explains Gogic for Kontekst.\n\nPresident Xi Jinping's visit to Belgrade, he adds, can signal to influential Western countries that Serbia has an alternative.\n\n\"This means that if Western countries continue to push Serbia away, if they continue with current moves, Serbia can turn to other partners who welcome it with open arms. In that sense, this visit of the Chinese president to Serbia, as one of only three countries President Xi visits in Europe, will have the role of prompting certain Western countries to consider what is more beneficial for them. Does Kosovo's membership in the Council of Europe bring them more harm or benefit? Who is a more important partner in the Balkans, Belgrade or Pristina? If they insist on Kosovo's membership in the Council of Europe, they can push Serbia even further away, which will then turn more strongly to Russia and China, and that doesn't benefit the West. That's why this visit of the Chinese president is of great importance for Serbia's international position,\" emphasizes Gogic.\n\nHistorian and political analyst Ognjen Karanovic emphasizes that Chinese President Xi Jinping is coming to Serbia at a complex geopolitical moment and that his stay in Belgrade is of immense significance.\n\n\"First and foremost, because China represents a global player, it is a global superpower and from that position represents a guardian of Serbia's territorial integrity and sovereignty. On the other hand, official Belgrade, with the statesmanship abilities of President Vucic, who is today one of the most respected world leaders, can be a link between those cold, complex, poisoned relations of Europe, the political West, and the People's Republic of China. If nothing else, then at least in an economic sense,\" points out Karanovic for Kontekst.\n\nHe adds that this visit represents another seal of friendship between President Vucic and President Xi, as well as between Serbia and China as a whole.\n\n\"President Xi is President Vucic's guest for two days, among other things, on the occasion of marking the 25th anniversary of the heinous bombing of the Chinese Embassy during the NATO aggression against Serbia. On the other hand, the People's Republic of China represents a huge support in the epic, titanic struggle of President Aleksandar Vucic on the diplomatic-political level, especially in the United Nations, regarding Aleksandar Vucic's efforts to protect the southern Serbian province and Republic of Srpska, as well as the entire Serbian people, from the attempts of the political West to finish, let's say, their business in Kosovo and Metohija, which they started with the criminal NATO aggression in 1999. On the other hand, in order to complete their dishonorable task, their monstrous task, they consider it politically opportune to label the entire Serbian people as genocidal now. And of course, in that regard, the support of the People's Republic of China has its immense weight, its immense significance,\" notes Karanovic.\n\nKosovo and Taiwan\n\nSerbia and China, he adds, jointly protect the territorial integrity of both countries, when it comes to Kosovo and the island of Taiwan, which is an integral part of the People's Republic of China.\n\n\"On the other hand, this visit will be a, let's say, great boost to fruitful economic cooperation between two truly friendly and partner countries. Last year, the total amount of trade between the two countries exceeded six billion euros. This year it will be one billion more. Companies with Chinese capital in Serbia, three of them, are the largest Serbian exporters, and thus the biggest support to the Serbian budget and public finances. Let's remember that President Vucic's congratulations on the Chinese Lunar New Year were broadcast on Chinese state television in prime time. The broadcast of the congratulatory message was watched by 100 million people, which represents a great gesture of honor and gratitude from the Chinese state to Vucic and Serbia. Relations between Serbia and China are at a historical peak, as confirmed by the recently signed Free Trade Agreement, which is a rare privilege that Chinese grant to some smaller countries in the world,\" emphasized Karanovic.\n\nHe emphasizes that geographical distance is not a barrier to the closest ties between Serbia and China.\n\n\"Serbia is a link between China and Europe, which was also confirmed at last year's meeting between President Vucic and Xi Jinping within the framework of the third Belt and Road Forum in Beijing. And indeed, as much as Europe is far from China, Serbia is close to China and China to Serbia. That's why we can understand this panic in regional media, in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Croatia, and even in the political West, which now points fingers at President Vucic's sovereignist policy. On the other hand, they also want to develop economic cooperation with China. Europe wants that too, but insincerely, because they are bothered by the fact that China benefits from it,\" concludes Karanovic.", "source": {"uri": "kosovo-online.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8117744809", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "16:33:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T16:33:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T16:32:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.indiandefensenews.in/2024/05/xis-visit-to-serbia-hungary-shows.html", "title": "Xi's Visit To Serbia, Hungary Shows Beijing's Limitations In EU-China Relations, Say Analysts", "body": "Xi's Visit To Serbia, Hungary Shows Beijing's Limitations In EU-China Relations, Say Analysts Wednesday, May 08, 2024 by Indian Defence News\n\nBelgrade: Analysts have said that Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Serbia and Hungary demonstrates China's limitations amid the ups and downs in ties between Beijing and the European Union, VOA News reported.\n\nXi Jinping, accompanied by his wife, Peng Liyuan, arrived in Belgrade on Tuesday to pay a state visit to Serbia. Xi and his wife arrived in Serbia after concluding his visit to France.\n\nSerbian President Aleksandar Vucic and his wife, Tamara Vucic, welcomed Xi Jinping at Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport. Children welcomed Xi and his wife, Peng Liyuan by presenting them with flowers and waving the national flags of China and Serbia.\n\nXi arrived in Serbia to mark the 25th anniversary of the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in 1999. The US has apologised for what it called a \"mistaken\" bombing that killed three Chinese nationals and injured 20 others. Xi is expected to pay tribute to those killed at the site, which is now a Chinese cultural centre.\n\nDuring his visit to France, French President Emmanuel Macron pressed Xi Jinping on Russia's military action in Ukraine, trade disputes and human rights. Notably, Xi is on a six-day visit to Europe and after his Serbia visit, he will head to Hungary.\n\nSpeaking to VOA News, Francesco Sisci, an Italian sinologist, said that it appears that China is facing difficulties in its relations with European nations.\n\nSisci said, \"It's interesting that ... China didn't manage to secure more significant countries for Xi's visit to Europe. It seems that China is having greater difficulties in its ties with European countries, and it has good ties with two governments that have also good ties with Moscow. That is -- Europe is moving faster away from China as it sees it too close to Moscow.\"\n\nSerbia and Hungary have developed close ties with Russia and China under Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic and Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban. China has been investing billions in various projects, including electric vehicles, railways, and factories, in Serbia and Hungary.\n\nJa Ian Chong, associate professor of political science at the National University of Singapore, said that Xi will try to stress China's role in supporting stability.\n\n\"Xi will probably try to stress the PRC's [People's Republic of China] role in supporting stability and maybe suggest but not openly accuse the United States of being destabilizing and unnecessarily aggressive,\" VOA News quoted Ja Ian Chong as saying.\n\nThe two nations like China have spoken against sanctions by the US and EU on Russia over its military action in Ukraine, which began in 2022, although Hungary has voted in favour of them.\n\nOrban, despite leading a nation that is both a North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and EU member, has friendly ties with Russian President Vladimir Putin and held talks with him on the sidelines of the Belt and Road International Cooperation Summit Forum held in Beijing in October.\n\nUnlike other EU members, Hungary continues to purchase the majority of its fuel from Russia. Serbia is a candidate to join the European Union. Viktor Orban is the only leader who attended the Summit and met Xi Jinping.\n\nDragana Mitrovic, a political science professor at the University of Belgrade, said those ties have triggered tensions with Hungary's partners in the West.\n\nMitrovic said, \"In this moment of tense geopolitical competition and measuring economic and overall cooperation by strategic gains and losses, Hungary will continue to be under pressure from Brussels and Washington when pursuing cooperation with China,\" VOA News reported.\n\nUpon arriving in Serbia, Xi in a written statement stated, \"China and Serbia enjoy profound traditional friendship. Our bilateral relationship has stood the test of changing international environment and become a fine example of state-to-state relations,\" Xinhua reported.\n\nXi said he looks forward to taking this visit as an opportunity to hold talks with Aleksandar Vuvic on bilateral ties and other issues of mutual interest, renewing friendship, planning for cooperation, exploring development, and creating a new blueprint for the development of bilateral relations.\n\nHe said, \"I am confident that this visit will be a fruitful one and will open up a new chapter in China-Serbia relations.\" Xi Jinping arrived in Serbia at the invitation of Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic.\n\nThis report is auto-generated from a syndicated feed\n\nComments", "source": {"uri": "indiandefensenews.in", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-05-348522530", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "05:32:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T05:32:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T05:27:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/china-xi-jinping-visits-serbia-anniversary-1999-nato-bombing-9315178/", "title": "China's Xi Jinping visits Serbia on anniversary of 1999 NATO bombing", "body": "Belgrade, after France, is the second stop on Xi's first visit to Europe in five years, which also includes Hungary. In Serbia, which is seen as China's most important partner in the Balkans, Xi is expected to discuss China\u00b4s multi-billion investment in the country and possible new deals.\n\nSerbian President Aleksandar Vucic and government officials welcomed Xi at the Belgrade airport, where he was greeted by a military guard of honor and folk dancers. The two leaders will hold a meeting on Wednesday.\n\nOn May 7, 1999, 20 Chinese nationals were wounded in the NATO attack, which prompted outrage in China and an apology from then U.S. President Bill Clinton.\n\nThe embassy was hit during a campaign against the then Yugoslavia to force late Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a crackdown on ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.\n\n\"The Chinese people appreciate the peace but will never allow that a historic tragedy repeats itself,\" Xi said in an opinion article in the daily Politika on Tuesday.\n\n\"The friendship between China and Serbia which is soaked in blood that the two peoples spilled together has become a joint memory of the two peoples and will encourage both parties to make together huge steps forward,\" Xi said.\n\nThe Belgrade streets were decorated with Chinese flags and placards as thousands of police officers were deployed to secure Xi and his 400-member entourage, the highest-level visit by a foreign leader in years.\n\nIRONCLAD FRIENDSHIP\n\nXi is visiting Serbia after France, where President Emmanuel Macron and EU Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen pressed him to ensure more balanced trade with Europe and use his influence on Russia to end the war in Ukraine.\n\nDuring his first visit to Belgrade in 2016, the two countries signed a strategic partnership. Last year, Vucic signed 18 agreements with Xi in Beijing, including a free trade deal that should become operational in July.\n\nBoth leaders insist on an ironclad partnership between their countries. Along with Hungary, which is Xi\u00b4s next stop, Serbia is Europe's firmest supporter of China's Belt and Road Initiative.\n\nChina runs mines and factories across Serbia and has lent billions for roads, bridges and new facilities, becoming Serbia's key partner in much-needed infrastructure development.\n\nObservers say Xi's choice of Serbia and Hungary is designed to pull closer two European countries that are pro-Russia and large recipients of Chinese investment. Serbia's Western partners view the country as a Chinese hub at the gateway to the EU.\n\nIn 2023, China was Serbia's second-largest trading partner after the EU with a total trade exchange of $6.1 billion and among its top five investors, according to the national investment agency.", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Indian Express"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8116878882", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "07:32:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T07:32:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T07:31:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://english.news.cn/20240508/0a5498683cbe4eb7b9d2a8af6babf3e7/c.html", "title": "Xi envisages stronger China-Serbia ironclad bond in visit upon anniversary", "body": "BELGRADE, May 8 (Xinhua) -- Chinese President Xi Jinping kicked off his second state visit to Serbia on Tuesday night with the aim of fortifying the ironclad friendship between China and Serbia amidst evolving global dynamics.\n\nUpon his arrival, Xi said China will work with Serbia to forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation \"with stronger momentum, greater scope, and higher quality.\"\n\nSerbia has rolled out its red carpet for Xi. Among those welcoming Xi at the Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport was his Serbian counterpart, Aleksandar Vucic. The two heads of state will hold meetings on Wednesday.\n\nTwo fighter jets were dispatched to escort Xi's plane upon its entry into Serbia's airspace. Over the past days, the streets of Belgrade have been richly ornamented with Chinese features, not least the flying Chinese national flags and waving banners.\n\nIn a signed article published Tuesday in Politika, a Belgrade-based Serbian daily, Xi wrote that the ironclad friendship between the two countries is ever-growing. \"Whatever changes in the international landscape, China and Serbia remain true friends and good partners.\"\n\n\"Together we will build a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era,\" Xi wrote.\n\nThe Chinese president's arrival coincides with the 25th anniversary of the NATO bombing of the Chinese embassy in the former Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.\n\nIn 1999, the U.S.-led NATO forces carried out savage airstrikes for 78 days against Yugoslavia, leaving more than 8,000 civilians dead or injured and nearly 1 million more displaced. On the night of May 7, exactly 25 years ago, NATO bombed the Chinese embassy, killing three Chinese journalists, including one from Xinhua.\n\n\"The Chinese people cherish peace, but we will never allow such tragic history to repeat itself,\" Xi wrote in the article. \"The China-Serbia friendship, forged with the blood of our compatriots, will stay in the shared memory of the Chinese and Serbian peoples, and will inspire us to march forward with big strides.\"\n\nAleksandar Mitic, research fellow in International Relations at the Institute of International Politics and Economics in Belgrade, told Xinhua that the friendship, tempered by blood and fire, \"will represent a cornerstone for cooperation in the future.\"\n\nDuring Xi's last state visit to Serbia in 2016, Xi made the site of the old embassy as his first stop to pay homage to the Chinese martyrs killed in the NATO bombing in 1999.\n\nThe ruins of the embassy have now been revamped into a Chinese cultural center for local residents in Serbia to learn both Chinese language and traditional culture. The square outside the center was also renamed \"Serbia-China Friendship Square.\"\n\nGordana, a local resident working nearby who didn't reveal her full name, referred to the bombing as a \"painful memory\" to her. \"The cooperation between China and Serbia holds the promise of providing my children with a better life than I experienced,\" she told Xinhua.\n\nPast years have seen leapfrog growth of China-Serbia cooperation. Two-way trade in 2023 surged to 4.35 billion U.S. dollars, Chinese customs statistics showed. In 2022, China became the largest source of direct investment for Serbia. In October 2023, witnessed by Xi and Vucic, China and Serbia signed a free trade agreement. After the deal takes effect, more than 60 percent of taxable items will become tariff-free immediately, and the final import volume proportion of both sides with zero-tariff items will reach about 95 percent.\n\nUnder the framework of the China-proposed Belt and Road Initiative are flagship projects such as the Smederevo Steelworks and the high-speed railway between Belgrade and Budapest. An integral segment of the Belgrade-Budapest railway is the high-speed train linking Belgrade and Serbia's second-largest city Novi Sad, which has transported some 6.83 million passengers over the past two years.\n\n\"We mainly cooperated in the field of transportation and energy field,\" said Katarina Zakic, head of the Regional Centre Belt and Road at the Institute of International Politics and Economics. In the future, cooperation will be important in the fields of green energy and e-commerce, she told Xinhua.\n\nAlready, Chinese companies and their Serbian counterparts are working on a number of green energy programs, such as the Saraorci Photovoltaic Project. Upon completion, the project will provide more than 16 million kilowatt-hours of green electricity every year and reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 16,000 tons.\n\nSerbia, undoubtedly, stands as a reliable partner for China in Europe, said Aleksandar Vojvodic, head engineer of the Clean Serbia Project of China Road and Bridge Corporation.\n\nThere will be a promising prospect for further enhancement and expansion of existing cooperation, said Vojvodic. \u25a0", "source": {"uri": "english.news.cn", "dataType": "news", "title": "english.news.cn"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
