{"uri": "8114893645", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "05:29:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T05:29:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T05:28:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.euractiv.com/section/enlargement-neighbourhood/news/serbia-opens-its-arms-and-economy-to-brother-xi/", "title": "Serbia opens its arms and economy to 'Brother Xi'", "body": "Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Belgrade on Tuesday (7 May) has raised eyebrows at a time when Serbia's President Aleksander Vu\u010di\u0107 has continued to resist increasing pressure to align foreign policy with the West, in particular the EU.\n\n\"China is the best partner for Serbia to achieve its national goals\", and it was time to raise bilateral relations to a new level, to a strategic partnership, Vu\u010di\u0107 told Chinese television station CCTV in an extensive interview ahead of Xi's visit.\n\nTo exemplify that, the Serbian capital has been covered with Chinese flags as a welcome gesture.\n\nBeijing's influence has significantly increased in the European Union member hopeful over the past decade, with Chinese investment topping \u20ac5.1 billion between 2014 and 2023.\n\nXi's visit will also coincide with a highly symbolic date of the 25th anniversary of the NATO bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade. The incident occurred during Operation Allied Force, which was triggered by the Racak massacre during the Kosovo War, ultimately seeing the withdrawal of the Yugoslav Army and an end to the conflict.\n\nHowever, the incident, which the US claimed was an accident, \"is one of the elements on which the Chinese have based their anti-Western narrative over the last 25 years,\" Stefan Vladisavljev, an analyst at the Belgrade Fund for Political Excellence (BFPE), told Euractiv.\n\nHe added, \"Visiting Belgrade on this occasion is a way for President Xi to affirm the ties that unite China and Serbia, but above all, Beijing's new role in the world order.\"\n\nBeijing has become Belgrade's second-largest trading partner, and by 2021, Chinese imports into Serbia were worth \u20ac3.6 billion (up 26.9% in 2020), even though the EU still accounts for 60% of the country's trade.\n\nChinese investments are concentrated in strategic sectors such as the automotive industry, the copper and gold mines in the Bor region, bought by the Chinese giant Zijin Mining Group in 2018, and the Smederevo steelworks, which came under the control of the Chinese group HBIS in 2016 for \u20ac46 million.\n\nNew contracts will likely be announced during Xi's visit to Serbia concerning the construction of the Belgrade metro and the 2027 international exhibition in the Serbian capital.\n\nVu\u010di\u0107 had already signed a free trade agreement with his Chinese counterpart last year -due to enter force on 1 July and to expire when Serbia joins the EU one day - covering thousands of products from both countries, including Serbian honey and wine.\n\nIn 2009, Belgrade had already signed a framework agreement with Beijing on infrastructure, exempting Chinese companies from going through restrictive calls for tender to bid for public contracts.\n\nThis provision has been denounced by Serbian civil society, which points to the opacity of the contracts signed by the Chinese - often financed by loans granted by banks that are also Chinese - and repeated attacks on the environment, for example, during the expansion of the Drmno lignite mine, which supplies the Kostolac power station near the Danube.\n\nAs Russia's war in Ukraine continues and Moscow's influence is felt throughout the continent, many fear what impact that could have on regions with a history of instability, such as the Western Balkans.\n\nIn late 2023, the EU announced the \u20ac6 billion Growth Plan for the Western Balkans to link funds to reforms and boost the regions ties to the European single market.\n\nHowever, public opinion in Serbia remains unconvinced, with only 33% of recent survey respondents saying they favour EU membership, the lowest percentage in a region where countries like Kosovo and Albania enjoy over 90% approval rates.\n\nWhile Serbia is a candidate for EU membership there has been little progress and earlier this year, the European Commission made changes to Serbia's negotiation conditions, insisting that it stop obstructing Kosovo's efforts to join international organisations including the Council of Europe and the EU.\n\nIn December 2023, then-prime minister Ana Brnabic wrote a letter to the Commission stating that the country would not implement several of the agreements made under the EU-backed dialogue.\n\nBelgrade has also refused to align itself with the EU's foreign policy regarding Russia and has strengthened economic and diplomatic ties with a series of high-level visits and agreements.\n\nA 2023 survey by the Westminster Foundation for Democracy found that 42% of Serbians believe they should rely on Russia, with almost 8% (third position) believing they should rely on China regarding international relations. Only some 25% had faith in the EU.\n\nAnother recent survey, found that over 75% of Serbs consider China \"friendly\", and 64% believe that relations between Serbia and China will improve.\n\nThese figures have been rising steadily since the COVID-19 pandemic, when the EU failed to provide fast and adequate support to candidate countries while Chinese planes were delivering surgical masks and gloves to Belgrade airport.\n\nBack then, street walls and placards in Serbia were covered with large signs proclaiming, \"Thank you, Brother Xi\".\n\nChinese political rhetoric emphasising the territorial integrity of states has also resonated in Serbia considering the ongoing dispute with Kosovo.\n\nIn February 2024, Vu\u010di\u0107 explained in an interview with Chinese television CGTN: \"For us, it's very simple. Taiwan is China. And it's up to you to see what, when and how you're going to do it.\"", "source": {"uri": "euractiv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "EurActiv.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8114862399", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "05:05:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T05:05:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T05:02:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13389921/Chinas-Xi-begins-Serbia-visit-25th-anniversary-NATOs-bombing-Chinese-Embassy.html", "title": "China's Xi begins Serbia visit on the 25th anniversary of NATO's...", "body": "BELGRADE, Serbia (AP) - Chinese leader Xi Jinping's visit to European ally Serbia on Tuesday falls on a symbolic date: the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during NATO's air war over Kosovo.\n\nU.S. jets dropped five bombs on the Chinese Embassy compound in the Serbian capital on May 7, 1999, setting it ablaze and killing three Chinese nationals. Twenty other people were injured in the incident, which has burdened relations between the two powers ever since.\n\nThe Western military alliance had launched the air war in March that year to force then Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic to end a brutal onslaught against ethnic Albanian rebels in Kosovo.\n\nThe U.S. at the time apologized and said the embassy bombing was a mistake that happened due to faulty intelligence. The intended target, Washington said, was the headquarters of a Serbian state arms exporter located on the same street, a few blocks away.\n\n\"Imagine that somebody would, even by accident, strike an American Embassy somewhere around the world. The reaction would be immediate,\" said Sven Biscop, a professor of European foreign and security policy at the Ghent University and Egmont Institute.\n\n\"So for a country like China, it is also clear that this is a big thing,\" he added. \"And, of course, it has not been forgotten.\"\n\nWorkers hang on ropes to install a giant Chinese national flag on a skyscraper that is a symbolic gateway leading into the city from the airport, in Belgrade, Serbia, Saturday, May 4, 2024. Chinese leader Xi Jinping's visit to European ally Serbia on Tuesday falls on a symbolic date: the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during NATO's air war over Kosovo. (AP Photo/Darko Vojinovic)\n\nAngry protesters in China stormed U.S. diplomatic installations as the bombing fueled anti-American sentiments and speculation that the attack was intentional rather than accidental. Mistrust over the incident has endured to this day.\n\n\"We will probably never really conclusively know either way,\" Biscop said. \"But one thing is sure. In war, incidents like that do happen, and I usually tend to go for the most simple explanation rather than try to invent complicated theories.\"\n\nWhile straining Beijing's relations with the U.S., the embassy bombing brought China and Serbia closer together. China has emerged as Serbia\u00b4s largest provider of foreign direct investment and its second-largest trading partner after the European Union.\n\nBeijing opposed the NATO bombing campaign and has since backed Belgrade's bid to counter the Western-backed push for independence in Kosovo, a former Serbian province. In return, Serbia has been a loyal ally to Beijing and has opened its doors without restraint to billions of dollars of Chinese investment, even as it formally seeks EU membership.\n\nSigns of pro-China sentiments were clearly visible ahead of Xi's visit on Tuesday and Wednesday. In Belgrade, a huge Chinese flag was placed on a skyscraper along a roadway leading into the city from the airport. Smaller Chinese and Serbian flags could be seen downtown and along a highway.\n\nXi will arrive from France and proceed from Serbia to Hungary as part of his first European tour in five years.\n\nHe is expected to visit the site of the former embassy on the anniversary date and pay his respects to the bombing victims. A Chinese cultural center now stands at the spot where the embassy was once located.\n\nThe sprawling complex reportedly includes a Confucius Institute, workshops, exhibitions, offices, residential space and a hotel. It is seen as a symbol of China's growing influence in Serbia and across Europe.\n\nNear the institute, a group of visitors from China last weekend bowed in front of a simple black-marble monument and laid flowers in honor of the victims of the 1999 bombing. An inscription on the monument in both Chinese and English reads: \"Honor Martyrs, Cherish Peace.\"\n\nSylvain Plazy contributed to this report from Brussels.\n\nChinese flags fly on lampposts, days before the visit of Chinese President Xi Jinping in Belgrade, Serbia, Wednesday, May 1, 2024. Chinese leader Xi Jinping's visit to European ally Serbia on Tuesday falls on a symbolic date: the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during NATO's air war over Kosovo. Chinese leader Xi Jinping's visit to European ally Serbia on Tuesday, May 7, falls on a symbolic date: the 25th anniversary of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during NATO's air war over Kosovo. (AP Photo/Darko Vojinovic)\n\nChinese and Serbian flags fly on lampposts, days before the visit of Chinese President Xi Jinping in Belgrade, Serbia, Wednesday, May 1, 2024. Since then, the China-Serbia relationship has realized leapfrog development, and achieved historic results, Xi said in the speech.\n\nStanding at a new historical starting point, he said that China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation, with stronger momentum, greater scope and higher quality.\n\n\"I look forward to taking this visit as an opportunity to have in-depth exchange of views with President Aleksandar Vucic on bilateral ties and other issues of mutual interest, renew friendship, plan for cooperation, explore development, and draw up a new blueprint for the development of bilateral relations,\" he said.\n\nXi is currently making a six-day visit to Europe, his first European tour in five years. {"uri": "8117264109", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:26:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:26:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:26:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "http://www.girodivite.it/SERBIA-Serbia-opens-its-arms-and.html", "title": "SERBIA: Serbia opens its arms and economy to 'Brother Xi'", "body": "Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Belgrade on Tuesday (7 May) has raised eyebrows at a time when Serbia's President Aleksander Vu\u010di\u0107 has continued to resist increasing pressure to align foreign policy with the West, in particular the EU.\n\n\"China is the best partner for Serbia to achieve its national goals\", and it was time to raise bilateral relations to a new level, to a strategic partnership, Vu\u010di\u0107 told Chinese television station CCTV in an extensive interview ahead of Xi's visit.\n\nTo exemplify that, the Serbian capital has been covered with Chinese flags as a welcome gesture.\n\nBeijing's influence has significantly increased in the European Union member hopeful over the past decade, with Chinese investment topping \u20ac5.1 billion between 2014 and 2023.\n\nXi's visit will also coincide with a highly symbolic date of the 25th anniversary of the NATO bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade. The incident occurred during Operation Allied Force, which was triggered by the Racak massacre during the Kosovo War, ultimately seeing the withdrawal of the Yugoslav Army and an end to the conflict.\n\nHowever, the incident, which the US claimed was an accident, \"is one of the elements on which the Chinese have based their anti-Western narrative over the last 25 years,\" Stefan Vladisavljev, an analyst at the Belgrade Fund for Political Excellence (BFPE), told Euractiv.\n\nHe added, \"Visiting Belgrade on this occasion is a way for President Xi to affirm the ties that unite China and Serbia, but above all, Beijing's new role in the world order.\"\n\nEconomic ties\n\nBeijing has become Belgrade's second-largest trading partner, and by 2021, Chinese imports into Serbia were worth \u20ac3.6 billion (up 26.9% in 2020), even though the EU still accounts for 60% of the country's trade.\n\nChinese investments are concentrated in strategic sectors such as the automotive industry, the copper and gold mines in the Bor region, bought by the Chinese giant Zijin Mining Group in 2018, and the Smederevo steelworks, which came under the control of the Chinese group HBIS in 2016 for \u20ac46 million.\n\nNew contracts will likely be announced during Xi's visit to Serbia concerning the construction of the Belgrade metro and the 2027 international exhibition in the Serbian capital.\n\nVu\u010di\u0107 had already signed a free trade agreement with his Chinese counterpart last year -due to enter force on 1 July and to expire when Serbia joins the EU one day - covering thousands of products from both countries, including Serbian honey and wine.\n\nIn 2009, Belgrade had already signed a framework agreement with Beijing on infrastructure, exempting Chinese companies from going through restrictive calls for tender to bid for public contracts.\n\nThis provision has been denounced by Serbian civil society, which points to the opacity of the contracts signed by the Chinese - often financed by loans granted by banks that are also Chinese - and repeated attacks on the environment, for example, during the expansion of the Drmno lignite mine, which supplies the Kostolac power station near the Danube.\n\nPublic opinion unconvinced by EU\n\nAs Russia's war in Ukraine continues and Moscow's influence is felt throughout the continent, many fear what impact that could have on regions with a history of instability, such as the Western Balkans.\n\nIn late 2023, the EU announced the \u20ac6 billion Growth Plan for the Western Balkans to link funds to reforms and boost the regions ties to the European single market.\n\nHowever, public opinion in Serbia remains unconvinced, with only 33% of recent survey respondents saying they favour EU membership, the lowest percentage in a region where countries like Kosovo and Albania enjoy over 90% approval rates.\n\nWhile Serbia is a candidate for EU membership there has been little progress and earlier this year, the European Commission made changes to Serbia's negotiation conditions, insisting that it stop obstructing Kosovo's efforts to join international organisations including the Council of Europe and the EU.\n\nIn December 2023, then-prime minister Ana Brnabic wrote a letter to the Commission stating that the country would not implement several of the agreements made under the EU-backed dialogue.\n\nBelgrade has also refused to align itself with the EU's foreign policy regarding Russia and has strengthened economic and diplomatic ties with a series of high-level visits and agreements. Ties with Russia, China\n\nA 2023 survey by the Westminster Foundation for Democracy found that 42% of Serbians believe they should rely on Russia, with almost 8% (third position) believing they should rely on China regarding international relations. Only some 25% had faith in the EU.\n\nAnother recent survey, found that over 75% of Serbs consider China \"friendly\", and 64% believe that relations between Serbia and China will improve.\n\nThese figures have been rising steadily since the COVID-19 pandemic, when the EU failed to provide fast and adequate support to candidate countries while Chinese planes were delivering surgical masks and gloves to Belgrade airport.\n\nBack then, street walls and placards in Serbia were covered with large signs proclaiming, \"Thank you, Brother Xi\".\n\nChinese political rhetoric emphasising the territorial integrity of states has also resonated in Serbia considering the ongoing dispute with Kosovo.\n\nIn February 2024, Vu\u010di\u0107 explained in an interview with Chinese television CGTN: \"For us, it's very simple. Taiwan is China. {"uri": "8116398448", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "23:50:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T23:50:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T23:45:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/chinas-xi-gets-red-carpet-232915944.html", "title": "China's Xi gets red-carpet welcome in Serbia", "body": "The red flags start at Belgrade's Nikola Tesla Airport and run all the way along the motorway into the centre of Serbia's capital.\n\nThis is Serbia's way of showing that it is proud of its \"ironclad friendship\" with China - and welcoming Xi Jinping to Belgrade.\n\nAt the Western City Gate, more commonly known as the Genex Tower, one entire tower is draped in China's national colours.\n\nJust for good measure, there is a billboard for Hisense, the Chinese home appliances manufacturer which opened a refrigerator factory in Valjevo, western Serbia, last year.\n\nIn some parts of Europe, the Chinese president's itinerary might have raised eyebrows. After all, it is not often that Serbia finds itself as part of a three-stop tour by an international leader of such stature.\n\nBut Serbia has been deepening its relationship with China in recent years, even as it continues with negotiations to join the European Union.\n\nMr Xi is likely to use his trip to highlight his criticisms of Nato. His visit coincides with the 25th anniversary of the US airstrikes on China's embassy in Belgrade. And in an editorial for the Serbian newspaper, Politika, the president made it clear that feelings over that incident still run high.\n\n\"We should never forget,\" he wrote. \"The Chinese people cherish peace, but we will never allow such tragic history to repeat itself.\"\n\nThat kind of rhetoric resonates in Serbia, where the vast majority of people oppose Nato membership. That is a key factor in why this stop on Mr Xi's European tour makes perfect sense.\n\nCommercial connections are also a factor. The two countries signed a free trade agreement last year, building on a \"comprehensive strategic partnership\" in 2016 - the year of Mr Xi's previous visit to Serbia.\n\nChina now claims to be the largest source of foreign direct investment (FDI) in Serbia. Its ambassador, Li Ming, says that Hisense, along with mining company Zijin and tyre manufacturer Linglong, provide 20,000.\n\nUN trade figures actually put China in fifth place on the foreign direct investment list, behind Germany, Italy, the US and Russia.\n\nNonetheless, the Chinese investments are eye-catching - and only likely to increase. Serbia has just taken delivery of its first Chinese electric high-speed trains. They will eventually run alongside Swiss-made rolling stock on the Belgrade-Budapest railway, which is being reconstructed with Chinese expertise and finance.\n\nAnd that is just the start. Serbia's infrastructure minister, Goran Vesic, says Chinese partners will work on other infrastructure, including roads, bridges, tunnels and sewage. \"There is really a lot of room for co-operation with Chinese companies,\" he told Serbia's national broadcaster, RTS.\n\nNo wonder Serbia's president, Aleksandar Vucic, is planning to personally serve the finest wines his country has to offer to his Chinese counterpart during a banquet in Mr Xi's honour.\n\nNoting that within five years Serbian wine will face no import tariffs in China, Mr Vucic told China Central Television that Serbian wines were \"not as expensive as [those] in France\" and that he believed Mr Xi was \"going to like\" his selections.\n\nThis was perhaps a gentle dig at Emmanuel Macron, who hosted Mr Xi for the first stop on his European trip. The French president's offering was a bottle of R\u00e9my Martin Louis XIII cognac, which would cost the best part of \u20ac5,000 in Belgrade.\n\nA trip to the Pyrenees was also included in the charm offensive - to sweeten pleas by Mr Macron and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen for Mr Xi to ensure more balanced trade with Europe and influence Russia's President Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine.\n\nAfter Belgrade, the next stop for China's president will be Budapest, where he will meet his strongest ally among the leaders of EU member states, Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban.\n\nChinese investments are also a strong factor there - with a factory for electric car giant BYD among the projects that buttress Mr Orban's resistance to the EU consensus on everything {"uri": "8117407633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:54:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:54:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:53:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://tass.com/world/1785661", "title": "Serbia-China cooperation moving to new level, to continue strengthening  --  president", "body": "According to Alexandar Vucic, the two leaders discussed the free trade agreement with China, industry, science, innovation, artificial intelligence, cooperation in the military field, agriculture, energy, infrastructure, culture, education, health, air transportation\n\nBELGRADE, May 8. /TASS/. The level of relations between Serbia and China is going beyond just strategic partnership, Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic said during talks with Chinese leader Xi Jinping.\n\nOn May 7, Xi arrived in Belgrade on his first visit to Serbia in eight years. He is expected to discuss the international and regional situation with Vucic.\n\n\"Great progress awaits us in our cooperation, which we raise from the level of strategic partnership to a shared future by our joint statement. I am pleased and grateful to President Xi for the support that he has given to Serbia,\" Vucic said during his talks with the Chinese leader and delegation.\n\n\"We discussed the free trade agreement with China, industry, science, innovation, artificial intelligence, cooperation in the military field, agriculture, energy, infrastructure, culture, education, health, air transportation. \"First of all, we discussed Expo 2027 and received Xi Jinping's assurance that China, with its experience, knowledge and presence, will confidently and strongly support Expo 2027, which is a great opportunity for Serbia's growth and further progress,\" the Serbian leader said.\n\nSerbian Minister of Internal and Foreign Trade Tomislav Momirovic, on the eve of the Chinese leader's visit, emphasized that the cooperation between Belgrade and Beijing had passed the level of strategic partnership and reached a new, higher level \"primarily thanks to the unbreakable friendship of the leaders of our states and peoples - President Aleksandar Vucic and President Xi Jinping.\"\n\nThe International Bureau of Exhibitions (BIE) previously selected Serbia as the organizing country for Expo 2027. A total of five countries put in bids to host the event - Serbia, the US (Minnesota), Thailand (Phuket), Spain (Malaga) and Argentina (Bariloche). The election of the Expo 2027 organizer was held by secret ballot. Since no candidate received two-thirds of the votes needed to win the first three rounds, Serbia and Spain advanced to the final round, where a simple majority of votes is required to be elected. Serbia received the votes of 81 countries, 70 favored Spain, and another 3 abstained.\n\nThe World Expo is the largest international event that allows participating countries to present themselves to the world by showcasing the latest developments in technology and science, cultural achievements and new architectural masterpieces. {"uri": "8117180638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "10:37:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T10:37:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T10:36:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.telegraf.rs/english/3886665-xis-message-for-vucic-you-are-exceptional-statesman-with-strategic-vision", "title": "Xi's message for Vucic: \"You are exceptional statesman with strategic vision\"", "body": "Xi said that he was deeply moved by the welcome of the citizens of Serbia\n\nPresident of the People's Republic of China Xi Jinping said today in Belgrade that he was deeply impressed by his meeting with President of Serbia Aleksandar Vucic, whom he referred to as an exceptional statesman.\n\n\"You are an exceptional statesman with a strategic vision, with a sense of historical responsibility. Under your leadership, Serbia maintained stability, achieved rapid economic development, and people's standard of living and lives improved,\" Xi said to Vucic.\n\nXi added that he was deeply moved by the welcome that the citizens of Serbia gave him as he appeared on the balcony of the Palace of Serbia and pointed out that it made him even more convinced of the friendship and cooperation between Serbia and China, which he said makes him glad.\n\n\"In China, we say that mountains cannot meet, but people can. In China, we say that great geographical distances cannot separate people when there are mutual affinities. You invited me many times, Mr. President, to visit your friendly country, and I am here today. Yesterday you said you hoped I would feel at home and now I really feel quite comfortable and pleasant here. I can really feel the hospitality of your country and between good friends there should always be more exchanges, more interaction,\" said the president of China.\n\nHe stressed that Vucic has been to China several times in previous years and that they had were involved in joint engagements on other occasions.", "source": {"uri": "telegraf.rs", "dataType": "news", "title": "Telegraf.rs"}, "authors": [{"uri": "d_r@telegraf.rs", "name": "D. {"uri": "8116143505", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "19:19:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T19:19:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T19:18:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://n1info.rs/english/news/xi-jinping-lashes-out-at-nato-over-1999-belgrade-bombing-ahead-of-serbia-visit/", "title": "Xi Jinping lashes out at NATO over 1999 Belgrade bombing ahead of Serbia visit", "body": "On the final day of his visit to France and ahead of his visit to Serbia, China's President Xi Jinping lashed out at NATO over the 1999 bombing of Belgrade.\n\n\"Twenty-five years ago today, NATO flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy in Yugoslavia, killing three Chinese journalists. This we should never forget. The China-Serbia friendship, forged with the blood of our compatriots, will stay in the shared memory of the Chinese and Serbian peoples,\" the Financial Times (FT) quoted Xi as saying.\n\nThe London daily said that the Belgrade neighborhood home to the former embassy was on Tuesday decked in Chinese and Serbian flags and that the activists of the League of Socialist Youth of Yugoslavia (SKOJ) and New Communist Party of Yugoslavia (NKPJ) on Monday hung banners outside the Chinese Cultural Center, now at this site, to welcome the Chinese president, including one suggesting similarities between Serbia and China: \"Kosovo is Serbia -- Taiwan is China,\" and one saying the street of \"Chinese victims of the NATO aggression.\"\n\nThe Chinese president ended his visit to France and is due in Serbia on Tuesday evening for a two-day visit as part of his mini European tour, during which he will also visit Hungary.\n\nOn the second day of the Chinese president's state visit, French President Emmanuel Macron and Xi headed to the Pyrenees for a private part of the visit, during which they were able to discuss more directly the war in Ukraine and trade disputes.\n\nAnalysts believe that Xi's European trip aims to exploit differences on the continent towards Russia and the US and to potentially undermine the unity of NATO and the EU on China.\n\nChinese academics have praised Macron's advocacy of a more independent European stance on the global stage, while Serbia and Hungary are seen as more pro-Russia despite the Ukraine war, reported the daily.\n\nThe Financial Times said that China is the biggest foreign investor in Serbia and accounts for 8.5 per cent of Belgrade's foreign loans, according to Branimir Jovanovic, a researcher at the Vienna Institute for International Economic Studies.\n\n\"In a way this is a failure of the EU and the west in general that China is so prominent. The west leaves space that China is more than willing to step into,\" Jovanovic said.\n\nThe FT reported that the EU on Tuesday adopted a \u20ac6bn growth package for the six countries of the western Balkans, but which comes with strings attached for Serbia, including a requirement to improve relations with Kosovo, making it less attractive than Chinese funding that comes without such conditions.\n\nEU affairs expert Dusan Reljic told the FT that the EU package was \"much ado about nothing\", saying it amounted to a negligible 0.3 per cent of the region's GDP and was so complex as {"uri": "2024-05-349953742", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "08:29:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T08:29:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T08:27:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.kosovo-online.com/en/news/politics/sretenovic-xi-jinpings-visit-gives-hope-serbia-some-controversial-decisions-un-will", "title": "Sretenovic: Xi Jinping's visit gives hope to Serbia that some controversial decisions in the UN will be prevented", "body": "The visit of Chinese President Xi Jinping to Serbia is significant on a political level because it gives hope that Chinese influence, especially in the UN, will enable Serbia to at least prevent some very unpleasant and controversial decisions being prepared at the UN level, such as the resolution on Srebrenica, historian Stanislav Sretenovic says for Kosovo Online.\n\nAs he explains, the hope is that China will succeed with its authority and influence among small states, in numbers surpassing the influence of Western countries that are eager to push through unpleasant resolutions for Serbia at any cost.\n\n\"On the other hand, economically, China plays a significant role, although we must say that the disproportion in economic power between China and Serbia is very large. Serbia does not represent such a significant market for China as the EU does. But China is very important for Serbia, and in that sense, they are developing relations, hoping for new investments,\" Sretenovic emphasizes, also noting that it is good, but caution is needed on how investments will be repaid to avoid falling into debt servitude.\n\nHe highlights that, symbolically, Xi Jinping is arriving on a tragic date, the 25th anniversary of Serbia's bombing by NATO, \"which is controversial from the perspective of international law,\" and on the tragic date when the Chinese embassy was bombed.\n\n\"These are also important signals. China is showing Serbia support both symbolically and politically, and Serbia hopes that this Chinese step will contribute to slowing down, if not stopping, the tendency of Western countries to challenge the integrity of Serbian territory and Serbian presence in its southern province of Kosovo and Metohija,\" he says.\n\nHe points out that using such strong words in international relations as \"ironclad friendship\" hides a certain policy behind them, and Serbia must be aware of that.\n\nRegarding Serbia's significance to China, Sretenovic reminds us that China's view of Serbia is tied to a global perspective China has towards Europe as a continent, not just the EU, and it involves the Belt and Road Initiative.\n\n\"China wants to project its influence, strength, and economy globally, especially to Asian, African, and European countries. In that sense, Serbia represents a small but significant link that, due to its geographical position, connects Asia, Africa, and Europe. Through Serbian territory, Chinese economic influence can flow, as China in Europe owns a very significant port it acquired, which is the Port of Piraeus in Greece,\" Sretenovic says.\n\nHe adds that Chinese investments are significant not only in Serbia but also in Hungary.\n\n\"At a time when two significant EU countries are withdrawing from the Belt and Road Initiative, I'm primarily referring to Italy's withdrawal and Poland's withdrawal, Hungary remains a significant lever for China, and its southern neighbor Serbia and Serbian southern neighbor Greece represent that wing that, according to Chinese estimates, can play a significant role in further developing Chinese investments and economic penetration,\" he explains.\n\nHe warns that for small countries, it is important that China's economic presence does not bring along too much political influence in the internal politics of these countries.\n\n\"Serbian politicians need to be wise and utilize all the benefits of the support Serbia currently has, but also be aware that Chinese investments and Chinese political influence domestically must be placed within certain legal frameworks and not exceed a level that would bring benefit to Serbia,\" he concludes.\n\nSretenovic, however, reminds us that this does not apply to China's foreign policy influence because China supports Serbia's integrity, just as Serbia supports China's integrity regarding Taiwan.\n\n\"So, a balance, a common interest has been established on the foreign policy level, which may not bring concrete benefits in the field, but at least at the level of international law, symbolism, setting some limits to the omnipotence of Western countries - it can play a role,\" Sretenovic believes.\n\nChina is a partner but also a competitor of the EU\n\nHe also notes that France needs China as a significant European country, one of the two engines of the EU (alongside Germany), and that the discussions in Paris were mostly about economic relations, where, he says, significant problems exist.\n\n\"But strategically, China needs the EU because China is the only factor that can influence Russia at the moment in terms of calming the war in Ukraine, if not stopping it,\" he explains.\n\nFrom an economic perspective, China is a partner of the EU but also a competitor who, as he says, floods the European market with goods, and intervenes with the state in its economic affairs, \"which is unacceptable from the perspective of the EU's liberal economy,\" and does not respect some EU rules on production quality, copyrights, etc.\n\nThe visit to France is also symbolic, according to Sretenovic, as it happened on the 60th anniversary of the establishment of Franco-Chinese bilateral relations in 1964, when France, after a very difficult period after the wars in Indochina and Algeria, recognized communist China.", "source": {"uri": "kosovo-online.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Kosovo Online"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8115083820", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "07:47:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T07:47:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T07:47:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/ca536cdb-8847-4c2e-9eca-1621e48a04dc", "title": "Xi Jinping lashes out at Nato over 1999 Belgrade bombing ahead of Serbia visit", "body": "China's President Xi Jinping has lashed out at Nato over its \"flagrant\" bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade in 1999 as he tries to cement ties with Serbia ahead of a visit to the Balkan country on Tuesday.\n\nXi, who is travelling in Europe for the first time in five years, will head to Serbia on Tuesday afternoon from the French Pyrenees, where French President Emmanuel Macron is hosting him on the final day of a three-day state visit to France.\n\nIn a signed letter in the Serbian media outlet, Politika, Xi invoked the 25th anniversary on Tuesday of the Nato bombing of the Chinese embassy in the former Yugoslavia during the Kosovo war to call for unity between Beijing and Belgrade.\n\n\"Twenty-five years ago today, Nato flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy in Yugoslavia, killing three Chinese journalists\u2009.\u2009.\u2009.\u2009This we should never forget,\" Xi said, according to an English version of the article. \"The China-Serbia friendship, forged with the blood of our compatriots, will stay in the shared memory of the Chinese and Serbian peoples.\"\n\nHis European trip, which will also include Hungary, is seen by analysts as aiming to exploit differences on the continent in attitudes towards Russia and the US and potentially undermine the unity of Nato and the EU on China.\n\nChinese academics have praised Macron's advocacy of a more independent European stance on the global stage while Serbia and Hungary are seen as more pro-Russia despite the Ukraine war.\n\nDuring Xi's visit, French and Chinese companies signed several co-agreements, including metro construction contracts for France's Alstom and a memorandum of understanding with Airbus on deepening aviation co-operation, but no big orders.\n\nSerbian President Aleksandar Vu\u010di\u0107, who will host Xi, was propaganda minister for former leader Slobodan Milo\u0161evi\u0107 during the Nato bombing of Belgrade -- an event that solidified Serbia's anti-American stance.\n\nNato has said the Chinese embassy bombing was an accident that happened during a war to protect Kosovans from Serbian aggression.\n\nIn one potential sweetener for Serbia, China's customs administration announced on Tuesday that it would lift an avian flu alert on Serbian poultry products.\n\nChinese media have carried several days of blanket coverage of Xi's trip to Europe. The People's Daily, the Communist party mouthpiece, quoted him as telling Macron and European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen at the \u00c9lys\u00e9e Palace on Monday that there was \"no "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3262053/xi-jinping-skips-site-1999-nato-bombing-serbia-visit-seen-calculated-move-avoid-stoking-tension-west", "title": "Xi Jinping skips Nato bombing site in Serbia, seen as 'calculated move' for West", "body": "Visit \u2018shows Xi does not want to overly irritate the US, or put his Serbian hosts in a difficult position\u2019 with the EU, says analyst\n\nBut timing the visit to coincide with the anniversary of deaths of three Chinese journalists is in itself viewed as a message to US-led West\n\nA decision by President Xi Jinping not to visit China\u2019s former embassy in Belgrade on the 25th anniversary of Nato\u2019s bombing of the site has been described as a \u201ccalculated move\u201d to avoid stoking tensions with the US-led West.\n\nThe omission from Xi\u2019s itinerary of the bombing site, which he toured during his first state visit to Serbia in 2016, came as a surprise to many watching the Chinese leader\u2019s trip to Serbia this week.\n\nThree Chinese journalists were killed when US-led Nato used missiles to attack the embassy in Belgrade on May 7, 1999, prompting a major crisis between Beijing and Washington, which the latter insisted was a \u201ctragic mistake\u201d.\n\nDeng Yuwen, former deputy editor of the Communist Party\u2019s flagship newspaper Study Times, said Xi\u2019s no-show at the bombing site was due, in part, to his tight schedule during the Serbian visit.\n\n\u201cBut, of course, it also shows Xi does not want to overly irritate the US, or put his Serbian hosts in a difficult position,\u201d he said. \u201cIf Xi went ahead with a speech commemorating the anniversary on top of a much-anticipated visit to the site, the European Union would probably put pressure on Serbia.\u201d\n\nWhile Serbia is seen as one of the most China-friendly countries in Europe, especially after Nato\u2019s bombing of the former Yugoslavia between March and June 1999, it is one of the six Western Balkan countries applying for EU membership.\n\nShen Dingli, an expert on international relations in Shanghai, said Beijing obviously did not want to embarrass Belgrade, which \u201cwould join the EU and Nato sooner or later\u201d.\n\n\u201cIt is clear that China does not want to further alienate itself at a time when Beijing has already edged closer toward Russia during Moscow\u2019s invasion of Ukraine,\u201d he said.\n\nBut it did not mean Beijing would change its adversarial approach towards Washington, Shen said.\n\n\u201cAs part of a three-nation European tour, Xi intentionally chose the anniversary [of the Nato bombing] to visit Serbia, which underlined his deep-seated anti-West views,\u201d he said. \u201cBeijing could have avoided this particular day for his visit to Serbia if it wants to show its willingness to improve ties with the US and Nato.\u201d\n\nYun Sun, co-director of the East Asia programme and director of the China programme at the Washington-based Stimson Centre, said Xi\u2019s second state visit to Serbia on the anniversary of the embassy bombing could hardly be a coincidence.\n\nDespite the embassy site not being among the president\u2019s stops, \u201cBeijing still criticised Nato,\u201d she said, noting the Chinese leader\u2019s pledge to \u201cnever forget\u201d the incident in an opinion piece published in Serbia\u2019s Politika newspaper on Tuesday.\n\n\u201cChina is in \u2026 stabilisation mode with the US so there is no need to strike that angle \u2026 and a touch on the bombing is enough,\u201d Sun said.\n\nIn the article published before Xi arrived in Belgrade, the president wrote, \u201cthe China-Serbia friendship, forged with the blood of our compatriots, will stay in the collective memory of the Chinese and Serbian peoples\u201d.\n\nDuring the visit, Xi announced the elevation of \u201cthe comprehensive strategic partnership\u201d with Serbia and signed a total of 28 agreements to deepen economic and other cooperation.\n\nEchoing the Chinese leader, Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic told a rally welcoming Xi on Wednesday: \u201cDo not forget that our Chinese friends were with us 25 years ago when this country was being demolished and bombed\u201d.\n\nLu Xiang, an expert from the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, said with Xi\u2019s 2016 visit to the bombing site and the Politika article, Beijing had clearly stated its stance on the incident.\n\n\u201cThere is no need to hold a commemorative ceremony every time he visits Serbia. And there is no need to let a historical event dominate the current China-Serbia relations and China-EU relations,\u201d he said.", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "South {"uri": "8117380343", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "12:38:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T12:38:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T12:37:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.b92.net/english/politics/20353/vucic-after-the-meeting-with-xi-jinping-xi-gave-me-two-important-news-well-have-chinas-support-in-the-un/vest", "title": "Vu\u010di\u0107 after the meeting with Xi Jinping: \"Xi gave me two important news; We'll have China's support in the UN\"", "body": "Serbian President Aleksandar Vu\u010di\u0107 and Chinese President Xi Jinping addressed the public after signing a joint statement and exchanging bilateral agreements, thus ending the official part of the visit.\n\nVu\u010di\u0107 reminded that he had repeatedly sent an invitation to the Chinese President to visit Serbia and that Xi Jinping has already visited our country twice, which is an exceptional honor.\n\n\"I am honored to be the host. I invited President Xi to visit Serbia, to come to such a small country twice in eight years, and I am thrilled that he is here. Although it was narrower, after the broader format of the conversation, my colleagues said that they had never heard that some conversations were so fundamentally and deeply devoted to our relations,\" said Vu\u010di\u0107.\n\n\"We could hear and learn a lot from the Chinese President, and we hope that we can learn more,\" said Vu\u010di\u0107, emphasizing that Serbia has worked hard to improve relations with China, which is our biggest economic partner.\n\nVu\u010di\u0107 also pointed out that he and the Chinese President signed a joint statement, which means that Serbia and China are moving from strategic relations to the highest quality of cooperation - a community that speaks of the common future of our two countries.\n\nVu\u010di\u0107 also said that the international pressure on Serbia is enormous, but that our country will defend itself with all its might, adding that Serbia will have the firm support of China on all issues raised within the UN, as well as that Serbia and China, with today's signed joint statement are moving from strategic bilateral relations to a community that, as he said, speaks of a common future and emphasized that it is the highest form of cooperation between the two countries.\n\nHe pointed out that the results of today's talks are that, in addition to Serbia supporting the principle of One China, for our country any question that someone would ask the People's Republic of China is their internal question, inckuding Taiwan, Xinjiang, Hong Kong.\n\n\"That is a question for the People's Republic of China. As China wants to solve these things, that is how it will be. And it will always have the support of the Republic of Serbia for such a thing, because that is what the United Nations charter is based on, along with the international public law,\" said Vu\u010di\u0107.\n\nHe pointed out that he is grateful to President Xi for his very clear positions on the issue of Kosovo and Metohija - the territorial integrity of the Republic of Serbia.\n\n\"But, I quote President Xi - the Republic of Serbia will have the firm support of the People's Republic of China on all issues that are raised within the framework of the United Nations. This is extremely important for us\", said Vu\u010di\u0107.\n\nSpeaking about the continuation of economic cooperation with China, Vu\u010di\u0107 said that Xi shared with him two very important news:\n\n\"China will ensure that 300 young people from Serbia study in China, and he also proposed that 50 of our scientific workers go to China. Do you know what does that mean for them? Xi emphasized the importance of scientific cooperation. He also proposed the formation of an intergovernmental technological committee, which is very important to us, and we also discussed the development of artificial intelligence,\" said Serbian president.\n\nLet us remind you that Xi Jinping is on a two-day visit to Serbia. He was welcomed at the airport last night, and the official program continued today.\n\nThe Chinese President did not miss any opportunity to emphasize that he is very happy about this visit and that Serbia and China are connected by \"steel friendship\".", "source": {"uri": "b92.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "B92"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Such friendship is characterized by profound historical roots, solid political foundation, extensive common interests and strong popular support.\n\n-- Over the past few years, under the leadership of Xi and Vucic, the bilateral relationship has leapfrogged with historic progress, and since the establishment of a comprehensive strategic partnership in 2016, in particular, the bilateral relationship has been enriched in substance and expanded in scope, which has become an example for China's friendly relations with other European countries.\n\n-- Actions speak louder than words. China will stand shoulder to shoulder with Serbia, share weal and woe like passengers in the same boat, carry forward the spirit of the ironclad friendship, maintain and grow their friendship, and jointly safeguard fundamental and long-term interests of the two countries.\n\n-- As the two sides pursue their respective national development and revitalization, China will join hands with Serbia to advance the building of a community with a shared future in the new era.\n\n-- Serbia is China's first comprehensive strategic partner in Central and Eastern Europe. Their bilateral cooperation has injected strong impetus into their respective development and rejuvenation, and brought tangible benefits to the two peoples.\n\n-- Under the new circumstances, Serbia has become the first European country to build with China a community with a shared future, which speaks volumes about the strategic, special and high-level China-Serbia relations.\n\n-- The China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era is an upgrade of the ironclad friendship between China and Serbia. It also represents their common values and objectives, namely, joint pursuit of development, win-win cooperation and mutual success. These are the common aspirations of China, Serbia, and all countries that are committed to independence, peace and development.\n\nON COOPERATION AND PEOPLE-TO-PEOPLE EXCHANGES\n\n-- Standing at a new historical starting point, China will work with Serbia to jointly stay committed to the original aspiration and forge ahead together to open up a new vista in China-Serbia cooperation with stronger momentum, greater scope, and higher quality.\n\n-- By building a China-Serbia community with a shared future in the new era, the two sides should keep deepening and expanding high-quality Belt and Road cooperation and collaboration between China and Central and Eastern European countries, thus contributing to their respective modernization.\n\n-- High-quality Belt and Road cooperation between China and Serbia has achieved remarkable results. The two sides should steadily advance cooperation in traditional areas such as transportation and energy infrastructure, make sure the entire Serbian section of the Belgrade-Budapest railway go into operation as scheduled, jointly operate well their major cooperation projects, create more small and beautiful livelihood projects, and continue to generate positive economic and social impacts.\n\n-- China supports Serbia in upholding independence and pursuing a development path suited to its national conditions, and supports its efforts in safeguarding national sovereignty and territorial integrity. The two sides should continue to offer each other firm support, deepen strategic cooperation, and safeguard their respective political security and fundamental interests.\n\n-- It is important for China and Serbia to jointly reject hegemonism and power politics, and oppose bloc politics or bloc confrontation. The two sides should join hands to uphold the purposes and principles of the UN Charter, practice true multilateralism, and promote international fairness and justice.\n\n-- With the China-Serbia Free Trade Agreement set to take effect on July 1 this year, the high-standard mutual opening up between China and Serbia will surely enter a new stage.\n\n-- China will continue to import more high-quality agricultural specialties from Serbia.\n\n-- China supports Serbia in hosting Expo 2027, and will send a delegation to participate in the grand show. China encourages its enterprises to take part in the construction of relevant projects.\n\n-- China will support 50 young Serbian scientists in taking part in scientific research exchanges in China in the next three years. It is ready to work with Serbia to strengthen cooperation on artificial intelligence (AI) and endeavor to ensure humanity properly develop and utilize AI.\n\n-- China will invite 300 young Serbians to China on study and exchange programs in the next three years.\n\n-- China welcomes the opening of direct flights from Belgrade to Shanghai by the Serbian side so as to comprehensively deepen {"uri": "8117241149", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:13:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:13:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:12:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.chinadaily.com.cn/a/202405/08/WS663b5d7ba31082fc043c5f8e.html", "title": "Visit provides fresh impetus to boost dynamism of Sino-Serbian friendship: China Daily editorial", "body": "Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Belgrade, capital of Serbia, on Tuesday night for a state visit to the Republic of Serbia on the second leg of his European trip.\n\nUnlike his first stop in France, where he discussed some of the thorniest issues affecting China's relations with not only France but also the European Union, the Chinese leader will have had easier discussions in the Balkan country, whose friendly relations with China have remained steadfast.\n\nIf his meetings in France with President Emmanuel Macron and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen were about improving ties and deepening mutual understanding, those with his Serbian hosts will have been on ways to carry forward and strengthen the amity and close cooperation between the two countries.\n\nSerbian President Aleksandar Vucic has been a staunch supporter of friendly ties with China despite the geopolitical headwinds across Europe. He has defied the recent European tendency to target China as a \"systemic rival\" and offered his support for Beijing's proposals against major-power competition and for peace and cooperation.\n\nWith long-standing cordiality dating back to the era of socialist Yugoslavia, the friendship between China and present-day Serbia has stood the test of dramatic geopolitical changes. The Chinese leader's visit will only cement and upgrade what has already been in his own words an example of fine state-to-state relations, making the friendship between the two countries even more dynamic.\n\nThe relationship between the two countries carries very special significance today as both countries seek to carry forward their traditional friendship and mutually beneficial cooperation amid the increasing global volatility.\n\nIn addition to expanding their common interests in economic and trade cooperation, the two countries have also sought and found broad common ground on regional and global affairs.\n\nThe importance the Chinese leader attaches to the bilateral relationship is obvious in the title of his signed article published in a local newspaper, Politika: \"Let the Light of Ironclad Friendship Illuminate the Road of China-Serbia Cooperation\".\n\nSuch amity has prospered particularly under the Chinese president's own watch. It was during his first visit to Belgrade in 2016 that the two countries established a strategic partnership. Last year, he and visiting President Vucic witnessed the signing of dozens of new cooperation agreements in Beijing, including a free trade deal expected to take effect in July.\n\nChina was Serbia's second-largest trading partner, after the European Union, last year with a total trade exchange of $6.1 billion, and it was among its top five investors. Serbia is a firm supporter of the Belt and Road Initiative. China-financed infrastructure projects under the framework of the initiative have become key development boosters of the country.\n\nSerbian enthusiasm for Chinese economic and trade connections stands in sharp contrast with the noise in Europe for \"de-risking\" from China. That the Chinese president's arrival in Serbia coincided with the 25th anniversary of the NATO bombing of the Chinese embassy has been widely interpreted as a pointed message on the growing unease between Beijing and the bloc that, encouraged by Washington, is seeking to extend its tentacles to the Asia-Pacific region citing \"systematic challenges\" posed by China.\n\n\"The Chinese people cherish peace, but we will never allow such tragic history to repeat itself,\" the Chinese leader said in the Politika article.\n\nThere is concern that the EU's growing unease about China's development momentum may be recklessly exploited by the string-puller of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to a crisis-causing degree.\n\nBeijing looks forward to taking Xi's visit as an opportunity to keep relations with Europe on the right track of healthy development, so that the latter can view its relationship with China more objectively.", "source": {"uri": "chinadaily.com.cn", In honor of the arrival of the Chinese president, billboards with inscriptions in Serbian and Chinese were also put up.\n\n\"Welcome, respected Chinese friends,\" the billboards read, while the flags of the two countries are also displayed along the highway leading from the airport.\n\nThe Belgrade Tower - the Western Gate of Belgrade - was draped in the Chinese flag, as another gesture of welcome.", "source": {"uri": "telegraf.rs", "dataType": "news", "title": "Telegraf.rs"}, "authors": [{"uri": "d_r@telegraf.rs", "name": "D. {"uri": "8117544678", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:19:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:19:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:19:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://sarajevotimes.com/vucic-and-xi-cooperation-between-serbia-and-china-at-the-highest-level/", "title": "Vucic and Xi: Cooperation between Serbia and China at the highest level - Sarajevo Times", "body": "President of Serbia Aleksandar Vu\u010di\u0107 and President of the People's Republic of China Xi Jinping signed today in Belgrade the Joint Statement of the two countries on deepening and raising the comprehensive strategic partnership and building the community of Serbia and China with a common future in the new era.\n\nAfter the meeting, Vu\u010di\u0107 expressed his gratitude to Chinese President Xi Jinping for the support that country provides to the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Serbia, and said that his country supports the principle of \"one China\".\n\nHe said that in 2021, 2022 and 2023, China is the biggest investor in Serbia and that exports to the People's Republic of China have increased 140 times in the last ten years.\n\n\"Our trade exchange, direct trade between our countries in the last ten years, has increased as much as eight times. Investments in the Republic of Serbia in the previous ten years have increased 30 times from the People's Republic of China,\" said Vu\u010di\u0107.\n\nHe added that Serbia and China are moving from strategic relations, to which they succeeded in raising the bilateral relations of the two countries, to a community with a common future in the new era.\n\n\"It is the highest form of cooperation between the two countries and I am proud that today, as the President of the Republic of Serbia, I was able to sign such a statement with President Xi,\" said Vu\u010di\u0107.\n\nAt the ceremony in the Palace of Serbia, 28 documents on cooperation were exchanged. Vu\u010di\u0107 said that the Free Trade Agreement with the People's Republic of China guarantees Serbia the placement of goods and services.\n\n\"And in the next five to ten years, we will be able to export almost 95 percent of the products that we make, that we produce in our country to the People's Republic of China without any tariffs, without any duties,\" said Vu\u010di\u0107.\n\nHe added that he sent a request to the President of China to open a production plant in Serbia for the production of trains, which China is very famous for. He also added that Serbia is negotiating with a Chinese company about flying taxis that they want to establish by 2027.\n\n\"In all areas of social life, we see the possibility for enormous progress - from the fields of culture and sports, to our finances, further overall progress,\" said Vu\u010di\u0107 and added:\n\n\"No one can break the iron friendship between China and Serbia. We are loyal people, and we are grateful to you for always standing by Serbia when it was in trouble. Serbia will stand by China even when the People's Republic of China is in trouble.\"\n\nThe President of China said that he was honored and impressed by the magnificent welcome in Belgrade, the hospitality and friendship of the Serbian people, which confirms that the relations between the two countries are at a high level and that there is a sincere and steely friendship between the two peoples.\n\n\"In China, we say that mountains cannot meet, but people can. In China, we say that great geographical distances cannot separate people when there are mutual affinities,\" the Chinese president said.\n\nXi said that Serbia was committed to independence and defended its sovereignty, territorial integrity and national dignity, and that the country deserves the respect of the international community.\n\n\"The steely friendship between our countries has only strengthened, even in this changing international dynamic. This friendship is rooted in history, and indeed it enjoys strong political foundations, common interests and firm support of the people,\" Xi said.\n\nIn the end, he said that China wants to work with Serbia and continue in the spirit of \"steel friendship\".\n\n\"We will work together with Serbia, to defend our fundamental and long-term, long-term interests. And when it comes to various international developments, we want to build that community with a common future in the new era and this is part of our efforts to contribute to the community for a common future for the whole of humanity,\" the Chinese president concluded, AA writes.\n\nPhoto: Anadolu Agency", "source": {"uri": "sarajevotimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sarajevo Times"}, We've apologized. I believe we've actually even paid reparations to the families. I do believe that the timing of the visit was unfortunate but deliberate,\" Gabriel Escobar, the US special envoy, said in an online media briefing.\n\nHe added that it is \"unhealthy\" to increase tensions between Serbia and the Western countries, and cautioned all partners \"to be very aware of China's agenda in Europe.\"\n\nSpeaking about relations between Serbia and Russia, Escobar said that Moscow is not the cause of the problems but it takes advantage of the problems.\u00e2\u20ac\u00a8\n\n\"It would be a mistake to look at Russia as the cause of the problems in the Balkans. Russia takes advantage of the problems in the Balkans, but the problems are those that have existed for the last 25 years. And by resolving the problems, I think we close off the opportunities for Russia to make mischief in the region,\" he added.\n\nEscobar expressed hope for Western Balkans countries to continue their path to the EU.\n\nChina and Serbia signed 28 cooperation documents on Wednesday following a meeting between visiting Xi and his Serbian counterpart Aleksandar Vucic.\n\nA large crowd gathered on the {"uri": "2024-05-347987392", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-07", "time": "16:17:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-07T16:17:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-07T16:03:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/serbia-prepares-warm-welcome-xi-160330996.html", "title": "Serbia prepares warm welcome for Xi in contrast to China-EU tensions", "body": "Chinese flags adorned highways as Serbia got ready to give a home-from-home welcome to Xi Jinping, in contrasting to tensions on the first leg of the Chinese president's six-day European tour over a potential trade war with the EU.\n\nXi prepared for his arrival in Belgrade on Tuesday night by hitting out against Nato for its 1999 bombing of the Chinese embassy in the Serbian capital, in which three Chinese journalists were killed.\n\nIn an article for the Serbian website Politika, Xi wrote: \"Twenty-five years ago, Nato flagrantly bombed the Chinese embassy in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, killing three Chinese journalists, namely Shao Yunhuan, Xu Singhu and his wife, Zhu Ying. We must never forget this.\"\n\nHe said the \"friendship of China and Serbia\" was \"soaked in the shared blood of the two nations\" and \"the close cooperation between\" them since his last visit there eight years ago.\n\nRelated: Xi's European tour: where is Chinese leader going and what are visit's aims?\n\nXi is spending the majority of his trip to Europe in Serbia and Hungary, which are seen as China-friendly, unlike most of the EU which sees Beijing as a trade and political rival.\n\nWhile the European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, restated the EU's readiness to impose tariffs on cheap Chinese imports including electric cars after her talks with Xi on Monday, Xi can expect full support in Belgrade, and in Budapest when he travels there later this week.\n\nBefore leaving France, Xi visited the Pyrenees with the French president, Emmanuel Macron. He said he would welcome more high-level talks on trade frictions, but denied there was a Chinese \"overcapacity problem\", casting doubt on how much progress could eventually be achieved on trade.\n\nAfter watching traditional dancers perform under the snowy peaks, the two leaders ate locally grown ham, lamb, cheese and blueberry pie. Macron gave Xi a woollen blanket made in the Pyrenees, a Tour de France jersey and armagnac from the nearby south-western region.\n\nFrench brandy is at risk of being hit by Chinese trade sanctions after Beijing opened an anti-dumping investigation into European brandy, seen as retaliation against the EU's mounting number of inquiries into alleged Bejing subsidies for exported electric cars, solar panels, wind turbines and medical devices.\n\nFrench and Chinese companies concluded some agreements on Monday in areas including energy, finance and transport on the sidelines of Xi's visit, but most were agreements to cooperate or renewed commitments to work together, and there were no significant deals.\n\nEuropean hopes of an Airbus plane order to coincide with Xi's visit appear to have been dashed, with the two sides agreeing only to expand cooperation.\n\nA European diplomat said Xi was the winner of the visit, having \"cemented his image as the 'ruler of the world' where westerners are begging him to solve European problems in Ukraine\".\n\nSerbia and Hungary are supporters of Xi's signature belt and road initiative to build ports, railways and power plants around the world as a way of boosting soft power and economic growth. Direct Chinese investment in the two countries exceeds \u20ac15bn, with more coming including China's first electric car factory in the EU, which will be built in Hungary.\n\nXi is expected to highlight a new high-speed train service between Belgrade and Budapest that is being built by China Railway, underlining the willingness of the Serbian president, Aleksandar Vu\u010di\u0107, to do business with Beijing.\n\nOn the political side, all eyes will be on Vu\u010di\u0107 and the Hungarian prime minister Viktor Orb\u00e1n's east-west balancing act, with both countries also considered friendly towards Russia's Vladimir Putin.\n\nLast year Orb\u00e1n reaffirmed his commitment to bilateral ties with Russia when he met Putin on the sidelines of a belt and road conference in Beijing, causing outrage in the EU.\n\nXi heaped praise on Vu\u010di\u0107 in his letter in Politika, talking about their \"meetings, telephone conversations and exchange of letters\" and noting China's position \"as the largest source of foreign investment and Serbia's second largest trade partner\".", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News UK"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Government", "label": "dmoz/Society/Government", "wgt": 14}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "label": "dmoz/Society/Government/Multilateral", "wgt": 16}, {"uri":
